The concise menu only features 13 items, but seasonal dishes, not on the menu, are also available. The chef’s signature dish, sweet and sour pork, is made to order, so expect to wait. The ginger chicken is simply divine – tender chicken glazed in a mild chilli sauce alongside zesty pickled ginger shoots. Also, try the kale with prawns.

Name: Muthu's Curry
Description: ‘Muthu’ means pearl in Tamil, which befits this gem (with another branche) serving traditional dishes from both the Southern and Northern regions of India. Originally called Muthu Makkan, the owner expanded and renamed the restaurant in 1982. The signature fish head, South Indian-style, uses a secret blend of spices. Swimmer crabs, masala prawns, lamb rack and tandoori chicken are also big hits among diners. Ask about the monthly specials.

Name: New Lucky Claypot Rice
Address: Holland Drive Market & Food Centre, #02-19, 44 Holland Drive, 270044, Singapore
Description: The claypot rice here is cooked to order over charcoal from scratch; the rice grains are left soft, chewy and separable from each other. The portion size is plenty for two to share. To avoid a long wait, call to pre-order.

Name: MP Thai (Vision Exchange)
Description: This simple shop may not be the most atmospheric, but its tasty food in generous portions at affordable prices always attracts a crowd. With a Thai owner and all Thai kitchen team, rest assured that the food is as authentic as can be. The tom yum soup strikes a fine balance between sour, sweet, spicy and salty tastes; the BBQ squid is nicely grilled and loaded with umami, perfect with the hot and sour sauce. Reservation recommended.

Name: Han Kee
Address: Amoy Street Food Centre, #02-129, 7 Maxwell Road, 069111, Singapore
Description: There is always a queue at this stall famous for umami-laden soup made with mackerel. Enjoy the soup on its own, or use it as a rich base for porridge or bee hoon with sliced fish or fish head. Come early to beat the crowd.

Name: Delhi Lahori
Description: The experienced tandoor master knows his clay oven inside out. His fluffy, crispy naans have a loyal following. His grilled-to-order seekh kebab and chicken tikka masala are also exceptional and come in generous portions.

Name: Un-Yang-Kor-Dai
Description: Though its name means ‘anything goes’, this restaurant is exceptionally specific about the food it serves – Isan cuisine hailing from north-eastern Thailand and famous for its infernal heat. The PenLaos signature chicken is marinated with white peppercorns and coriander for three days before being grilled to perfection. Leng zaab is pork ribs in a spicy sour broth that is simply addictive. Ask for the house-made Isan tamarind dip to dunk the pork in.

Name: Tian Tian Hainanese Chicken Rice
Address: Maxwell Food Centre, #01-10/11, 1 Kadayanallur Street, 069184, Singapore
Description: Expect a long queue, but the velvety chicken with springy skin is worth the wait. Even the aromatic oil rice and briny-sweet sauce are perfectly made. Consider ordering half a chicken to share, or an extra drumstick.

Name: Eminent Frog Porridge & Seafood (Lor 19)
Description: Frog is certainly big on the menu – besides the famous frog porridge, try frog fried with ginger and scallion or tossed in Kung Pao sauce. A favourite spot among locals for late-night supper, this place is always packed, so be prepared to wait.

Name: Ar Er Soup
Address: ABC Brickworks Market & Food Centre, #01-141, Blk 6 Jalan Bukit Merah, 150006, Singapore
Description: Offers 8 kinds of MSG-free long-boiled soups, served with pumpkin rice.

Name: Hong Kong Yummy Soup
Address: Alexandra Village Food Centre, #01-51, Blk 120 Bukit Merah Lane 1, 150120, Singapore
Description: Here, the second generation of the family sells local-style salad with pineapple, cucumber and deep-fried dough stick, tossed in a special home-made sauce and sprinkled with ground peanuts. Chilli is optional.

Name: A Noodle Story
Address: Amoy Street Food Centre, #01-39, 7 Maxwell Road, 069111, Singapore
Description: The stall has an interesting look and sells local, traditional noodles cooked in an innovative way.

Name: Chuan Kee Boneless Braised Duck
Address: 20 Ghim Moh Road Market & Food Centre, #01-04, Blk 20, Ghim Moh Road, 270020, Singapore
Description: Juicy and flavoursome braised duck is served with rice, congee, kway teow or noodles, plus optional extras such as duck gizzard, duck liver or marinated egg. The "set" comes with a bowl of bak kut teh.

Name: Soh Kee Cooked Food
Address: Jurong West 505 Market & Food Centre, #01-44, Blk 505, Jurong West Street 52, 640505, Singapore
Description: Serves porridge with chicken, fish or cuttlefish. Sets for one to three people are also available.

Name: Tai Wah Pork Noodle
Address: Hong Lim Market and Food Centre, #02-16, Blk 531A, Upper Cross Street, 051531, Singapore
Description: Noodles served with soup meat balls, dried fish and pork liver.

Name: Outram Park Fried Kway Teow Mee
Address: Hong Lim Market and Food Centre, #02-17, Blk 531A, Upper Cross Street, 051531, Singapore
Description: The Kway Teow is fried with a dark sauce you can add cockles to the noodles. Always a long queue.

Name: Hoo Kee Bak Chang
Address: Amoy Street Food Centre, #01-18, 7 Maxwell Road, 069111, Singapore
Description: Glutinous rice mixed with salted duck egg yolk pork and chestnut wrapped with bamboo leaf.

Name: Kelantan Kway Chap · Pig Organ Soup
Address: Berseh Food Centre, #02-39, 166 Jalan Besar, 208877, Singapore
Description: Pork cuts and offal like belly, trotter, intestines and skin are cooked in a soy-based marinade with spices. The depth and rich flavours of the meat are the perfect accompaniment to the kway chap ribbon noodles.

Name: Chey Sua Carrot Cake
Address: 127 Toa Payoh West Market & Food Centre, #02-30, Blk 127, Lorong 1 Toa Payoh, 310127, Singapore
Description: The pan-fried radish cake is hugely popular. Fried on one side until golden, it allows you to taste the caramelised crispy bits and the soft moist cake at the same time. The cakes are fried to order, so expect a longer waiting time.

Name: Adam Rd Noo Cheng Big Prawn Noodle
Address: Adam Food Centre, #01-27, 2 Adam Road, 289876, Singapore
Description: The prawn mee cooked à la minute is a recipe from the owner’s father. Opt for “dry” noodles tossed in prawn paste of your desired level of heat, alongside a bowl of prawn soup. Toppings like pig skin add contrasting textures.

Name: Jason Penang Cuisine
Address: ABC Brickworks Market & Food Centre, #01-112, Blk 6 Jalan Bukit Merah, 150006, Singapore
Description: Besides Penangese quick bites from char kway teow to prawn mee, this stall is famous for Penang assam laksa – the tangy, mildly hot yellowtail fish broth works magic with the noodles; but it's the fresh mint that makes it so distinctive.

Name: Chai Chuan Tou Yang Rou Tang
Address: 115 Bukit Merah View Market & Hawker Centre, #01-51, Blk 115 Bukit Merah View, 151115, Singapore
Description: The mutton soup here can be paired with tripe, meatballs, tendon or even brain. The mutton boasts the right mix of fatty and lean meat, without tasting gamey. The broth has a mildly herbal flavour. Come early as they tend to sell out.

Name: Sin Huat Seafood Restaurant
Description: Fried rice vermicelli with crab, available for dinner, is the main event. The gigantic crab is loaded with seafood flavour; the vermicelli pick up the juices nicely, exuding scallion, ginger and chilli aromas. The other seafood dishes are also tasty.

Name: Du Du Shou Shi
Address: Jurong West 505 Market & Food Centre, #01-19, Blk 505, Jurong West Street 52, 640505, Singapore
Description: This stall carries two varieties of tu tu kueh – coconut and peanut. The steamed rice cake is chewy and springy on the outside; both fillings are nutty, sweet and aromatic. Best enjoyed piping hot!

Name: Tai Seng Fish Soup
Address: Taman Jurong Market & Food Centre, #03-145, 3 Yung Sheng Road, Jurong West, 618499, Singapore
Description: This third-generation family business prides itself on its flavoursome fish soup made from scratch and served with sliced fish, deep-fried fish or fish head. Order noodles, rice or congee on the side for a complete meal.

Name: Hai Nan Xing Zhou Beef Noodle
Address: Kim Keat Palm Market & Food Centre, #01-06, 22 Lorong 7 Toa Payoh, 310022, Singapore
Description: Choose between blanched rice noodles tossed in a thick gravy, or soup noodles in a deeply flavourful ox bone broth. Then top with sliced beef, beef tripe, tendon, beef balls, or a combination.

Name: Spinach Soup
Address: Geylang Bahru Market & Food Centre, #01-12, 69 Geylang Bahru, 330069, Singapore
Description: This is the place to come for a comforting bowl of soup. The broth is flavourful and sweet; the spinach is crisp and fresh. You can also order stuffed tofu or seafood on top, or add mee tai mak for some starchiness.

Name: Heng Kee
Address: Hong Lim Market and Food Centre, #01-58, Blk 531A, Upper Cross Street, 051531, Singapore
Description: This stall, founded in the 1970s, is now run by the second-generation owner. Its hallmark dishes are mild, well-balanced curry broth, custom-made tofu puffs and fish cakes, as well as generous helpings of velvety chicken.

Name: Da Shi Jia Big Prawn Mee
Description: Guests are spoiled for choices here. First, pick between prawn noodle soup and fried prawn bee hoon. For prawn mee, specify the size of these wild-caught marine crustaceans – from regular to XXL. Then pick your noodles –the yellow variety, kway teow, bee hoon, or any combination of those. For real big eaters, choose extra toppings of fish cake, pork ribs or sliced pork. Don’t forget about snacks like tofu skin prawn rolls and fried prawn balls on the side.

Name: Hong Heng Fried Sotong Prawn Mee
Address: Tiong Bahru Market, #02-01, 30 Seng Poh Road, 168898, Singapore
Description: Cooked-to-order, the noodles stir-fried with sliced fish, squid and prawn and served with homemade chilli sauce is a favourite.

Name: Joo Siah Bak Koot Teh
Description: The signature dish here is pepper-flavoured bak kut teh. The soft pork rib goes well with chilli soy sauce. Earlier closing hours on Sunday.

Name: Bahrakath Mutton Soup
Address: Adam Food Centre, #01-10, 2 Adam Road, 289876, Singapore
Description: Since 1973, this stall has been serving its secret mutton soup recipe. The broth is rich, dense, and full of herbal flavours. Apart from the popular leg, also try other lamb cuts. Order bread to mop up the broth.

Name: No.18 Zion Road Fried Kway Teow
Address: Zion Riverside Food Centre, #017, 70 Zion Road, 247792, Singapore
Description: Kway teow noodles are fried to order and topped with fish cake and cockles. The wok hei impresses with its robust flavours and a hint of spiciness, while the cockles impart extra umami. The wait can be long, but is well worth it.

Name: Zhi Wei Xian Zion Road Big Prawn Noodle
Address: Zion Riverside Food Centre, #04, 70 Zion Road, 247792, Singapore
Description: The soup has a rich prawn flavour. Fresh prawns, chili and pork rinds combine to make a great bowl of noodles.

Name: Hai Nan Zai
Address: Chong Pang Market and Food Centre, #01-129, 105 Yishun Ring Road, 760105, Singapore
Description: Singaporean food such as oyster omelettes, fried prawn mee and carrot cakes. Fried kway teow with cockles and Chinese sausage are cooked-to-order.

Name: Whole Earth
Description: ‘Vegetarian cuisine for non-vegetarians’ is how the team describes their longstanding Thai and Peranakan restaurant. Meat-like textures and flavours are achieved by clever preparations of soy product and tofu. The tangy, crispy mango tamarind tofu roll is jazzed up with Penang rendang, herbs and spices, while the mushrooms deliver a texture that is almost indistinguishable from meat. The cosy interior is simple and bright. Portions big enough to share.

Name: Zai Shun Curry Fish Head
Description: The fish head curry boasts velvety flesh loaded with umami and is hot and spicy, perfect with steamed rice. Besides its eponymous dish, other equally stunning fish dishes and stir-fries are also available.

Name: Koh Brother Pig's Organ Soup
Address: Tiong Bahru Market, #02-29, 30 Seng Poh Road, 168898, Singapore
Description: Provides a wide range of pork offal like liver, chitterlings and tripe in pepper-flavoured stock.

Name: Shi Hui Yuan
Address: Mei Ling Market & Food Centre, #02-33, 159 Mei Chin Road, 140159, Singapore
Description: Thin, smooth rice noodles and gravy - with chicken, duck or chicken feet toppings.

Name: Hui Wei Chilli Ban Mian
Address: Geylang Bahru Market & Food Centre, #01-58, 69 Geylang Bahru, 330069, Singapore
Description: Ribbon noodles made in the stall are served in soup or "dry" – tossed in home-made chilli sauce and topped with minced meat, meatballs, poached egg and fried lard. You can also opt for e-fu or ramen noodles instead.

Name: Ru Ji Kitchen
Address: Holland Drive Market & Food Centre, #02-28/29, 44 Holland Drive, 270044, Singapore
Description: Two adjoining stalls sell noodle soup or "dry" noodles with minced pork, pork balls or fish balls handmade on the spot. The bouncy-textured, deep-flavoured fish balls made with yellowtail are especially popular.

Name: Tiong Bahru Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice
Address: Tiong Bahru Market, #02-82, 30 Seng Poh Road, 168898, Singapore
Description: The rice that comes with the signature Hainanese boneless chicken imparts a mild turmeric aroma. Tender juicy meat, without too much fat under the bouncy, gelatinous skin. The roast chicken is also recommended.

Name: Song Fish Soup
Address: Clementi 448 Food Centre, #01-38, 448 Clementi Ave 3, 120448, Singapore
Description: The menu offers blanched sliced fish, deep-fried fish and fish maw, either in fish broth or bee hoon soup. Fish maw double fish soup lets you sample three items at once. Fish head, clams and shrimps are also available.

Name: Hewelke
Description: Gdańsk’s famous brewer and astronomer Johannes Hevelius lends a variant of his surname to this trendy spot situated in, appropriately enough, a former brewery. The stylish décor includes a vaulted brick ceiling, exposed steel support columns and the odd flash of neon. A bakery by day, in the evening it becomes a restaurant where the cooking adopts global influences, including pan-Asian elements ranging from tom kha to the rightly popular Peking duck. In a nod to Hevelius, the cocktails are named after the planets.

Name: SPOT.
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Terrace
Description: A 19th Century power plant on the edge of Jana Pawla II Park is home to this faux industrial style restaurant. Sit on the terrace overlooking the row of chardonnay vines as you sample something from the exceptional wine list – which champions all things natural and biodynamic, including over 75 native wines. The menu makes a feature of house-smoked ingredients, such as terrific, meaty duck in the beetroot salad. The cooking comes with the added bonus of attractive pricing and generous portions.

Name: Koneser Grill
Description: Its location is one of this restaurant’s many strengths, forming part of Centrum Praskie Koneser, an old vodka distillery that now has the feel of a mini walled village; apartments, shops, art venues and a museum all now sit within the former factory. From the owners of Butchery & Wine, this grill-centric eatery offers a range of quality steaks aged in-house – but everything from the salad to the Basque cheesecake dessert is just as enjoyable. Sharing is the way to go for the best value experience.

Name: Vinissimo
Description: The clue’s in the name: wine takes centre stage at this simply styled and bang on-trend bar-cum-restaurant. On-sale bottles can be glimpsed around the room, while the list contains plenty of great options by the glass. The menu is filled with good value dishes like skrei cod croquettes, which both deliver bags of flavour and show a wise restraint from the kitchen team. Instead of throwing unnecessary ingredients into the mix, they focus on a clean, balanced style of cooking.

Name: Fromażeria
Description: As the name suggests, cheese-lovers will be in heaven at this welcoming, rather unique dining spot. To one side is a smart, bustling little bistro; to the other is a cheese bar with an admirable display of global varieties. A concise selection of carefully executed Polish and modern Mediterranean dishes offers great value; these, naturally, should be followed by a cheese course. If you’re just after a quick snack, pop in for a seasonal cheeseboard with alcohol pairings.

Name: Kieliszki na Próżnej
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Bring your own bottle,Counter dining,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: A huge, gravity-defying rack of wine glasses is the first thing you notice when you arrive at this friendly wine bar and bistro. Next, it’s the striking black and white wildlife mural filling one wall. The appealing menus represent good value, especially at lunchtime, and include hearty dishes that are bursting with bold and punchy flavours. An extensive wine list offers plenty of great quality choices to fill all those glasses with, but ‘bring your own’ is welcome too.

Name: TU.REStAURANT
Description: After a striking, architect-led conversion, this historic military building now boasts a mezzanine, a feature wine wall and a cocktail bar with a communal table. This all adds up to a stylish and characterful restaurant; one which also features a wide-ranging, modern European menu that includes small plates, large dishes to share and a small pasta selection. Everything is well-priced and appealing, with crêpes Suzettes a must if you get the chance.

Name: MOLÁM
Description: A fun evening out is on the cards at this lively spot inspired by the night canteens of Bangkok. An open kitchen and vintage vibe contribute to the party atmosphere, which is helped along by a range of Thai-inspired cocktails. The authentic menu covers all four regions of Thailand, with vibrant dishes delivering the hallmark blend of sweet, sour, spicy and salty. Sharing is encouraged and the dishes are well-priced, so don’t hold back when ordering.

Name: Treinta y Tres
Address: Olivia Centre, Aleja Grunwaldzka 472c, Gdansk, 80-309, Poland
Description: The 33rd floor of the Olivia Centre skyscraper provides spectacular panoramic views for this buzzing restaurant where Spanish guitar music soundtracks your visit. The cooking has a similar tone, with a selection of classic tapas to begin – the Ibérico ham croquetas are terrific – before a choice of main dishes. If you’re dining with company, the 800g lobster rice for two is the most eye-catching option on the menu. A genuine warmth from the service team and a comprehensive, largely Spanish wine list complete the picture.

Name: Le Braci
Description: There's a clubby feel to this intimate Italian restaurant thanks to its zinc-topped bar, high ceiling and dark green colour scheme. The appealing Italian menu covers all regions, with dishes proving to be authentic and full of flavour – especially the impressively precise homemade pasta. A superb range of wines includes those from small Italian producers and lesser-seen regions. Charming service helps to create a welcoming atmosphere.

Name: Folga
Description: Located in the trendy Plac Nowy square in the city’s historic Jewish Quarter of Kazimierz, this busy and buoyant restaurant adopts a chic brasserie-style aesthetic with high-top tables and a terrace that’s ideal for the summertime. The menu showcases appealing variety, with the globally influenced dishes ranging from oysters to arancini and tempura to ceviche. Whatever you choose, there’s a unifying theme of sensible pricing and quality execution from the kitchen team.

Name: 1911 Restaurant
Description: Hidden behind an unassuming façade, you'll find this smart modern bistro with a team that’s eager to please and food that offers fabulous value for money. The concise menu makes sure the kitchen doesn’t overstretch but instead packs heaps of flavour into every unfussy dish, be it shrimp toast or fried skrei cod. Desserts are a highlight, with the kitchen’s creative streak coming through in the likes of milled cornflake ice cream.

Name: alewino
Description: Spread across various rooms, this starkly decorated bistro started life as a wine shop. There’s still a range of bottles for sale, along with a wine list that offers plenty of younger and lesser-known producers. The well-priced menu allows guests to order a few plates to share, be that classics like beef tartare or dishes that show off seasonal vegetables such as asparagus and morel mushrooms. Look out for the signpost by the gates when arriving, as the entrance is tucked away off the main street.

Name: Luneta & Lorneta Bistro Club
Description: The Pałac Ciekocinko Hotel, a large house dating back to the 1920s, is the home for this smart restaurant with a few plush details in its décor. Situated in the basement, there’s a pleasantly cosy feel to the dining room, which is accentuated by the cheery, welcoming service. A garden terrace is used to fine effect in the summer, while the cooking is admirably light on price and heavy on flavour. Confit duck leg with a fabulous silky jus is a prime example.

Name: kontakt
Description: Just outside of the hustle and bustle of the city centre, you'll find this trendy spot with a wine bar on its lower level and a rustic bistro upstairs. The cooking has a Mediterranean heart, with croquetas and cavatelli likely to appear on a great value menu that’s perfect for sharing. The wine list plays a starring role, providing an extensive choice that largely focuses on natural and bio-dynamic wines from lesser-known producers – and the team have an excellent knowledge of their selection.

Name: Ceviche Bar
Description: Bringing South American flavours to Warsaw, you’ll quickly find that this bright, airy restaurant is much more than a bar and serves far more than just ceviche. The famous Peruvian dish does feature – with sea bass, tuna and oyster among the varieties – but so do empanadas, grilled steaks and picarones. Argentinian Chef-Owner Martin Gimenez Castro imbues them all with freshness and vitality. In the evening, the music grows louder and the pisco sours start emerging from the bar at increasing speed.

Name: Gostilna na Gradu
Description: The Gostilna na Gradu (the “restaurant at the castle”) says it all. You’d be forgiven for thinking that this was a tourist address given its location in the inner courtyard of the city’s busiest, most iconic monument, and yet the dishes here are prepared using carefully chosen Slovenian ingredients and cooked to perfection. Our favourite dishes included beef tongue with onions, a superb dish that was a lot more elaborate than that simple description suggests. The tongue is lightly brined, then smoked and served thinly sliced with turnip mousse, toasted pumpkin seeds and wild-garlic oil, as well as stewed sweet-and-sour onions.

Name: LALU Bistro
Description: A glass of Pinot Noir from the Štajerska region (Slovenian Styria) makes the perfect introduction to a meal at this small modern, minimalist-style restaurant with a welcoming feel in the town centre. The friendly service is accompanied by cuisine influenced by Italy, with ingredients such as San Daniele ham on the menu alongside local specialities such as Savinjski želodec (a delicious local ham) served with olives and wild capers. Don’t miss the crème brûlée with passion fruit and coconut sorbet which adds an exotic touch to your meal.

Name: Jožef
Description: Housed in a modern hotel just outside the town centre, this restaurant boasts an attractive, bright dining room on the first floor that comes as a surprise given its fairly anonymous location. Although the menu is not extensive (and is even more restricted at lunchtime), it changes daily and showcases traditional local dishes reinterpreted with a modern twist. Make sure you try the žlikrofi (delicious potato-filled ravioli) served with a type of lamb stew – a local speciality for which the restaurant is a certified producer.

Name: Gostilnica Ruj
Address: Dol Pri Vogljah 16, Dol pri Vogljah, 6221, Slovenia
Description: Situated in the Karst region above Trieste, this restaurant occupies a small house surrounded by trees, with an entrance directly from its outdoor patio. The cuisine here is local and seasonal and is announced at your table by chef Peter Patajac, an engaging host who will happily share his delight at finding just the right ingredient from local farmers who pay close attention to the natural rhythms of nature. Chatting with him is a real pleasure, enhanced perhaps by a glass of a good Slovenian red wine such as the delicate yet ample Vlkovin 2015, with its elegant spicy aromas.

Name: Gostilna Rajh
Address: Soboška ulica 32, Bakovci, Murska Sobota, 9000, Slovenia
Description: This restaurant now run by the fourth generation of the family is a real culinary institution in this region, with many of its regular guests having eaten here since they were children. There’s a welcoming bar for socialising and an elegant dining room in which to enjoy classic regional fare such as cured hams, delicious hot beetroot with horseradish, superb Wiener Schnitzel with a fragrant side salad and excellent pumpkin oil, plus unmissable traditional desserts to finish. Offering good value for money, this is a restaurant to return to time and time again.

Name: Restavracija Majerca
Description: This small restaurant, which is part of an intimate boutique hotel near Lake Bohinj amid the valleys of the Julian Alps, boasts a contemporary-style dining room with relaxing views of the surrounding countryside. Here, the chef creates dishes inspired by typical mountain ingredients (local beef and veal, trout from Lake Bohinj, celeriac, potatoes etc) which are modern yet uncomplicated and fully focused on flavour. In the evening, guests can choose between a 3-, 4- or 5-course menu, while simpler options are available at lunchtime. 90% of the wines are Slovenian.

Name: Gostilna in vinoteka Faladur
Description: Situated in the centre of Vipava, an attractive little town with pre-Roman origins, this restaurant has the feel of a charming and welcoming inn, with the added attraction of an enchanting terrace for summer evenings. The restaurant is pretty and carefully decorated with interesting bottles of wine for sale displayed on the walls. The menu features regional recipes alongside more modern dishes, such as mackerel sashimi with mandarin and the baked pancetta with spicy chard (our favourite). The service is friendly and attentive (the selection of local wines is presented with real enthusiasm) and there’s an attractively priced menu at lunchtime.

Name: Kodila
Description: The ground floor of this restaurant is home to a café and an opulent delicatessen offering a huge selection of hams that are cured and seasoned on site – the theme continues on the first floor, where guests pass a display of hams on their way to the dining room. It soon becomes obvious that this bistro-style restaurant with a covered terrace is dedicated to local specialities such as seasoned hams, pork chops and delicious pork scratchings. The seasonal dishes include delicious brawn served with pumpkin oil and seeds, smoked prosciutto with fresh horseradish, and calf’s liver with polenta. Kodila is a real paradise for meat-lovers, with specialities that can be enjoyed without spending a fortune. The delicatessen is also worth a visit.

Name: Triangel
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Great view,Terrace
Description: Situated in a majestic mountain setting just a few kilometres from the elegant Kranjska Gora ski resort, Triangel is the perfect place to stay and to enjoy a pleasant dinner, with a delightful outdoor terrace that is a must in summer. The cuisine has something for everyone, with a menu offering a combination of modern and traditional dishes. Dishes not to missed include the ričet (a typical Slovenian barley soup with Carniolan sausage), the delicious veal loin with shallot sauce, and perfectly cooked steak. The tasting menus are a convenient option at lunchtime, while the wine list includes a selection of top-quality local and international labels.

Name: Mahorčič
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Wheelchair access
Description: An unmissable restaurant in a small village in the beautiful Karst region, with a classic, beautifully kept dining room with the intimate feel of a private lounge. The owners here are friendly and welcoming and keen to showcase the best of their region. With enthusiasm and expertise, skilful owner-chef Ksenija Krajšek Mahorčič adds a personal, technical touch to Slovenian ingredients resulting in dishes of the highest quality. Among the appetisers, a good example of his sustainable approach is the puffed wild garlic chip topped with a sea bass cream made from fish scraps. Also recommended is the local roast lamb served with cider from home-grown apples and a garlic potato mash. The same care and attention to detail is found on the wine list.

Name: 14Horses
Description: The unusually named 14 Horses is a well-run restaurant with a sleek, pared-back look and a relaxed vibe. Here, many of the dishes are brought to the table by the chef himself, who proudly shows off ingredients from his regenerative farm in Radiškis. There’s certainly value on the cards: you receive bread, four courses and a pre-dessert – with the flexibility to choose either three starters or two starters and a dessert. Bold, well-defined flavours are delivered in original combinations. The staff are happy to advise, but the ‘beef from nose-to-tail’ is a must.

Name: Gaspar's
Description: On the border of the Old and the New Town you’ll find Gaspar’s, a neighbourhood restaurant with a long history as an eatery – look out for the original Yiddish restaurant sign above the door (this was once the Jewish Quarter). Chef Gaspar Fernandes was born in Goa, India and is of Portuguese heritage, so his cuisine is an intriguing blend of the two countries. The menu is concise, driven by the produce available and subtle Indian spicing, and dishes are generous and beautifully presented. “My mum’s curry” is available in several varieties and the naan bread uses locally milled whole wheat flour, which adds a unique nuttiness.

Name: Nüman
Description: History oozes from the walls of this lovely building, which has housed everything from a butcher’s to this discreet little bistro. Set just outside the city centre, it has a charming, understated feel and the stunning photos on the walls will draw your eye. Modern, flavour-led dishes are cooked with care and flair and, pleasingly, won’t break the bank. You’ll find everything from duck dumplings with dried mushrooms to superb guinea fowl accompanied by some of the best chips around. The delicious homemade bread is a must and friendly service rounds out the whole experience.

Name: Le Travi
Description: This lovely little restaurant will quickly become one of your go-to spots for an enjoyable and great value night out. Mattia – a native of Genoa – has created a wonderfully authentic osteria split over two rooms, with a cramped, rustic style; ask for a seat at the counter to watch the magic happen. This is ‘nonna’-style cooking with a pure Italian heart, nothing too fancy, just straightforward dishes that burst with flavour. The menu of 8 or so dishes is written on the walls; this could include a wonderful ox tongue with tonnata sauce or a daily made pasta such as tagliatelle with a rich ragu.

Name: Xin Wen Ji (Yuexiu)
Address: 1-3F, Sino Trade Centre, 67 Panfu Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Terrace
Description: The room is divided into zones with different ambiances – satin tablecloths signal a chic, formal vibe, while distressed wooden tables feel hip and casual. The culinary highlight is undoubtedly the piping hot congee claypot loaded with fresh seafood, from sand shrimps to mud crab. You can also pick your own fish from the tank and ask servers the best way to have it cooked. Cantonese stir-fries and sizzling claypot dishes exude exceptional wok hei.

Name: Jia Yuan
Address: 7 Xingrenli, Guangxiao Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: This restaurant with wood-rich finishes primarily serves dishes made with soybean products or mushrooms – no dairy, eggs, garlic or onion are used. Sweet and sour monkey head mushrooms and vegan meat with pickled cabbage are both tangy creations with layers of textures. The house-made mugwort-scented dumplings and plant-based yoghurt are also popular. Reservations recommended on the 1st and 15th day of every lunar month, when Buddhists go meat-free.

Name: Mamak
Address: Shop 082C, East 1 Street, B1F, Fashion Tianhe Plaza, 299 Tianhe Road, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Named after hawker stalls in Malaysia, this small and cheerful spot in a big shopping mall is boldly decorated with bright yellow hues and Malaysian flags everywhere. Naturally, the menu is loaded with the country’s national dishes, such as laksa (seafood noodle soup) and nasi lemak (coconut rice) served with juicy fried chicken and house-made sambal. For drinks, try teh C special (three-layer milk tea) or teh tarik (hand-pulled tea).

Name: Liang Jie Nanning Pumiao Shengzha Mifen
Address: 242 Yinghua Street, Xiaogang Bay, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: This friendly neighbourhood shop specialises in sourdough rice noodles. While preserving her hometown culinary tradition, the owner also dials down the sourness to cater to local tastes. Noodles are made to order – fermented rice batter is squeezed into boiling water and then drenched in soup, or tossed with pickled string beans, ground pork and deep-fried tofu. You can also opt for the beef brisket version. Prepare to wait after placing orders.

Name: Wen Ji Yixinji
Address: 10 Xuanyuanqiao, 76 Baohua Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: This joint expanded in 2020, adding a dining room across from the original shop. Its signature Yixin chicken remains the key draw – birds from Qingyuan weighing about 1.8 kg are slow-cooked in a white marinade with herbs and dried scallops, boasting juicy, silky flesh and glistening, springy skin. Also try its osmanthus roll, an ancient very rare recipe, consisting of fatty pork and salted egg yolk in a duck intestine casing, sliced and doused in honey glaze.

Name: Ease (Yuexiu)
Address: 112A, 1F, Newspaper Printing Service Building, 289 Art Park, 289 Guangzhou Middle Avenue, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: Nestled in a printing plant-turned-cultural park, the two-storey restaurant boasts an airy, high-ceilinged dining room. Faux-industrial elements work well with wood and bamboo accents for a relaxed ambience. The menu features simple dishes with Sichuanese touches, such as the must-try poached fish with peppercorns on the vine – layered flavours contrast nicely with the velvety fish. Friendly service and sensible prices are also reasons to visit.

Name: Xiguan Zhuyuan (Lizhiwan)
Address: C4, Phase 2, Lizhiwan Scenic Area, Huangsha Avenue, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Not only is this a noodle shop – nestled in a picturesque park – but it’s also a factory that makes noodles for various restaurants in Guangzhou and Hong Kong. These famous strands made with duck eggs are dried on bamboo skimmers outside the shop. Dried plaice is toasted on charcoal before being added to the flavourful broth along with pork backbones and dried shrimp. Customers who wish to enjoy the same taste at home can buy their pre-packed noodles.

Name: Zijin Shi Fang
Address: 39-1 Zishan Street, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Though Zijin occupies two adjoining ground-floor units, there is barely an empty seat throughout the day. For over 10 years, locals have been fans of the impeccable barbecue meats, which are displayed in all their glory at the front of the shop. The signature goose braised in premium soy boasts velvety meat and deep flavours. Double-boiled soups, stir-fries and claypot dishes are also popular. Come early, as certain items tend to run out.

Name: Hui Xing Yuan
Address: 177 Xiaobei Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: This three-storey building is the brand's first outlet, dating back to 1981. Known for traditional Cantonese food at bargain prices, the restaurant prides itself on meticulous cooking techniques and attention to detail. Their speciality of steamed chicken uses only free-range birds from Qingyuan for their firm, silky flesh and fine, springy skin. The goose intestines blanched in soy sauce are also impeccably made.

Name: Dayang (Wenming Road)
Address: 160-1 Wenming Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Among locals, its name is synonymous with double-boiled soups, which dominate the menu here. Apart from the top-selling silkie chicken soup in whole coconut, other popular selections, such as free-range chicken soup with goji berries and yam as well as quail soup are trickier to order as they change every few hours. That means you'll never quite know what exactly is available in advance. Adventurous eaters may also try the turtle jelly with milk and honey.

Name: Lao Xiguan Laifen (Wenming Road)
Address: 216 Wenming Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: As its name suggests, Laifen noodle soup is the key item on offer in this rustic shop – you can have it alongside ingredients, such as barbecue pork, beef balls or octopus. The old-time dish ‘water caltrop’, which is rice noodles shaped like bite-size buffalo nuts topped with shredded omelette, preserved cabbage and barbecue pork, is hard to find elsewhere. Also try homemade preserved radish.

Name: Chuang Fa
Address: 512-2 Guangfu North Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Terrace
Description: Since opening in the 1990s, this has been a popular place among locals who can’t seem to get enough of the kitchen's Cantonese home-style cooking, especially the double-boiled tonic soups. The signature “real-taste” chicken is free-range from Shunyi and is prized for its firm, flavoursome meat and silky, gelatinous skin. Large fried pork intestines with basil, and live seafood cooked-to-order are also excellent. Reservations recommended.

Name: Sa Er Ta Dongxiang Shou Zhua
Address: 103 Baohan Zhijie, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Valet parking
Description: Tucked in an alley filled to the brim with halal restaurants, this two-storey establishment has a dining room on the ground floor and some private rooms upstairs. Lamb is big on the menu, such as the juicy boiled premium version, which is chopped into chunky pieces with skin on and bone in. Pair it with garlic for extra pungency. Heyan flat noodles and Dongxiang stir-fried chicken are also worth ordering. For drinks, the eight-treasure tea is a must.

Name: Zhu Zai Ji Shi Fu (Jiangnan Avenue)
Address: 429 Jiangnan Avenue South, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: A hawker-stall-turned-restaurant now with two branches – this casual, bustling three-storey joint is prized for its authentic Cantonese food. The juicy, flavoursome roast goose has been a big hit for the past 20 years. Other specialities include salted pork trotters, Zhu Ji steamed chicken, and blackened barbecued pork. Pastured pork soup with mung bean-stuffed lotus root tastes delicious and delivers interesting textures.

Name: Xing Fu Yi Zhan (Yulei Third Street)
Address: 8 Yulei Third Street, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: Furnished like a vintage staging post, this restaurant whisks you back in time. Feel free to join the servers and dress up in period costume for a selfie. The Sichuanese head chef feeds hungry patrons with Chongqing-style cooking characterised by rich, intense flavours. Stir-fried dried pork with smoked bamboo shoot packs serious wok hei and a hint of smokiness. On the shelves, local liquors are on display, including some brewed in-house.

Name: Stay Here
Address: Shop 2, 23 Xigang Road, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: This tiny gem has changed hands, but the kitchen is still run by Chaoshan natives. The small menu stars all the greatest hits of Chaoshan cuisine, with raw marinated mud crab that packs tons of oomph standing out in particular. Diners need to book via a texting app and pre-order their food, which does streamline the process immensely. To round out your meal, try the ‘ginger potato’ and split mung bean sweet soup.

Name: Ze 8 (Haizhu)
Address: 174 Binjiang West Road, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: The dimly lit space is dotted with red lanterns and bamboo screens; the sizzling sounds and intoxicating smells from the semi-open kitchen prime diners for a feast that engages all senses. The menu features around 30 dishes served in claypots, complemented by an array of home-made sauces – try the rice paddy eel variety with firm, flavoursome meat. The double-boiled soups and home-made ginger juice milk curd ice cream are also worth trying.

Name: Enning Liu Fu Ji (Donghua East Road)
Address: 547 Donghua East Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: The founder started a shop on Enning Street in the 1940s and invented a unique way to make noodles. Fast forward to present day and his successors still honour his heritage by making bouncy noodles just like the old days – with duck eggs and flour only. The must-try blanched noodles tossed in lard is simple but addictive. The shrimp wontons are big and bursting with seafood flavours. Don’t miss their deep-fried wontons, available on weekends only.

Name: Hai Xian Jie Cai Guan
Address: 152-2 Haizhu South Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Nestled in an old neighbourhood, this shop has kept regulars coming back for almost three decades with their no-frills, tasty food at frugal prices. Come early for their double-boiled soups which tend to run out early. Fish head soup particularly entices with succulent flesh and a hint of Chinese herbs; brace yourself for the heady aromas when you lift the paper lid. Steamed chicken, roast goose and steamed pork patties are also popular choices.

Name: Xiguan Zhuyuan (Shiba Fu)
Address: 107 Shiba Fu South Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: It lacks the views of its Lizhiwan counterpart, but the food here tastes just as good. Duck egg noodles are kneaded with a traditional bamboo pole for a springy texture, before being blanched and tossed in shrimp roe, or in a broth made with dried plaice, pork bones and dried shrimp. Apart from the classic shrimp wonton, there is also the crab roe variety. Don’t miss the beef offal soup, fried savoury dough, beef brisket and pork intestines.

Name: FT · Bak Kut Teh
Address: Wonderful Life Mansion, 36-48 Wenming Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: You can’t miss the long line at the door, but that doesn’t stop avid chowhounds from coming here. The signature bak kut teh is simmered for three hours with pork ribs, garlic, white peppercorns and herbs until the meat falls off the bones. Char-grilled skate in sambal, seafood laksa and grilled durian also stand out. Reservations are not accepted. Join the queue on the mobile app ahead of time; or walk in and expect to wait for up to three hours.

Name: Hai Men Yu Zi Dian (Yanling Road)
Address: 1-2F, Jinyan Mansion, 120 Yanling Road, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Terrace
Description: Next to a glass-walled kitchen where a veritable army of chefs may be seen at work, this high-ceilinged bi-level dining room was remodelled to have entrances on both ends, thereby making it feel even more comfortable than before. It’s essentially an up-market hawker stall experience in an air-conditioned space. Diners pick their food at the entrance, where fresh seafood delivered daily from Swatow is laid out neatly on ice. First-timers may also refer to the menu for recommendations.

Name: Wei Shi Jia
Address: 598 Jiefang North Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Shi shi chicken – steamed chicken served with fermented clam dip – ranks among the top 10 chicken dishes in Guangzhou, but it’s hard to come by these days. The chef, who once worked in a prestigious hotel, uses Qingyuan birds for this dish because of their bouncy skin and silky flesh. Besides the clam dip, it comes with soy sauce and ginger scallion dip. Also try the rice noodles made from scratch in-house and dressed in a secret soy blend.

Name: Hui Cheng (Dunhe Road)
Address: H 101, Yeo’s Park, Dunhe Road, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: A far cry from its humble beginnings as a street stall, this elegant restaurant in a cultural park prides itself on the freshest catch from Chaoshan, the owner's home area. There is no printed menu; diners choose from the ingredients on full display. Start with the signature pork trotter in a spiced soy-based marinade for its gelatinous skin and exceptional depth. Sour plums cut through the oily richness of the steamed fourfinger threadfin.

Name: Tong Ji
Address: 3 Fuguangli, Changshou East Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Tucked away in an alley, this two-storey, no-frills joint has been in business for over 30 years. You're not here for the ambience, but for the steamed chicken – only free-range pullets before they lay their first egg are used because of their springy skin, oily richness, silky flesh and robust flavour. Boiled chicken intestines, stir-fried ribbon rice noodles and creamy congee are also sound reasons to visit.

Name: Yao Ji
Address: 15 Long Yuan Road, Panyu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: Yao Ji has been a household name in Panyu District for over 40 years. On the menu, classic Cantonese flavours work their magic in painstaking recipes that are a rarity these days. The sweet, steamed lotus root puree is sticky and chewy and well complemented by briny dried shrimps and aromatic scallion. Oyster sauce chicken is nicely browned and boasts an inimitable umami flavour thanks to scallion and ginger.

Name: Temple Street
Address: 10 Dongdi Second Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Since opening in 2018, this tiny shop has been jam-packed with diners, so expect to share a table with strangers at peak hours. It’s named after Temple Street in the owner’s native Hong Kong and focuses on 20+ types of clay pot rice in dai pai dong style, alongside three kinds of double-boiled soups. Try their claypot rice topped with assorted traditional preserved meats, beef loin with perilla leaves or satay beef with onion.

Name: Hunan Cuisine
Address: 2842-39 East Xingang Road, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: This design-forward restaurant is located within an industrial park of remodelled factory buildings. Aptly, the décor exudes an industrial chic that complements the origami art hung from the ceiling. Trained as a designer, the owner took care of the décor and furnishings, whereas the Hunanese chef recreates classics from his home province. Dongting fish head, wotou cornbread and sweet fried dumplings are cooked with acumen and dexterity.

Name: Lingnan Haiyanlou (Binjiang East Road)
Address: 2-3F, Jiangpan Huating, 1040 Binjiang East Road, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: The two chefs in this kitchen once worked at a prestigious hotel and their skills are unquestionable – which is why it’s so hard to get a table here. Try their ‘premium trio’ which was usually saved for state banquets only – rich and buttery foie gras, plum-scented squab with crispy skin, as well as springy goose webs and wings in white marinade. Barbecued meat is grilled daily in limited servings. Arrive early to nab a seat or risk disappointment.

Name: Huacheng Yuan (Jinsui Road)
Address: 5F, Grand Mercure, 62 Jinsui Road, Zhujiang New Town, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Wheelchair access
Description: Since 2018, Huacheng Yuan has been serving hotel guests and other gourmands with home-style Cantonese fare. The brightly lit space boasts a tasteful décor and there are a number of private rooms of varying sizes. Along with signature dishes such as double-steamed chicken, lotus root starch pancakes, and soy-marinated chitterlings, the milky white, rich and flavoursome slow-cooked pork tripe soup is a must-try. Reservations are recommended.

Name: Xiang Qun (Longjin East Road)
Address: 853-857 Longjin East Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Standing the test of time since 1988, this operation started out as an ‘ice parlour’ serving cold drinks and light snacks. Now firmly in the 21C, it has morphed into a chain famous for home-style cooking and this branch pays tribute to the charm of historic Guangzhou. Signatures include steamed Qingyuan chicken and soy-marinated goose. The stir-fried eel fillet with French beans seduces with aromas of garlic and shallot as the naturally sweet veggies work wonders with the firm eel flesh.

Name: Rong Yi Fa Niu Za Dian (Shishu Road)
Address: 56 Shishu Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: For over 40 years, the owner has been insisting on shopping for fresh beef offal daily, painstakingly preparing and braising it in a rich stock made from scratch with beef and lamb bones. His beef bone marrow boasts a creamy texture and is a perfect match with the house-made radish pickles. Beef tripe tip is another premium cut, available only after 11am. As well as beef offal, also try wonton noodle soup, braised beef brisket and tendon.

Name: Soodle
Address: Shop 309, 3F, Adjoining Building, Kingold Century, 62 Jinsui Road, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Commanding spectacular city views, the sun-drenched, plant-filled space caters to a well-heeled business clientele. The Western-centric menu focuses on vegetables and mushrooms, as opposed to typical Chinese vegetarian cuisine based on soy faux meats. The bamboo fungus with pickled radish, chilli and rattan pepper has a wonderfully crisp texture and tingling tanginess. The deep-fried Yunnan eggplant with vegan demi-glace is also unmissable.

Name: Xin Tai Le (Yuexiu)
Address: 1-2F, Sino Trade Centre, 65 Panfu Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Valet parking,Wheelchair access
Description: Since 1989, this household name for its signature swamp eel rice has attracted a loyal fan base. Of all the branches, this two-storey one in the old part of town is the flagship. Apart from its famous rice dish topped with crisp, flavourful eel that imparts a robust wok-qi, the kitchen also recommends fatty roast char siu, all sorts of stir-fries and seafood dishes. Private rooms of varying sizes are available on the second floor.

Name: Ya Yuan
Address: 14 Chaotian Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: The three-storey room is furnished with orange tables and leather chairs that evoke 1980s nostalgia. For over three decades, Ya Yuan has been feeding hungry locals with classic home-style dishes such as slow-boiled soups and claypot rice. With its velvety flesh and gelatinous skin, the poached Qingyuan chicken dressed in scallion oil is addictively aromatic. Even the post-meal complimentary mung bean or red bean sweet soups are made with care.

Name: Da Ge Fan (Tangxiayong West Road)
Address: 1F, Tian Hui Building, 69 Tangxiayong West Road, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: The chain operates branches in Hunan and Guangdong, but everything started in this flagship venue with a landscaped garden and a running stream. Its namesake signature dish is rice cooked in a pigeon and pork bone broth, boasting a crispy golden crust on the bottom and topped with steamed pigeon or a combo of pigeon meat and gizzards. Besides deep-fried or salt-baked fowl, the sautéed squid with cucumber is also a must.

Name: Dai Yong Town
Address: 59 Tianhe East Road, Tianhe, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Valet parking
Description: A wall map and backlit illustrations lend the rustic interior an artistic flair. The owner and the staff, who all hail from the Chaoshan area, pay homage to the kaleidoscopic food culture of this region using mainly ingredients and seafood from their homelands. ‘Floating’ on dry ice fog, marinated raw crab boasts gelatinous roe loaded with umami and winey aromas. It even comes with hot ginger tea to balance the crab’s ‘coldness’.

Name: Hua Ge Si Chu
Address: 443 Guangfu North Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: The owner was behind a legendary, now-shuttered restaurant and opened this much smaller spot, keeping some of the menu’s most popular items. The chef has decades of experience and his Hakkanese cooking is a pure delight. The signature salt-baked chicken uses birds from Qingyuan, dry-rubbed in a droolworthy secret seasoning blend. House-made pickles, and winter special, white radish pork balls, are also recommended.

Name: Mian Ji (Yuexiu)
Address: 224 Dezheng Middle Road, Yuexiu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Since 1985, this tiny gem has been specialising in double-boiled soups. The menu boasts some 20 health tonics that are grouped by medicinal properties – some nourish the lungs; others boost energy levels. Those slow-cooked in whole coconuts are especially loved by customers, like the coconut chicken soup that imparts sweet aromas. Steamed rice with pork patty and pickled mustard greens entices with briny umami and juicy, silky pork.

Name: Jian Ji (Liwan)
Address: 299-303 Changshou East Road, Liwan, Guangzhou, China Mainland
Description: Shops that sell homemade E-fu noodles can be hard to come by. For over 50 years, this one has attracted a faithful following with not only E-fu, but also freshly made raw and cooked egg noodles. The ladies working in the open kitchen show off their swift moves as these particular strands are notorious for their finicky cooking process. The flavourful broth made with dace, pork bones, shrimp roe and dried shrimp matches the noodles perfectly.

Name: Nan Yuan
Address: 142 Qianjin Road, Haizhu, Guangzhou, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Great view,Wheelchair access
Description: This long-standing institution boasts a classical landscaped garden complete with pavilions, bridges and water features. It makes the perfect backdrop for a dim sum lunch. The food is mostly Cantonese, with the odd dish from other provinces. Try their banded grouper two ways – steamed fillet rolls are silky and juicy; deep-fried bones are spiced up with peppered salt. Private rooms are worth splurging on for special occasions.

Friendly service, sensible prices and plenty of buzz in the air – this is the kind of neighbourhood spot we’d all love to have at the end of our street. It’s located in the north of the city, inside a substantial three-storey building dating back to the 19th Century. The unfussy dishes are a great example of Nordic bistronomy: rustic, satisfying and filled with bold, balanced flavours – whether that be fresh herbs adding vibrancy to a burbot dish, or tart lingonberries cutting through the sweetness of meringue.

Name: Enomania
Description: With a name that means 'Wine Mania' it's no surprise that this Italian restaurant attracts a crowd of dedicated oenophiles. The wine cellar comes with a table for tasting and there’s an excellent list of several hundred bins, mostly from Burgundy and Owner Damiano Alberti's native Piedmont. In his role as Sommelier, Damiano provides wine service that is helpful, passionate and generous. The place itself is simple and trattoria-like, serving straightforward and satisfying dishes like 'spaghetti alla chitarra con gamberoni' from a weekly-changing menu.

Name: The Little Pickle
Description: It’s not often that restaurants in Oslo are influenced by British cuisine, but that’s exactly what you’ll find at this minimally decorated neighbourhood bistro. Operations such as London's St. John are the inspiration for the kitchen, with dishes like beef brisket pie and mash providing suitably gutsy flavours and hearty generosity. They even serve a traditional roast dinner on Sundays! French influences come into play as well, as with the madeleines for dessert. Friendly service creates a lovely, welcoming atmosphere.

Name: Bar Agrikultur
Description: A warmly run, intimate and cosy wine bar that is a perfect fit for Södermalm. The freshly prepared and delicious small plates are designed for sharing and showcase classic Swedish flavours. The three stainless steel tanks contain home-distilled gin – flavours are changed regularly using various herbs, oils or fruits.

Name: Lilla Ego
Description: With its pared-back feel, rustic exposed brickwork and buzzy vibe, this is just the place for a lively night out. It remains one of the hottest tickets in town, so try for a counter seat overlooking the kitchen if you haven’t booked. The concise menu includes modernised Swedish classics that are robust, well-composed and certainly deliver on flavour. Service is accommodating, warm and efficient.

Name: no.2
Address: Nicolai Eigtveds Gade 32, Copenhagen, 1402 K, Denmark
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Located in the Christianshavn dockside development is this minimally decorated, no-frills sister restaurant to a|o|c. This approach extends to the low-key service and the laid-back ambiance, while the fresh, flavoursome dishes focus on Danish produce, incorporate some impressive culinary techniques and offer great depth of flavour. The fish of the day is a prime example, showcasing a quality prime ingredient that’s been expertly seasoned and accompanied by a well-judged garnish of caramelised cauliflower purée and foamy mussel sauce.

Name: Anarki
Description: An unassuming and proudly run neighbourhood bistro, set just over the water in Frederiksberg. The regularly changing menu draws its inspiration from the season, the best quality ingredients available and the mood of the chef – and the bold, rustic dishes are bursting with flavour, with some great wines to match.

Name: Pluto
Description: Concrete pillars and an intentionally ‘unfinished’ feel bring a distinctive vibe at this ever-popular restaurant. The huge numbers they serve whilst maintaining quality and affordability is a testament to both the kitchen and service teams. Sit at wooden tables, at the long metal bar or at communal marble-topped tables to enjoy the extensive selection of unfussy sharing plates, including stand-out pasta dishes and their signature savoury waffles. A selection of natural wines completes the picture.

Name: Silberbauers Bistro
Description: Eponymous Danish chef Mathias has taken over the spot previously occupied by Manfreds to create a lively, friendly eatery with a focus on fish and shellfish. The day’s catch gives rise to the concise menu, and the emphasis on top quality produce ensures that the simple, well-priced dishes are full of flavour.

Name: Namu
Description: Restaurateur and Swedish MasterChef winner Jennie Walldén is behind this fun, energetic restaurant that blends Nordic ingredients with Jennie's South Korean heritage. Offering great value for money, the cooking is colourful, zingy and generous in both size and flavour; the signature flank steak served with an array of accompaniments is a highlight. Dishes are designed for sharing, with tasting menus available if you're feeling indecisive. Head next door to their Gaji cocktail bar to keep the party going.

Name: Familjen
Description: This lively, friendly eatery is divided into three parts: a bar with bench seating and an open kitchen; a bright red room with a characterful cellar and a glass wine cave; and a superb wrap-around terrace. The good value cooking is rich and hearty, with a touch of originality here and there. A relaxed atmosphere and an appealing wine, beer and cocktail list add to the experience.

Name: Mêlée
Description: You will quickly feel at home in this bustling neighbourhood bistro with a friendly, lively atmosphere. The uncomplicated spirit of the restaurant is reflected in modern, country-style cooking, generous portions and bold flavours. There is a French basis to the concise monthly menus, with some Danish influences. The excellent wine list offers an impressive array of vintages.

Name: juju
Description: On the edge of the city centre, near Rosenborg Castle, sits this casual Korean restaurant. A wide selection of small plates like Korean fried chicken and mandoo of pork are ideal for sharing in the simple, bistro-like dining room. Dishes are prepared with knowledge and skill, offering wonderfully intense flavours at a reasonable price tag. Friendly service adds to the appeal.

Name: Smalhans
Description: A sweet neighbourhood café with friendly staff and an urban feel. Coffee and homemade cakes are served in the morning, with a short selection of dishes including soup and a burger on offer between 12pm and 4pm. In the evenings, they serve a set menu of rustic Norwegian dishes.

Name: Marv & Ben
Description: The young owners bring plenty of enthusiasm to this little restaurant, where dining is split over two dimly lit floors. Organic produce features in seasonal cooking which displays purity and depth of flavour. They produce 6 dishes each evening, which are priced individually or as 4 or 6 courses.

Name: Mathias Dahlgren-Matbaren
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: Set within the Grand Hotel Matbaren, this trendy, modern bistro offers well-priced dishes with a Scandinavian heart; three are about right for one person, or order more and share. Grab a seat at the zinc-topped bar counter for a better view of the open kitchen; the keen service team add to the atmosphere.

Name: Pondus
Description: Set by the narrow city centre canal, the little sister to Substans is a small, rustic bistro with a friendly vibe and a stripped-back style. Bright, colourful dishes are formed around organic Danish produce and represent great value. Wines are either natural or organic.

Name: Selma
Description: A sweet, homely place, named after the chef-owner’s daughter and run by a friendly young team. Lunchtime smørrebrød are modern in style yet still respect tradition; dinner dispenses with the homemade rye and sourdough bases to create dishes ideal for sharing. Be careful not to miss any dessert specials, which are not always listed on the menu. To drink, there's an excellent selection of craft beers, alongside snaps and aquavit made in-house.

Name: FAGN-Bistro
Description: This simple bistro is set on the floor above FAGN restaurant and uses the same top quality local produce as its Michelin-Starred sibling. The Norwegian dishes are rustic with punchy flavours; choose between an à la carte or tasting menus of 3 and 5 courses. The waiting staff and chefs add to the relaxed buzz.

Name: anx
Description: This nicely styled, well-run annexe to Frederikshøj serves sophisticated yet well-priced smørrebrød, which are classic in their ingredients and modern in their presentation. Contemporary art punctuates the walls and service is charming and efficient.

Name: Ruths
Description: The open kitchen takes centre stage at this buzzy all-day café/bakery/deli, which has been wholeheartedly embraced by the locals. Lunchtime snacks and salads make room for generously sized, boldly flavoured Mediterranean dishes at dinner. Most of the wines on the concise list are available on-tap.

Name: Bjørnekælderen
Description: The ‘Bear’s Basement’ has been a restaurant for over 130 years, and references to the furry creatures are legion in this cosy, characterful eatery. Smørrebrød are served at lunch, with more substantial dishes in the evening, and the carefully crafted plates have flavour, imagination and a modern touch.

Name: Frances
Description: One of three restaurants housed in the former US Embassy building, this ground-floor spot occupies a space previously used for the rather less exciting purpose of issuing visas. It’s now been transformed into a café, wine bar and restaurant, serving a selection of Middle Eastern and Mediterranean-inspired sharing plates. The generous dishes catch the eye with their vibrant appearance, then satisfy the palate with their fabulous flavours; confit cauliflower with the colourful trio of tomato coulis, cashew cream and coriander oil is a prime example.

Name: Allegrine
Description: Set off the busy Sveavägen thoroughfare, this brasserie provides a hidden oasis. Sit on the attractive front terrace or in the chic dining room, where seats at the kitchen counter are in demand. Variously sized dishes are richly flavoured, with a French base, Scandinavian influences and subtle contrasts.

Name: Gabrielle
Description: Sibling to Norrlyst and Theo in the city, this French-style bistro is run by seasoned local restaurateurs and delivers traditional Gallic fare with an appealing price tag. The kitchen's skilled classical technique is highlighted across the menu, which features the likes of Gillardeau oysters with mignonette sauce and their speciality beef tartare – which is of undeniable quality. Add in linen-laid tables, simple wooden chairs and an all-French wine list and you could easily forget that you're in Copenhagen.

Name: plein
Description: A simple, homely feel and the generosity of the kitchen have helped to turn this former butcher's shop into a fabulous neighbourhood bistro. A welcome broth and bread provide a great precursor to the 4 course set menu, which can be expanded with two extra dishes. The cooking is flavoursome and demonstrates refined, well thought through composition from the chefs; earthy celeriac, for example, is elevated by the sweetness of pear jelly, balanced by the saltiness of roe-infused beurre blanc and finished off with fragrant dill oil.

Name: Mutantur
Description: This restaurant's semi-industrial styling means concrete floors, brick-faced walls and exposed ducting, accompanied by an open kitchen and counter dining. The menu of good value cooking offers snacks and small plates with a Nordic style and some Asian influences; they recommend between 3 and 5 per person. An extensive wine list completes the picture.

Name: Paesàno
Description: Down a charming cobbled street in the trendy Nørrebro neighbourhood, where you will find a number of artisan food producers, lies this thoroughly fun restaurant run by a Neapolitan Chef. The short Italian menu is supplemented by blackboard specials and might include ‘cucina povera’ style dishes like 'pasta e piselli' and ‘soffrito napoletano’ – a ragu made using 'the best parts of the pig'. Whatever it is you choose, you can bet it will be colourful, packed with flavour and excellent value.

Name: Babette
Description: Whether you are popping in for a glass of wine and a pizza or choosing a meal from the daily changing menu of small plates, this buzzy neighbourhood bistro is a great place at a great price. Dishes might be simple to look at but have bags of rustic flavour; sit at the counter to be served by the chef.

Name: Bistro Lupa
Description: Not far from Nordhavnen lies this vegan bistro that comes with simple décor and a lively atmosphere. Sustainability is a big theme, with a focus on local and seasonal produce, some of it foraged or from their own mushroom farm. These ingredients are fashioned into good value dishes with well-balanced flavours, served by a charming and knowledgeable team. The homemade sparkling kombucha is highly recommended.

Name: Norrlyst
Description: An intimate basement bistro with a relaxing, neighbourhood feel. Lunch sees some delicious smørrebrød on offer, while dinner involves a set 4 course menu; seasonality is all-important so expect fresh, top quality local ingredients, accompanied by some interesting beers and an amazing array of schnapps.

Name: Møntergade
Description: The charming team are a big part of the draw at this lively upmarket brasserie that offers generous, classic dishes at a reasonable price. While the chalkboard displays daily specials, there is always a place for a multitude of herring on the menu – curried, pickled, marinated or fried, the choice is yours. Other dishes like a perfectly crisped chicken tartlet are equally appealing. There’s a cosy vibe to the place and a small drinks counter where you can chat away with the waiters.

Name: Nolla
Description: Nolla means ‘Zero’ and this lively neighbourhood restaurant has a zero-waste ethos running throughout it, from using up scraps in their own composter to the uniforms made being from discarded bed linen. Small producers who share the Nolla philosophy provide ingredients for the hearty cooking, which is best enjoyed from the generous ‘Chef’s Choice’ menu. The dishes pack a punch flavour-wise, exemplified by a wonderfully intense, glossy meat reduction sauce to accompany tender roasted deer.

Name: Bobe
Description: In a cobbled city centre square stands this attractive townhouse that's now in the hands of Danish celebrity chef, Bo Bech. His simply decorated contemporary bistro offers reasonable pricing and plenty of flexibility on an extensive à la carte menu. There's strong cooking and great produce across the board, but those with a sweet tooth should keep their eye out for the cheesecake with smoked maple syrup. A wine bar in the basement provides ample opportunity to extend your visit.

Name: Triton
Description: Charming in its lack of pretension, this bohemian neighbourhood restaurant has a homely feel. It’s simply furnished and the pared-back cooking has an unfussiness to match. Dishes show technical skill and provide some well-judged flavours using great Swedish ingredients. In an expensive city, the set menu presents good value for cooking of this quality.

Name: JH Matbar
Description: You will find this bistro at the southern tip of Sweden, in the centre of a small town with picturesque streets that provided the setting for the Wallander detective TV series. The good value menu offers a wide choice of dishes, with vegetarians and vegans well catered for. Scandinavian produce powers many of the modern dishes, which are prepared and presented with real care.

Name: Bona Fide
Description: Clean, natural and uncomplicated cooking is the big draw at this simple little restaurant. Welcoming, helpful service and a good atmosphere add to the appeal too, enlivening the modest surroundings. The chefs have a great understanding of their seasonal ingredients and treat them with care. Flavours are subtle but are put together in well-thought-out combinations, resulting in quality dishes at a reasonable price.

Name: Mantel ja Korsten
Description: This picture-postcard clapboard house's name means ‘mantel and chimney’ – and, fittingly, a green-tiled fireplace and mantel take centre stage in a room furnished with bright, bold designs. Flavoursome dishes take on an eclectic mix of styles, from truffle risotto arancini with smoked duck and butternut squash for starters to a blend of coconut, cherry, white chocolate and almond to finish. The well-chosen wines have an organic and biodynamic bias, and service is endearing.

Name: Härg
Description: This busy, buzzy, all-day brasserie with stone walls, exposed ducting and striking copper chandeliers provides the perfect pick-me-up, particularly in the colder months, while the courtyard is a popular spot come summer. Whatever the weather, you’ll always receive a warm welcome from the charming team. Seasonal modern dishes keep the focus on the local area, with the chargrill taking centre stage; the ‘Dirty Steak’ – a ribeye – is cooked directly on the charcoal. Portions are large, but if you do make it to dessert, the ‘Disentangled Napoleon’ is a must.

Name: NOA
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: You can take in delightful views over both the city and the sea from this stylish waterside restaurant. The cosy room is furnished with natural materials and the full-length windows flood it with light. Seasonal modern menus are inspired by the owner’s worldwide travels and provide plenty of choice.

Name: Fellin
Description: This brightly decorated café-cum-bistro sits within a red brick building on the edge of the Old Town and has something of a bohemian air, courtesy of a tiled bar, an eclectic mix of artwork and a laid-back vibe. Carefully prepared European dishes have a homely style and burst with freshness and flavour; you can have anything from coffee and cake or a lamb sandwich to a full meal, with the house pasta coming highly recommended. It’s a place that’s loved by guests both young and old.

Name: Tuljak
Description: Set in an elevated spot, with distant views of the Gulf of Finland, this airy restaurant with floor-to-ceiling windows is a wonderful example of modernist architecture. Dishes have a Baltic heart, with a few Asian and Mediterranean touches; expect plenty of originality and some intriguing flavours.

Name: Lore Bistroo
Description: The sister of ‘Lee’ is a characterful modern bistro which sits in a cavernous warehouse overlooking the harbour at Port Noblessner. Steel girders, hoists and concrete pillars provide the backdrop, while an open kitchen adds to the buzz. Assured, modern dishes are inspired by the owners’ travels, ensuring you'll always find something that appeals. Go for the 'Lore Experience' menu if you fancy sharing dishes served 'family-style' – and if you see crêpes Suzette on the menu, be sure to give them a try!

Name: Capim Santo
Address: Av. Brig. Faria Lima, 2705, São Paulo, 01451-000, Brazil
Description: This restaurant is a reference for contemporary Brazilian cuisine. Located in the heart of São Paulo, it offers a tranquil and relaxing oasis for those keen to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. It occupies the Solar Fabio Prado (formerly the Museu da Casa Brasileira), and features an extensive outdoor space teeming with vegetation, as well as a pleasant internal dining room. Here, renowned chef Morena Leite, who grew up in the kitchens of his family’s restaurant in Trancoso, conjures up comfort food that showcases typical Brazilian ingredients, allied with techniques acquired elsewhere. One of the classic dishes on the menu is the tapioca ravioli filled with Canastra cheese and a delicious herb sauce that will linger long in the memory.

Name: Mocotó Vila Leopoldina
Description: A very safe bet, where the experience is such that you will always enjoy a good meal, whether you order the famous “dadinhos de tapioca”, the delicious “torresminhos”, the traditional “rabada” or less conventional but equally superb options, such as the “beijupira ceviche”. The cuisine follows the same pattern as the flagship Mocotó, namely informal and inclusive cuisine that combines influences from the Sertão region courtesy of founder José Almeida (the chef's father) and an innovative approach from renowned cook Rodrigo Oliveira. Even though the original chef is not present In this Vila Leopoldina outpost, it is clear that the brand’s identity remains intact through expressive flavours and seasonings. Simplicity is very much to the fore here, a sentiment enhanced by the cheerful colour scheme and the open kitchen running the length of the dining room and is one of the main reasons it is never empty. If you’re keen to savour the chef's homely cuisine, we recommend arriving early as the restaurant does not take bookings.

Name: Più Higienópolis
Description: If you’re passionate about Italian cuisine and delicious fresh pasta, you’ve probably already heard of this restaurant, as Più is one of the pioneers of Italian cooking in the Greater São Paulo area. Under the baton of chef Marcelo Laskani, it now has its second outlet in the Shopping Pátio Higienópolis, where the innovative cooking calls upon top-quality Brazilian ingredients. Dishes such as tuna carpaccio stand out for their fresh, light touch, and are raised to an even higher level by a delicious accompaniment of fresh tomato, raspberry vinegar and burrata. No review of Più is complete without mentioning the house speciality, the braised ossobuco which is slow cooked for 12 hours and served with a creamy aligot of manioc with cheese. The superb array of cocktails adds to the experience!

Name: Cora
Address: Rua Amaral Gurgel, 344, São Paulo, 01221-000, Brazil
Description: Located in the heart of the city, in an unusual sixth-floor setting with views of the Minhocão, Cora is one of the most popular restaurants in São Paulo. The kitchen here is run by Argentinian chef Pablo Inca, whose aim is to “share experiences connected with the land for an urban experience”. The concise menu is designed for sharing and changes in line with the availability of the best market ingredients. Having said this, some dishes are permanent fixtures, such as the unmissable squid omelette, which highlights the chef’s roots, and the duck heart accompanied by a delicate roasted cauliflower and onion cream. Another amazing option is the “olhete” fish with caju, lemon and pepper, which is fresh and full of flavour. An excellent choice of wines and other drinks completes the picture.

Name: Petí Gastronomia
Description: A restaurant that will come as something of a surprise given its location inside the Pintar Artistic Materials boutique, in the Pompeia district of the city. Here, you’ll find an unpretentious yet welcoming ambience, plus a glass-fronted patio with an organic garden. Young chef Victor Dimitrow, who gained experience working in leading restaurants in Europe, creates contemporary cuisine which is fragrant, full of taste and highly expressive from fresh and organic ingredients, but without unnecessary frills. The menu is updated every three weeks or so and offers three full options (including cover charge, starter, main course and dessert), a vegetarian version, another that includes the fish of the day, and a fourth with grilled Wagyu beef. These are also complemented by the à la carte. O Petí is only open lunchtimes from Tuesday to Sunday.

Name: Manioca
Address: Avenida Brigadeiro Faria Lima 2232, São Paulo, 01451-000, Brazil
