Description: This charming small restaurant has a contemporary decor of paintings and designer chairs on the first floor of a stone - built house. Tasty cuisine showcasing seasonal market produce with an emphasis on vegetables.

Name: Racines by Daniel Gallacher
Description: This self-taught chef with Scottish roots can be relied on to turn out inventive and brilliant dishes that spurn conventionality; he changes his menu every week according to produce to be had at the market. Fresh and meticulous dishes, as in his sea bream marinated in a green herb infusion. The food is dependably delicious, and the restaurant, which calls to mind a modern bistro, is always full.

Name: Fidelis
Description: At their spot facing the ramparts, this professional couple are making a big splash with delicious traditional cuisine that remains true to the ingredients: salmon tartare tacos with guacamole, pico de gallo and crème fraîche; minced chicken, rice noodles, coriander, ginger, garlic and soy sauce; peanut and chocolate parfait, salted butter caramel and vanilla ice cream. A pleasant location and smiling bistro service!

Name: Spica
Address: 48 rue de la Préfecture, Dijon, 21000, France
Description: The former Café de la Préfecture is run by a young Japanese chef who worked (most notably) at La Maison des Cariatides. Think upcycled furniture, jazz music, unique menu with meticulously prepared market-fresh cuisine, and Burgundy wines at bargain prices. The pâté en croûte made in the traditional way made an impression, as did the rib eye steak with a red wine sauce and cardamom espuma: it's bold and it works!

Name: La Table du Fleuve
Description: The brainchild of Thierry and Julien Verrat, this Charentes restaurant is distinctly bistronomic in style. The menu keeps pace with the seasons. For example, semi-preserved duck foie gras and truffles; tartare of trout with herbs and its caviar or raspberries with pineau des Charentes topping and steamed meringue. On fine days, meals are served on the terrace. An aristocratic yet welcoming setting devoted to good food.

Name: Le Malu
Address: 1 route de Tours (à Villerable), Vendôme, 41100, France
Description: A military barracks under Napoleon III, the site has since been converted into a restaurant, where chef Ludovic Brethenoux brings in the big guns. Originally from Périgord, he trained, most notably, at La Villa Madie in Cassis. His affinity with the Vendômois area is evident in his precise and refined contemporary cuisine. A real treat.

Name: Cozna
Description: After a stint in several prestigious establishments in France and the US, Sandra and Léo have settled in a car-free street in historic Annecy. Tradition is their motto (“cozna” means cooking in the Savoie dialect), a credo with which their diners wholeheartedly agree. The food is delicious food and served with a smile. A genuine good deal.

Name: La Loge Bertin
Description: Behind the stylish mint green façade, an enthusiastic team is ready to take you on a gourmet adventure. The chef uses only the freshest ingredients to create extremely tasty, beautifully presented market-inspired cuisine. The contemporary bistro-style interior was recently refurbished.

Name: La Safranière
Address: 52 rue du Lavoir, hameau de Chabrits, Mende, 48000, France
Description: A gourmet restaurant situated on the site of an old saffron farm in the Gévaudan foothills. Enjoy seasonal cuisine in a fresh, colourful dining room. Cheese and wine from the region take pride of place on the menu.

Name: Au Bon Accueil
Description: In a quiet street in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower, you can enjoy appetising market-fresh cuisine that mirrors the seasons and comes at a very reasonable price: smoked heart fillet of salmon served with lemon cream; roasted chicken supreme, oyster mushrooms and grenaille potatoes; pavlova with exotic fruits – all accompanied by well-chosen wines. A reliably good option, which is always booked out!

Name: Voyages des Sens
Description: After learning the ropes in the company of legendary chefs, Nicolas Morelle has opened his own establishment in this pretty village. He works hand in hand with small local producers, devising intelligent, subtle dishes that hit the spot every time, such as trout, horseradish emulsion and organic seasonal veggies. A cheerful casual vibe sets the scene and curious connoisseurs can keep an eye on the kitchen and the chef through a window to the rear.

Name: Café A
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The beating heart of Maison Aribert, Café A never sleeps – it is open throughout the week from breakfast to dinner. Remaining true to his "village café" theme, which reinterprets recipes handed down from mothers and grandmothers, the chef proposes fine bistronomy cuisine at affordable prices. The simple food is made from carefully selected ingredients. Memorable dishes include a simply addictive pain perdu made with brioche served with ice cream and caramel sauce. A safe bet every time. Brunch on Sundays.

Name: Lai'Tcha
Description: In this annex of Yam'tcha, located at the foot of Église St-Eustache, you can enjoy simple but straight-to-the-point Chinese cuisine that is fragrant and made with fine ingredients. The short menu offers various dim sums, but also fresh home-made noodles, Imperial sautéed beef and an excellent salad of Galician beef, lamb's lettuce and oyster mushrooms.

Name: Pica Pica
Description: Fabien Lefebvre, formerly Michelin-starred at Octopus, as well as being crowned "Meilleur Ouvrier de France" 2004, is the chef behind this delicious and friendly brasserie. He serves up uninhibited Mediterranean cuisine, cleverly blended with other influences. The menu features a selection of tapas (hummus with cumin and pita bread; croquetas de jamón), picas such as lamb kebab with za'atar and sumac, or grilled octopus. More elaborate dishes include semi-salted cod, watercress and gnocchi, lemon and caviar emulsion. And then there are the tasty desserts. A down-to-earth concept, with sharing in mind. The lunch menu is a steal. A resounding success.

Name: Les Arpents
Description: Not far from the château, this contemporary bistro nestled behind a traditional burgundy-coloured façade makes an impression! Two old friends, who met at Tours hospitality management school, rustle up a flawless culinary experience, delving freely into the abundance of first-rate local produce available, from asparagus and strawberries in season to Roi Rose pork and goat's cheese. Dishes that taste as delicious as they sound include roasted scallops, cauliflower and vanilla oil; or lemon tart sprinkled with dried black lemon, a wickedly tempting detail that makes this dessert irresistible.

Name: L'Atelier Locavore
Address: 2 avenue de la Libération, Le Coteau, 42120, France
Description: On the banks of the Loire, this establishment is now in the hands of a local lad. He aims to serve market-fresh dishes throbbing in flavour with a bargain-priced lunchtime menu and a more elaborate monthly menu. The majority of his ingredients come from within a radius of 200km, albeit with the occasional saltwater fish: his Brittany monkfish spiked with langoustine is truly mind-blowing!

Name: Mova
Description: From a line-up of carefully selected seasonal ingredients (vegetables and fish), François Merle conjures up appetising, modern recipes, illustrated by a fresh, light starter of rillettes of seabream, celery pickles, coriander sorbet and fish eggs, whose distinctive flavours are exquisitely harmonious. Single set menu at lunchtime, tasting menu in the evening.

Name: L'Épicerie
Address: 1 chemin des Usages, La Borne, 18250, France
Description: Is the restaurant a grocer’s or is it the other way round? Whatever, this cheerful, two-in-one business quietly feeds us well, which is all that matters! Mathieu (in charge of savoury dishes) and Clémentine (desserts) curate a seasonal menu with 100% regional produce, making their unpretentious eatery a hit with the locals, always a good sign. All the tableware is the handiwork of artisans established in this thriving pottery village. Beware, 20 seats only, so book before you come! An affably French establishment offering a taste of rural life in times past!

Name: Les Dilettants
Description: Formerly a salesman for a leading pétanque brand, Thomas Filiaggi changed direction at the age of 30 to satisfy his love of cooking. He proposes an individual cuisine, largely based on fresh vegetables and aromatic herbs from his garden. A gem!

Name: L'Océanide
Description: Roasted scallops with cabbage and crunchy buckwheat, red mullet in a shellfish jus... L'Océanide certainly maintains close ties to the sea, although the menu also features duck foie gras simply ‘cuit au naturel’ and veal kidneys sautéed with shallots. Chef David Garrec sources his produce from the famous Talensac Market next-door, hence the unmistakable freshness of the fish! The authentic 1950s vintage interior oozes old-fashioned charm by the bucket load.

Name: Olive & Artichaut
Description: Originally from Nice, the chef moved back to the region with his Breton wife after several stints abroad. He showcases local ingredients in knockout recipes, inspired by the sea and the mountains: pissaladière-style wafer-thin tart with roast black pudding, braised chuck veal with creamy chickpeas and a chocolate and hazelnut praline pie to finish.

Name: L'Auberge du Pont des Pierres
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This restaurant on the road to Monts Jura is invariably busy! Chef Romain Blanc, who hails from the region, has no shortage of talent or ideas when it comes to cooking seasonal local produce: fish from Lake Geneva or nearby fish farms, pork and poultry from the surrounding area, local market gardeners and a herb garden. He also demonstrates a flair for preparing jus and a mastery of cooking processes, and makes a lot from scratch (including ice cream and bread). Bargain prices and service with a smile from Chloé, who will guide you through the nice selection of wines from independent winegrowers.

Name: Le Jardin Les Crayères
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The little sister of the Château les Crayères, housed in an outbuilding in the park, is a smart, very contemporary and elegant brasserie with its own veranda and terrace just opposite the herb garden. Flavoursome seasonal cooking.

Name: Le Cerisier
Description: The menu at this small restaurant with a modern interior makes your mouth water in anticipation of the hearty, unpretentious dishes and the house speciality, pâté en croûte, made with different ingredients as the seasons change. In the kitchen, a couple is at work, preparing delicious cuisine that highlights local produce such as Ardèche trout. The desserts are particularly meticulous – poached pear with mulled wine, vanilla and speculoos trifle, pear sorbet. The terrific wine list (600 labels) includes a judicious choice of wines by the glass.

Name: Restaurant Anne & Matthieu Omont - Hôtel de France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: Treat yourself to a gourmet interlude in this establishment on the village high street. Chef, Matthieu Omont crafts masterful, boldly creative cuisine, to be enjoyed in a spruce modern setting. A champion of Bourbonnais produce, he also works with top-drawer seafood: fillet of whiting in a crust of cèpes, langoustine cream and risotto of Vernusse pleurote mushrooms, followed by a rum-flavoured raisin pannacotta, finely diced granny smith apples, a pear sorbet and a Piattelli-flavoured emulsion. Comfortable rooms, ideal for an overnight stay.

Name: Le Bistrot de Guillaume
Description: Right in the centre of Moulins, the small dining area is light and intimate, already setting the tone, and we don't need to be asked twice to be shown to our table. But the best is yet to come: in his little kitchen, the chef-owner composes dishes that are delicate and intelligent to the joy of our tastebuds, such as his textbook perfect Provençal aioli.

Name: La Capitelle
Description: La Capitelle has plenty going for it. It offers a short menu that changes every two or three days and comprises of dishes made with quality ingredients (local, as far as possible). The traditional recipes are given a contemporary spin and are perfectly cooked. There is also an attractive vaulted dining area presided over by an imposing fireplace.

Name: La Fleur de Sel
Description: In the heart of the historic district, it is a pleasure to taste Vincent Guyon’s inspired craftsmanship. The menu might feature monkfish, fried artichokes barigoule, dried tomatoes, emulsion of artichokes, stock and Brittany curry or another house signature dish: beef tartare with oysters served with mizuna, caviar vinaigrette and grilled rice. Deftly crafted and consummately cooked.

Name: La Chaize Gourmande
Address: 2 place du Marché, La Chaize-Giraud, 85220, France
Description: In this friendly, contemporary eatery, Cédric Merlaud, who aims for “enlightened international” seasonal cuisine, adds a sprinkling of originality to predominantly regional ingredients. Dishes can include the catch of the day from local Vendée ports and vegetables from small-scale market gardeners. Carefully executed, aromatic and mouth-wateringly tempting. Deliciously eater-friendly prices.

Name: PY Restaurant
Description: In this dinky brasserie in a smart neighbourhood, Pierre (in the kitchen) and Yuko (front of house) make the magic happen. In this contemporary decor, diners sample generous, well-crafted dishes. The à la carte menu in the evening is enriched with premium dishes such as hare pâté en croûte.

Name: Le Muratore
Description: The Muratore house is named after its former owner, a liquor-maker and confectioner. It stands on a pedestrian street of Évian overlooking an exquisite square with a fountain in its centre. Now a restaurant, it is in the hands of Marc Serres, who crafts wholesome regional fare. The menu is sensibly priced and the à la carte range stars noble ingredients, including fish from the lake, without forgetting a few hearty classics from Lyons. Shaded by a linden tree, the terrace is bliss in summertime.

Name: Winstub du Chambard
Description: The chef, Olivier Nasti, revisits all that Alsace's terroir has to offer: baeckeoffe and choucroute, onion tart and presskopf... Without forgetting the trout from the vallée d’Orbey, with white wine sauce, and an iced kougelhopf to die for. Tasty and generous, an ode to good food! Daily specials on the chalkboard too.

Name: Le Jean Moulin
Description: Tables are set up on either side of this elongated dining space divided by a glazed wine cellar. The industrial loft-inspired designer decor is the perfect foil to Grégoire Baratier's contemporary cuisine. The menu changes regularly, but here are two examples to give you an idea of the market-fresh cooking served here: a delicate, crispy tartlet with Burgundy snails, creamy mushrooms and parsley pesto; and a moist cake made from Ardèche chestnuts, with a few meringues, candied clementine and a pear and cardamom sorbet. Fresh, well-crafted cuisine, with the occasional nod to Lyon's culinary heritage.

Name: Le Pantruche
Description: Pantruche was a 19C slang term for Paris... an apt name for this bistro whose chic vintage décor happily nurtures a 1940s-1950s vibe. As for the food, the chef and his small team put together tasty seasonal dishes in keeping with today’s bistronomic trend. Examples include a light, fluffy, velvety Grand Marnier soufflé, worthy of any fine dining establishment. A bright red awning offers shelter to a few tables on the pavement in typical Parisian fashion. As well as resolutely authentic, this restaurant offers eater-friendly prices.

Name: Abri Soba
Description: You may have heard of soba, Japanese pasta made with buckwheat, the reputation of which is currently snowballing around the planet. The chef of this restaurant has made soba his house speciality and serves it lunch and evening in an amazing variety of preparations: hot, cold, in stock or with finely sliced duck. Simply flavoursome – get out your chopsticks!

Name: Winstub À Côté
Description: An extension of Auberge St Laurent, this winstub gives diners a taste of Alsace – tarte flambée with marinated Scottish salmon, "granny's" home-made spaetzle – in a contemporary decor (designer furniture and light fittings, copper-topped counter). Unbeatable value for money and excellent service are the key to the success of this establishment: it's often fully booked!

Name: Phô Tai
Description: In a quiet street in the Asian quarter, Mr and Mrs Té keep a watchful eye over their little Vietnamese canteen, which has its fair share of regulars. In a boisterous atmosphere, diners tuck into flavoursome home-style cooking at tightly packed tables: crispy chicken with fresh ginger, bò bún; the phở soup and Vietnamese dumplings (bánh cuốn) deserve a special mention. Very reasonable prices.

Name: Les Canailles Pigalle
Description: This pleasant restaurant was opened by a pair from Brittany who can boast impressive culinary backgrounds. Here, the name of the game is bistronomy and seasonal recipes. Specialities include beef tongue carpaccio with ravigote sauce, and rum baba with whipped vanilla cream – a real treat! Tip: if the restaurant is full, go to Le Comptoir Canaille, just a few doors down, where they serve more contemporary cuisine.

Name: Au Pont Corbeau
Description: Experience local gastronomic specialities and traditional decor (Renaissance features, posters) in this restaurant next door to the Musée Alsacien, with its displays of popular art.

Name: Impérial Choisy
Description: In the heart of Paris's Chinatown, this Chinese restaurant is popular with many people from the local Asian community, who have adopted it as their canteen. In a room that is always full (the service runs non-stop from lunch to dinner, and is fast-paced, to say the least!), they serve fine Cantonese specialities, including crispy pork and Peking duck. A truly authentic meal, without breaking the bank! You can't book here; you just have to go and wait to be seated.

Name: L'Antre Amis
Description: The chef-patron at L'Antre Amis brings passion to his cooking. Using the finest seasonal ingredients, he composes a short up-to-the-minute menu, which also includes traditional dishes (pâté en croûte made with game and foie gras; cod loin fillet in a pistachio crust, spinach and ricotta cannelloni), plus tapas-style dishes for sharing. To be accompanied by your pick from over 500 different wines. Pleasant contemporary decor and terrace on a quiet street.

Name: L'Araignée Gourmande
Address: 8 rue de la Paix, Laragne-Montéglin, 05300, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: Settle at your table in this bright, modern interior and experience the talent of Thierry Chouin. This Breton chef may have a particular penchant for fish - based fare, but that doesn't mean he snubs lamb and potatoes. He fetes the ingredients with nicely turned - out dishes, each a lovely homage to tradition.

Name: Au Petit Relais
Description: This restaurant proposes exceptionally tasty dishes featuring lobster, fine fish, Bresse specialities and choice wines. The dining room is smart, and the service is friendly.

Name: L'Alcôve
Description: Just behind the cathedral, this restaurant has been treated to a makeover and a new name, whilst retaining its culinary hallmark: expertly crafted, market-fresh recipes as full of flavour as they are flawlessly prepared. Examples include spider crab, crunchy veg and vinegar sorbet; whole grain risotto with asparagus, confit artichokes and an emulsion of wild garlic. Enduringly popular, all the more so because of the eater-friendly prices.

Name: Auberge de la Baraque
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: "In the interior, as cosy and hushed as they come (fireplace, mouldings and chandeliers) of this coaching inn (1800), diners can enjoy quality contemporary cuisine; it is tasty and nicely presented. Pleasant service, reasonable prices and good wine list. "

Name: Hostellerie d'Héloïse
Description: Wholesome regional dishes – Burgundy snails, Charolais beef and a reduction of red wine from Mâcon, together with tempting traditional recipes (roast turbot, mashed cauliflower and veal gravy), have built the reputation of this hostelry, which also proposes more modern dishes and a splendid choice of wines by the glass. Lovely bright conservatory overlooking the River Grosne. Rooms for overnight stays.

Name: Art'zain
Description: Artzain means "shepherd" in Basque – a tribute by the owner to his father. Located in the centre of the village, this converted barn has retained its rustic feel, with its exposed stone beams and walls, while sporting a designer style thanks to the furniture by Basque craftsman Alki. The menu features an enticing array of seasonal and predominantly local cuisine that doesn't disappoint, with dishes such as the flavoursome warm terrine of Kriaxera duck, Arto Gorria corn polenta galette, caramelised spring onions and crispy ventrèche.

Name: La Taverne Alsacienne
Address: 99 rue de la République, Ingersheim, 68040, France
Description: Run by the Guggenbuhl family since 1964, this salmon-pink-fronted tavern has earned its reputation. Even those who know nothing about Alsace cuisine are smitten by the enticing regional dishes, washed down by fine wines from near and far! The fillet of zander, sautéed sauerkraut and Riesling sauce we sampled lingers with us still.

Name: Bistrot RG
Description: MICHELIN-starred chef Nicolas Gautier (from Nature, just next door) and his brother Mathieu pay tribute to the cooking of their father Roger Gautier (RG) with a short menu featuring tasty unpretentious dishes and a bill that won't break the bank: "Antoine" pâté en croute or the chef's grilled veal sausage billed as "15-20cm of happiness". This convivial place keeps it in the family.

Name: Mets et Vins
Address: 11 rue de la République, Bourg-en-Bresse, 01000, France
Description: This is the kingdom of Stéphane Prévalet, a champion of local produce and home-made fare who enjoys pushing traditional culinary boundaries. Examples include chicory and blue cheese upside-down pie or Dombes duckling with Bugey blackcurrant. A minimalist interior decorated with birch trunks sets the scene in this trendy establishment.

Name: La Table Bâgésienne
Description: Behind the façade of this former coaching inn lies a contemporary interior, complete with a glazed wine cellar, and hearty Bresse cuisine to make your mouth water… Pommes Anna with frogs' legs sautéed with a garlic butter cream, Bresse poultry with cream and vin jaune, or the traditional nougat glacé. Pleasant, quiet terrace to the rear.

Name: Le Pressoir de Bacchus
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: Such is the renown of Sylvie Grucker and her son that this pretty restaurant on the wine route is greatly in demand. Sylvie combines traditional recipes with an inventive streak in a bid to showcase regional fare: bacon-flavoured choucroute soup or duck shepherd’s pie, mushrooms and 12-spice sauce, side by side perennial favourites like granddad’s snails, ravioles of carp in a creamy, smoked sauce or Sylvie’s meringue and ice cream extravaganza! Local winegrowers and producers from the village (thirty or so) take pride of place on the enticing wine list.

Name: L'Olivier
Description: Chef Olivier Lamard, former second-in-command to Michelin-starred Julien Binz, now has his own restaurant. He proposes modern cuisine that draws on the terroir of Alsace: soft cheese mousse, potato salad and home-smoked trout, pork from Goettelmann’s farm, and for dessert, pear with sesame. Nicely prepared dishes made from fine ingredients, some of which come from the chef's grandfather's garden. A charming place.

Name: Le Beaujolais
Description: With such a name, this Beaujolais could not do otherwise than pay tribute to a region famous for its fine food and wines! The friendly couple that runs this house has hit the nail on the head with hearty wholesome fare. Examples include traditional andouillette, whole grain mustard sauce and sautéed potatoes.

Name: Le Rousseau
Address: 16 bis cours Saint-André, Le Pont-de-Claix, 38800, France
Description: In low-key, tasteful and contemporary premises, the new Le Rousseau is now more spacious and boasts a quiet alfresco area to the rear. Chef Élie Michel-Villaz, who remains forever faithful to his defining mantra, simplicity, rolls out a fresh, carefully crafted repertory, paired with lovingly selected wines (several hundred references – many natural or biodynamic), served in a casual atmosphere. A short supply chain business that is going strong. Simpler menu at lunchtime.

Name: Une Table à Deux
Address: 10 rue de la Pleau, Toulouse, 31000, France
Description: After learning the ropes in Toulouse, Morgane and Nicolas made a beeline for Korea and Malaysia to research new flavours. Back in their hometown, they have chosen the Carmes district to regale diners with playful recipes that blend Mediterranean and tropical flavours, resulting in impressively curated and beautifully balanced dishes. Fantastic value for money lunchtime menu.

Name: Balsamique
Description: The youthful chef has more than one trick up his sleeve and his cuisine, poised between regional and modern, throbs with flavour. Examples include Tatin-style black pudding with cider apples. Daring recipes enhanced by impeccable produce (fish from Boulogne-sur-Mer, for example). Slick service. The peaceful little terrace is a real draw, especially on summer evenings!

Name: Aux Plumes
Description: A young Japanese chef with a great track record creates inspired, generous cuisine using the best ingredients in the neighbourhood. Cream of sweet potato soup, cocoa emulsion; lychee and coconut milk blancmange and exotic fruit minestrone – the original dishes are carefully prepared, change on a weekly basis and are delicious every time. At lunchtime, a trilogy of starters at an unbeatable price.

Name: Le Bouchon Bourguignon
Description: Generous, meticulous cuisine inspired by the culinary traditions of Burgundy is served in the contemporary setting of this annexe to Yohann Chapuis's fine dining restaurant. The regional classics are present and correct: "pâté croûte Maison Greuze", eggs meurette (in a red wine sauce), fresh frog's legs in a parsley sauce, Bresse chicken with morels and vin jaune, as well as more refined creations such as carpaccio of Charolais beef with verbena oil, cherry tomatoes and shavings of Comté. It makes a delightful change to see a list of wines served from magnums available by the glass.

Name: Nougier
Description: For three generations, this delightful inn has been cultivating the art of hospitality and good food. The chef concocts meticulous dishes that toe the line between tradition and modernity and pay tribute to the seasons. So take a seat and order safe in the knowledge you will eat well!

Name: Mandoobar
Description: Good authentic Korean restaurants are not two a penny in Paris, but this little restaurant, where the chef works behind his counter, is one of them: diners look on while Kim Kwang-Loc, as nimble-fingered as he is precise, creates the famous mandu (Korean dumplings) and tuna and beef tartares that make up the bulk of his minimalist menu. Passionate about Korean herbs, he seasons each of his delicate and tasty dishes with addictive flavours, perhaps in a quest to recreate his earliest culinary memories in Korea…

Name: 52 Faubourg St-Denis
Description: Fans of neo-bistro aesthetics will love this place done out in bare concrete and exposed stone, where diners tuck into cuisine infused with Asian flavours, as well as time-honoured bistro classics such as pâté de campagne (rustic-style pâté) or leeks in vinaigrette. The food is nicely washed down with fine wines or craft beer, and you can round off your meal with coffee selected and roasted by the owner. Please note: no reservations.

Name: Le Radis Beurre
Description: Diners are drawn here by the warm welcome, the buzzing atmosphere, the appetising menu written on a large blackboard and, above all, by the tasty, well-crafted cuisine of chef Jérôme Bonnet. His cooking is influenced by his origins – the South of France – as one can see in dishes such as the appetising shoulder of suckling pig sautéed in a pan with Tarbais beans au jus and roasted vegetables, or the excellent riz au lait with salt crystal dulce de leche. This place is all about comfort food simmering on the stove. A real favourite, and the ideal place to celebrate with friends!

Name: Le Bistrot du Château de Berne
Description: The simple, sun-drenched menu is packed with ingredients that call to mind the surrounding landscape. Crunchy local asparagus; rack of Duroc de Bataillé pork with an Asian twist; apple pastry, almond cream and caramel. These fresh, unfussy dishes are accompanied by wines from the estate. The prices are reasonable, and efficient service is provided by a team who are able to converse with the substantial English-speaking clientele.

Name: L'Atelier Flavien Valère
Description: After honing his talents around southwest France, Flavien Valère has decided to treat Langon to his culinary flair. He knows his stuff, no doubt about that: impeccable cooking techniques, perfect seasonings, premium produce and carefully crafted recipes – everything is from scratch, to our delight! Eater-friendly priced lunchtime menu. Bookings advisable.

Name: Sépia
Description: This little eatery near the beach is perfect for lunch. It is run by a pair of catering pros – she is in the dining room while her hubbie, who boasts stints in fine restaurants, helms the kitchen. Whether in the dining space with its maritime decor, or on the lovely timber-decked terrace, you will sample vibrant, legible food that warms the soul: tartare of sea bream fished off the coast of Valras; pollock, aioli and black rice; creamy coconut and pineapple marinated in ginger.

Name: Jouvence
Address: 172 bis rue du Faubourg-Saint-Antoine, Paris, 75012, France
Description: Not far from rue de Cîteaux, this restaurant in an apothecary-style shop dating back to the 1900s is not merely aesthetically pleasing. It serves modern cuisine packed with quality ingredients: scallop ceviche, fine Angus beef entrecôte… The chef knows how to draw out flavours with a generous touch, and the service is attentive.

Name: Auberge Pyrénées Cévennes
Address: 106 rue de la Folie-Méricourt, Paris, 75011, France
Description: Chef Pierre Négrevergne is really flourishing in this house that is over 100 years old. He delights diners with his tasty "grandmother's" cooking, which highlights French gastronomic heritage (home-made terrine, blanquette de veau à l'ancienne and grilled rice, millefeuille), served in generous portions. It is still a treat to eat here.

Name: Le Tire Bouchon
Description: Pay little attention to the unremarkable façade of this restaurant, as the main focus is on the pretty dining room with its exposed beams and open fire. Refined traditional cuisine that follows the seasons is served. Friendly service with a smile.

Name: Le CasseNoix
Address: 56 rue de la Fédération, Paris, 75015, France
Description: Old signs, clocks and vintage furniture: the scene is set. As for the food, authenticity is the order of the day: delicious down - to - earth canaille cuisine, good wines and an amusing collection of nutcrackers picked up here and there by the owner's mum. Tasty.

Name: La Vieille Forge
Description: Beyond the rustic façade of this charming 16C house, some lovely surprises lie in store: chef Laurine Gutleben's dishes give pride of place to fresh produce and free rein to creativity, for instance the scallops with light hollandaise, braised leeks and gomasio popcorn. Well-chosen wine list, particularly from Alsace but not only.

Name: Le Jour du Poisson
Description: Run by a youthful team, this friendly little bistro at the tip of the island is often fully booked. The menu, as short as it is tempting, is everything it's cracked up to be: fish, from local fish auctions, features in many guises, short supply chains and natural wines are favoured, the bread is made in-house with flour sourced from Oléron. Agnolotti of langoustines, lemon butter and herbs is the signature dish.

Name: U Licettu
Description: Could this pink-rendered villa, decked in flowers and overlooking the gulf, have found the secret of authentic Corsican food? Whatever the case, you can be certain that you will sample wholehearted, full-bodied dishes made with first-class ingredients in keeping with time-honoured culinary traditions: nothing goes to waste from pig’s trotters to tails, the meat is slowly spit-roasted on the open fire or the lady of the house hovering nearby to check you finish your plate. Beverages included in the menu. Highly recommended.

Name: Le Balcon
Description: Chef Jean-Philippe Gauthier is upholding the traditions of this former coaching inn, which has been in the family since 1951. House specialties include: terrine of quail with plums and armagnac and a knockout trolley of matured cheeses. Meals are served in an interior that blends character and authenticity. Charming welcome and service. Rooms for overnight stays.

Name: L'Angle Saint-Laurent
Description: The arrival of a new couple at the helm, who worked for many years alongside the former owners, has changed nothing in terms of the establishment’s concept or philosophy: regional produce is cast in the leading role (Bayeux pork, Normandy oysters, Carrouges gruyere) of the appetising lineup. On the corner of Rue St Laurent and Rue des Bouchers, the setting is also as appealing as ever with exposed stone, painted beams and soft lighting. What’s not to like?

Name: La Maison de Celou
Description: Clinging to the ramparts of the historic village, this lovely house embodies the art de vivre of Provence. The chef crafts spot-on dishes, steeped in originality, illustrated by scallops on toast with spinach and confit of tomatoes. The decadent desserts are fiendishly tempting, even addictive. Superlative sweeping view over Mont Ventoux and the Luberon range from the terrace.

Name: Relais de l'Abbaye
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This modern Relais, looking out onto the surrounding meadows, is anchored in local culinary traditions. The chef is passionate about fine ingredients and showcases regional producers (Charlieu andouille, Charolais meat, cheese etc) in contemporary, hearty dishes. Pleasant guestrooms for an overnight stay.

Name: Le Relais des Salines
Address: Port des Salines, Le Grand-Village-Plage, 17370, France
Description: This waterside bistro showcases seafood flavours and super-fresh produce. The menu sails between timeless classics (oysters, confit of octopus, lentils, mustard-flavoured sabayon and the chef’s lemon pie) and more spur-of-the-moment recipes. Inside, this former oyster shed upholds its heritage, while the terrace overlooking the marshes is blissful.

Name: Bistrot Saveurs
Description: British chef Simon Scott knocked around in London and Provence, before setting up shop in Tarn. A vibrant red façade leads into the snug trendy interior. This eclectic chef and master craftsman works exclusively with first-class ingredients (preferably local) in a bid to serve crisp, legible food oozing with flavour and aroma: cannelloni of king prawns wrapped in local courgettes, asparagus, truffle-flavoured mimosa eggs and squid ink ice cream; plancha seared slab of veal, foamy mashed carrot and nigella blossom, carrots in cream of cumin and carrot tops… Searingly good food throbbing with flavour!

Name: Le Flaveur
Description: This restaurant is tucked away in a side street set back from the marina and the walled city. Harmony reigns in the kitchen, where a duo of chefs composes dishes made with ultra-fresh ingredients. Locally sourced produce takes pride of place on the menu: buckwheat, the daily catch of small local boats, Brittany-reared pork, Bruyère Blanche poultry, farm-range eggs, without forgetting the excellent homemade bread.

Name: L'Écureuil
Description: This modern bistro with its chic country decor serves appetising market-fresh cuisine: duck breast with black olives, pork cheeks braised in red wine, French toast made with brioche... The short menu is chalked up on the blackboard, and a simpler lunch deal is available at a snip.

Name: Le Beauvoir
Description: Annie and Mickaël Landaud are at the helm of an elegant family establishment which is quite a favourite with the locals. The bluish tones and plant-inspired artwork pay homage to the nearby marshlands… The chef conjures up modern, appetising dishes, adding a playful new spin to a traditional Gallic score. Alfresco dining in the rear courtyard.

Name: Les Quatre Saisons
Description: The cooking of Didier Guibert, whose restaurant is located in a quiet little street in the city centre, is sincere and nicely done. He only works with fresh produce – and in particular meat supplied by his two brothers, butchers by trade. A well-run place.

Name: La Rapière
Description: This restaurant in a 15C building, tucked into a picturesque little street, has earned itself a good reputation. It serves fresh fish, fine local specialities or a sunnier culinary register.

Name: Italie là-bas
Address: 23 rue de la Bancasse, Avignon, 84000, France
Description: This enthusiastic Italian couple is living proof that Italians do it better. While he pampers guests front of house, she rustles up delicious Italian dishes, some highly creative, to propose tasting menus that include a vegetarian option. Buon appetito!

Name: La Cour de Rémi
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: After pursuing a career abroad, the chef has returned to his roots, to the family's former hunting lodge, to devote himself to cooking – his earliest passion. In this convivial place, he has perfectly mastered generous traditional cuisine, from cooking to seasoning. We love the terrine with home-made sourdough bread and gherkins from the estate in vinegar. The plus: overnight accommodation in a cabin on stilts!

Name: Au Bon Accueil
Description: You will first be won over by the vintage charm of this 1960’s house, before you meet the talented team of the brother (in the kitchen) and his sister (in the dining room), who are both fast gaining in confidence. The food is on-point, the wine cellar savvy and the terrace very pleasant in season.

Name: Le Martin Bel Air
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This completely renovated country bistro opposite the town hall welcomes you into a natural, contemporary setting (pale wood, cork wall decorations, black ceiling). The chef, who has trained in some of the region's finest establishments, creates modern and sophisticated market-fresh dishes that are unbeatable value for money. Think beef tartare with wasabi, onion pickles and spicy carrot – a punchy starter with harmonious flavours.

Name: La Terrasse
Description: The terrace under the vine-shaded pergola is the perfect spot in fine weather, while in winter you can take refuge inside, beneath the medieval vaults of this former 11C stronghold, done out with contemporary furnishings. On the menu: dishes with bold flavours, featuring regional producers: lamb from the Lot, farm-reared pork, and poultry from Mayrac etc. View of the cliffs and the Dordogne.

Name: La Croix d'Or
Address: 6 rue de la Herse, Le Pin-la-Garenne, 61400, France
Description: A country inn with an authentic family atmosphere. After working in some of the finest restaurants, the chef returned to his roots and transformed his grandparents house into a traditional inn serving fine cuisine.

Name: L'Orangerie
Address: 9 rue de la Prépoise, Pornic, 44210, France
Description: Trained by some of the best (Alain Dutournier, Jean-Michel Lorrain, Alain Ducasse), chef Julien Lainé crafts enticing food that surfs between tradition (leek vinaigrette; veal vol-au-vent; chocolate fondant cake and cocoa sorbet) and modernity (carpaccio of croaker and blood orange dressing; pan-seared line-caught seabass with a haddock emulsion). In a seaside resort such as Pornic, this eatery with two colourful little dining areas and an open kitchen is most welcome.

Name: L'AO - L'Aigle d'Or
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: A young generation has brought a zest of modernity by way of more contemporary plating techniques and recipes (octopus with miso broth, or braised breast of pork with bbq-style jus and chimichurri…) all the while continuing to celebrate regional traditions (brawn, frogs’ legs, game etc). Practical rooms for overnight stays.

Name: In-Fine
Description: In his sleek restaurant in the centre of Frontignan, self-taught chef Grégory Doucey is a stickler for ensuring the quality of his ingredients: he sources fish from the nearby Sète fish market, vegetables from a market gardener in Fabrègues, beef and veal selected from a nearby farm in Aveyron. This delicious cuisine strikes a balance between the local terroir and modern fare, with optimum flavour as the underlying principle. Served up by a dynamic young team, the dishes form a particularly colourful palette: a light espuma of herb mayonnaise and mustard seed pickles cuts through the green of crunchy roasted asparagus; the dense, fleshy meatiness of the pollack is enhanced by colourful wilted spinach, fondant carrots and broccoli tips.

Name: La Falène Bleue
Address: Place de la Mairie, Lannepax, 32190, France
Description: Fabien, in the kitchen, and Hélène, front of house, have combined their two first names and come up with La Falène Bleue, where life is good and so is the food. Everything is both simple and delightful, from the carefully presented dishes (featuring ingredients sourced entirely from local producers) to the interior, decorated with paintings and vintage objects. This restaurant in the small village of Lannepax is surrounded by vineyards and has a pleasant terrace to the rear. The lunch set menu changes weekly and is good value for money.

Name: Clamato
Description: Inspired by the oyster bars of the East Coast of the United States, this outpost of Septime owes its name to a cocktail that is very popular in Quebec, a Bloody Mary of sorts with the addition of clam juice – needless to say, you can try one here! The place has all the makings of a bistronomy hit, with its trendy decor and short menu that puts fish and seafood and vegetables centre stage, and draws on international influences. The ingredients are chosen with great care and prepared as simply as possible, then presented in plates for sharing. Please note that reservations are not possible: first come, first served!

Name: Quai 17
Description: Don't hesitate to try out this establishment set up within a charming hotel in a wonderful location on the canal. In this plush space lit by droplet chandeliers, tuck into modern cuisine with plenty of Mediterranean flair, in which fish from Sète's market takes pride of place. Examples of dishes include mussels and snails from the lagoon or the sea, cold cream with oven-roasted garlic; sea bass with peas, red wine sauce with pig's trotters. All the magic of Sète on a plate.

Name: Côté Saisons
Address: 10 avenue de la Côte-Vermeille, Laroque-des-Albères, 66740, France
Description: Let's set the scene: a 19C building surrounded by greenery, with large bay windows, a flower-decked garden and a pretty terrace to cater to all seasons. On the menu are tasty, well-crafted dishes, eg warm calf's head with Charroux mustard, Cerdagne pig confit with honey-ginger, tender chuck of beef and pan-fried foie gras. In addition, the service is all smiles.

Name: Au Bon Accueil
Description: This restaurant with a bright, contemporary interior is true to its name when it promises a warm welcome. Chef Gaëtan Crespin works with good seasonal produce, most of it sourced locally, to craft creative and technically on-point cuisine. A shining example comes in the form of his scallops, endive and clementine, or rack of pork, parsley and spelt… And with excellent value for money guaranteed, what's not to love?

Name: Paris Méditerranée
Description: The name pays tribute to singer-songwriter Georges Brassens, a local lad, and also to Mediterranean cuisine which takes pride of place on the menu, depending on the chef’s mood, (a former Parisian) and the catch of the day. In a quiet side street near the canal, the chef deftly crafts fresh, mainly maritime produce, with a weakness for forthright, no-nonsense flavours such as sashimi of flathead grey mullet and cream of smoked anchovy. We tasted a heart-warming slab of hake served with homemade gnocchi flavoured with wild garlic. Fried squid, risotto and spicy stock is another house specialty. The chef’s wife, a native of Sète, smilingly pampers guests in the rustic dining room appointed with red bench seating.

Name: Caillebotte
Description: Chef Franck Baranger crafts fresh, thoroughly modern dishes, the secret of which only he holds: lightly seared squid, redcurrants, courgette and gremolata; line-caught fish, marinated cucumber, polenta, béarnaise sauce and fig pickles… A casual, friendly vibe provides the perfect foil to distinctive, appetising and colourful food.

Name: Lou Pinatou
Description: He’s from the hills of Puy and she’s from Marseille. He likes forthright flavours and premium produce and she’s more of a pastry buff. Their gourmet culinary repertory is two-fold: in the old stone inn is a bistro that upholds traditions, while in a brand-new structure, you will taste gastronomic fare with a fine view of the valley to boot.

Name: La Méditerranée
Description: The frescoes evoke the Mediterranean in this restaurant opposite the historic Odéon Theatre. The maritime inspired cuisine, in which particular attention is paid to first-class ingredients, is influenced by the sunny South of France. House specialties include bouillabaisse, carpaccio of seabass, honey-glazed seabream… Affordable menu, pricier à la carte offering.

Name: Jeux 2 Goûts
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: Having settled in his native region after several years spent in high - end Parisian establishments, Christophe Marchais is bringing a dose of culinary flair to Châteauroux. He prepares tasty and creative dishes, inspired by a building steeped in history. The best restaurant in the city.

Name: Auberge des Chenets
Description: You soon forget the road just outside, as you snuggle up near the fireplace of this pleasant Auberge! The menu stars simple dishes of Burgundian inspiration that are nicely crafted and packed with flavour: slow-cooked egg and snails in a red wine sauce, guinea fowl supreme, puréed potato, braised endive, Bourdaloue tart – and the bill won't break the bank.

Name: La Gabale
Description: With this brasserie, Cyril Attrazic has created the ideal offshoot of his gourmet establishment. The modern decor, adorned with panoramic photos of Aubrac landscapes, provides the perfect foil to sample full-flavoured, well-crafted dishes, whether indoors or on the shaded alfresco area out front. A few dishes you may sample include poultry and foie gras pâté en croûte with vegetable pickles; sautéed fillet of hake, red Camargue rice and pistou of herbs; strawberries, elderflower lactic sorbet and miniature waffles.

Name: Le Saint-Eutrope
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: A New Zealander, previously sous-chef here, and his partner are replacing the British chef who was at the helm for many years. The decor has been freshened up a little, and the single set lunch menu has been replaced by a short two-choice menu. The new bosses have been wise enough to maintain the winning formula: a vintage vibe, friendly atmosphere, low prices and a wine list with a passion for natural wines. The unadorned plating belies the technical refinement of the cuisine. No fancy presentations here, just trendy, family-style cooking (yes, it's possible!).

Name: Auberge des Aryelets
Description: You have to gain a little altitude to reach this village high up in the Pyrenees, which champions its exceptional natural heritage with understandable pride. On the central square, a young couple has injected a sense of enthusiasm into this place, honouring the region's traditions and produce: free-range slow-cooked egg with Noir de Bigorre ham. Other dishes are more contemporary, such as royal sea bream with sashimi and asparagus. The appealing wine list boasts almost 500 wines.

Name: La Part des Anges
Description: Market-fresh cooking with a devout respect for the seasons and just the right dose of generous creativity is the name of the game here. Local small-scale producers take pride of place and you can expect an abundance of flavours.

Name: Auberge de Combes
Description: This quintessential inn – typical of the area – stands on the heights of the Orb Valley. The terroir expresses itself in no uncertain terms: the food and the landscape share a subtle yet rugged edge. Semi-cooked foie gras over grapevine embers, wood pigeon roasted in a wine sauce, sweet chestnut and pear tart… Meals are served within hundred-year-old stone walls or on the patio which commands a sweeping view over the valley. To be washed down with a glass of Faugères, of course!

Name: L'Ourdissoir
Description: Slightly outside the city centre, this modest establishment sports a warm interior that provides the perfect foil for spot-on, modern food that generously keeps pace with the seasons. Elegant presentation and an original culinary score, with unexpected combinations.

Name: L'Auberge du Laminak
Description: In this charming inn on the edge of the forest, the Basque country – where the chef is from – meets fine produce from the Ardennes. The result is tasty and skilfully made dishes, such as the slow-cooked egg with piperade and Basque ham.

Name: Le Boudes La Vigne
Address: Place de la Mairie, Boudes, 63340, France
Description: Built on old fortifications, this pleasant restaurant lies at the heart of a wine-growing village that produces Boudes, one of the five wines of Auvergne's vineyards. Christian Coutarel, a jovial chef, works away in the kitchen preparing generous and flavoursome traditional cuisine, without ruling out more modern dishes.

Name: Au Petit Vatel
Description: Diners flock here their eyes closed to sample modern, seasonal dishes made with first-rate local produce. Examples include pâté en croûte, veal stuffing, guinea fowl, figs, gribiche sauce; stuffed confit of veal, grand veneur sauce, celery and hazelnut sauce, without forgetting a wickedly tempting dessert trolley. Your mouth will water as your read the menu, before your tastebuds even sample the flavoursome fare, as generous as the region. Prices that make sense.

Name: L'Équilibre
Address: 10 place de la Libération, Balma, 31130, France
Description: "Run by a couple of 30 - somethings, who believe in hearty, wholesome food, this restaurant fully deserves its resounding success. The chef concocts inspired and balanced recipes using top - quality, market - fresh produce: flawlessly poached egg with cream of leeks and ginger; haddock and carrot pickles. Outstanding value for money. "

Name: L'Émotion
Description: From one year to the next and from one location to another, local lad Michaël Ruat has been regaling the foodies of Puy-en-Velay. The interior sports natural materials and designer details (glazed wine cellar). The food forges a culinary course between regional Haute Loire ingredients (green lentils, premium Mézenc beef) and a more contemporary bent (tartare of red tuna, citrus fruit, fennel sorbet and crunchy pesto).

Name: La Merenda
Description: A charmingly simple, old-fashioned little restaurant, where Dominique Le Stanc prepares delicious local dishes (pissaladière, tripe à la niçoise, stockfish, chard pie, lemon tart etc) to be enjoyed at tightly packed tables. N.B. no telephone – drop in to book a table.

Name: L'Évidence
Description: After honing his skills in top houses, Julien Burdin is enjoying his well-deserved success: knockout plating, premium ingredients and crisp, legible flavours, illustrated by ham and parsley terrine, mustard-flavoured whipped cream and onion pickles. The à la carte range highlights superior produce, like blue lobster, vegetable risotto and a seafood, tomato and wine sauce. Polished service.

Name: La Table d'Inomoto
Description: This endearing bistro has acquired a faithful crowd of regulars, enchanted by the weekly changing menu. Chef Seiji Inomoto expertly crafts fine Franco-Japanese fare, in which "humble" ingredients are taken to new heights thanks to flawless cooking and astute seasoning (panko breadcrumbs, miso, soy marinated veggies). The food is good, often unusual, and you won't believe the value for money. What’s not to like?

Name: La Mandale
Description: Picture a Klein blue frontage and a trendy bistro furnished with assorted antiques and numerous knick-knacks that is packed to the seams with smiling diners. It seems that Léo Huet, like other chefs of his generation, has hit upon the recipe for success: intriguing, tangy dishes rich in fresh premium produce, such as smoked mussels, kaffir, Thai basil and pistachio or steak with Gorilla pepper, kimchi, shiso and cherries, all with contrasting flavours that surprise and titillate the tastebuds. At dinner, the food becomes distinctly high flying as diners prepare to take their time to do justice to the excellent dishes recommended and explained by Maximilien, the chef’s associate, in a pleasantly unstuffy, relaxed vibe.

Name: Hyacinthe & Robert
Description: Chef Damien Le Quillec named his restaurant after his two grandfathers. In this unusual setting – previously a garage, cleverly converted into a contemporary loft – he channels his talent into crafting ambitious dishes that appeal to the modern palate. Meanwhile, he has opened a convivial little bistro next door – Numéro 100, where he serves bistronomy fare in a home-from-home atmosphere.

Name: Le Saisonnier
Address: 56 rue de la Verrerie, Roye, 70200, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Anyone able to pull off a combination of gravlax salmon and smoked duck breast cream deserves our full attention! This is a chef with an impressive track record who, together with his wife, has brought to life this old farmhouse on the main road through the village. Expect well-crafted and carefully presented dishes, with combinations of flavours that may surprise (the salmon is a case in point). A cuisine that revisits certain classics but also encompasses dishes that are firmly rooted in the region, it draws on seasonal ingredients such as morels, emulsion of Vieux Comté cheese and vin jaune. Dine in the modern interior or on the pleasant terrace to the rear.

Name: Le Bistrot de Villedieu
Address: 21 place de la Libération, Villedieu, 84110, France
Description: Laurent Azoulay has embarked on a new culinary adventure in this village in northern Vaucluse since June 2020. The veteran owner chef, currently of the star EKrin at Méribel, whisks up provençal fare in a locally sourced bistro register. The flavoursome, flawlessly executed repertory is rich in character and some of the dishes are cooked in the wood-burning oven of the open kitchen. Meals are served in a contemporary bistro setting, or, in fine weather, on the shaded terrace on the village square.

Name: Le Margote
Description: In his restaurant overlooking the Bassin du Roi, chef Gauthier Teissere is assisted by Marguerite (his wife) front of house. He delivers contemporary, creative cuisine, jazzed up with the occasional nod to Asia. The stylish, snug interior is the perfect foil for dishes that reverently respect the seasons. Each dish is a masterpiece – not least the tender pork belly with a celeriac purée and smoked emulsion, or the generous pollack with cauliflower and capers.

Name: Les Jardins
Description: This country restaurant has put down its roots in a peaceful winegrowing village in a bend of the River Lot. The wine barn of a former winery is the venue for youthful Marius Halter to whisk up delicious modern recipes in which fine local produce features prominently, without forgoing exquisitely balanced creative touches (spices, sweet and sour blends). Concise organic wine list, friendly, smiling table service and pretty patio in the garden.

Name: Racines
Address: 1981 avenue de Trévoux, à Saint-Denis-lès-Bourg, Bourg-en-Bresse, 01000, France
Description: This family-run establishment, which has had a contemporary makeover, affords relaxing views over the surrounding grounds. Chef David Lachavannes continues to deliver tasty and coherent cuisine that makes the most of ties with local producers. The market-fresh "Menu du Marché" served on weekdays is a bargain; the weekend menus are more ambitious. A real gem.

Name: Briket' Bistrot
Description: On the heights of the picturesque village of Guéthary, the Ibarboure family hotel also operates this pleasant bistro, independent from their fine dining restaurant. The chef crafts meticulous, delicate and flavoursome food in an uncluttered setting. Basque ingredients dominate the generous dishes of the concise menu: Bayonne ham, bellota chorizo, Banka trout, Ardi-Gasna cheese. A youthful, friendly team and sensible prices. A real treat.

Name: La Table de Pablo
Address: 1713 route de Rustrel, Hameau Les Petits-Cléments, Villars, 84400, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Delicate and decidedly creative cuisine based on good regional ingredients: this restaurant surrounded by vines and cherry trees is a real find. Try the surprise menu, inspired by the offerings of the markets and small-scale local producers. The chef-patron takes care of everything himself, both in the dining room and the kitchen. Special mention for the peaceful terrace, where you can hear the cicadas' call.

Name: Arkadia
Description: In the historical centre of this village near the Ardèche Gorges, the chef, who is originally from Brittany, confidently sets about regaling diners with locally sourced ingredients (vegetables and cheeses in particular). The menu, renewed every month, is packed with indulgent and generous dishes. Front of house, Philippine's good humour sets the tone.

Name: Les Plaisirs
Description: This friendly family-run inn is tucked away in a village high in the hinterland of Nice. The young owner-chef, descended from a long line of restaurant owners, throws his heart and soul into preparing Provençal recipes using impeccably selected regional produce. Authentic flavours, fuss-free plating, enticing recipes and eater-friendly prices! What more do we need to say?

Name: Bistrot la Coulemelle
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: In the middle of the village, this is the delightful "bistro annexe" of Régis and Jacques Marcon's fine dining restaurant. The traditional pâté en croûte "Richelieu", skate wing terrine, roasted cauliflower and mushrooms, cheeses from Ardèche and Auvergne. What more can we say? This is hearty fare and devilishly good. The open kitchens lend the place an inviting feel.

Name: Auberge du Pont de la Zorn
Address: 2 rue de la République, Weyersheim, 67720, France
Description: Marquetry art from Atelier Spindler, antiques, bleached beams and rough wooden tables: the dining area displays its Alsatian heritage with pride! On the menu: tasty regional specialities, tartes flammées, but also Breton turbot with shrimp bisque and risotto venere, and delicious desserts, like this raspberry-meets-geranium from the garden. Bucolic terrace on the banks of the River Zorn, impeccable welcome and service – this place deserves its success.

Name: L'Alicanta
Address: Route de Meyrueis, Le Rozier, 48150, France
Description: L'Alicanta has been on the scene for a while, perched on the banks of the River Jonte, in the exceptional setting of the Gorges du Tarn. The chef puts in a solid performance, his cooking is replete with distinct flavours and his dishes are brilliantly assembled. Everything here is home-made and the menu changes with every season. Absolutely delicious!

Name: Le Biniou
Description: The chef draws his inspiration from deepest Brittany, illustrated by dishes such as crumbly buckwheat in butter and shallots, but is also open to other influences, as the fillet of whiting, lemon balm and watercress coulis demonstrate. Deftly crafted food, cheerful service, a digestible bill and a location just a few knots from the beach. The quintessence of Brittany.

Name: Le Patio by Lou Caléou
Address: 23 place de la Libération, Sommières, 30250, France
Description: This former wine storehouse is now the restaurant of Guillaume Dercourt and Amandine Sabot, chef and pastry chef respectively. The cooking is resolutely modern in its form and draws playfully on the traditional French repertoire: chicken liver royale with port, creamy corn and red pepper gel; duo of pork with filet mignon cooked at low temperature and shoulder confit. Round off your meal with the nicely crunchy tartlet with black sesame, yuzu and vanilla bavaroise. You're sure to fall hook, line and sinker for this place – not least the gorgeous patio cobbled with old stone and featuring an olive tree!

Name: La Table de Léo
Address: 13 rue de l'Abbaye (Le Bourg), Saint-Avit-Sénieur, 24440, France
Description: This stone - built house in the heart of the village has a pretty terrace overlooking the church square. Inside, you will discover a great little restaurant with a chef who dares to branch out from the usual regional fare. He pays special attention to his ingredients and how best to present and cook them.

Name: L'Hibiscus
Description: In a bustling pedestrian street, the façade is discreet. Venture inside for fresh ingredients, original recipes and modern cuisine, courtesy of Céline Lefebvre, a chef with a proven track record. No à la carte, but a short set menu changing regularly abreast of the seasons and availability. Reasonable prices.

Name: Vidal
Description: In this restaurant opened in 1984, the Vidal family serve a delicious repertoire that is an intelligent take on tradition: tasty dishes that highlight a series of small local producers (noire du Velay lamb, fin gras du Mézenc beef, market gardeners...). Aurélien's pâté en croûte is a fine technical feat and deserves a special mention.

Name: La Belle Étoile
Address: 285 promenade de la Batellerie (Le Bourg), La Roque-Gageac, 24250, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: At this residence overlooking the Dordogne, wonderful surprises await you. The delicious food showcases the best of local produce and is an absolute delight. There are pretty guestrooms, should you wish to extend your stay in this pretty village.

Name: Akashon
Address: L'Heliopic, 50 place de l'Aiguille-du-Midi, Chamonix-Mont-Blanc, 74400, France
Description: Part of L’Heliopic hotel resort, Akashon turns out hearty, flavoursome food poised between local gastronomy and more modern fare, such as a tonnato-style tartare of veal and lobster. Untreated metal and granite set the scene in the minimalist interior, the terrace of which commands a fantastic view of the mountains.

Name: Le Nid
Description: An establishment run by charming people: Emilie takes care of the customer's every need, while the chef rustles up seasonal cuisine, full of freshness and flavour, making the most of short food supply chains and local producers. A gourmet hideaway that fills up every day and offers excellent value and maximum dining pleasure.

Name: Le Bistro des Glycines
Address: 4 avenue de Laugerie, Les Eyzies-de-Tayac-Sireuil, 24620, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: One of the undeniable bonuses of this hotel is its excellent bistro! The dining room-conservatory serves (lunchtime only) sensibly priced menus in tune with the zeitgeist, such as gravlax of Eyzies trout with a smoked cream cheese sauce or shoulder of lamb, confit and smoked in a casserole dish. Flavour, generosity and respect for the seasons set the tone for chef Pascal Lombard’s creative and enticing culinary score – we’ll be back for more!

Name: Ô en Couleur
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: In the colourful, contemporary interior with its large glass façade, or on the terrace in the leafy garden, tuck into the chef's well-crafted dishes concocted with the finest ingredients. Gribiche-style head cheese, pan-fried beef and crumbled offal, small pot of cream and a madeleine… Appealing to the palate, it's also easy on the wallet. Comfortable and colourful guestrooms are available, should you wish to prolong your stay.

Name: La Gazette
Description: Inside this small half - timbered building, the trendy decor harmoniously blends refinement with the charm of timeworn beams. As for the seasonal cuisine, it showcases the finest ingredients. A memorable experience!

Name: La Chaumière
Description: Put your skis away! You won't be able to resist this lovely thatched cottage at the entrance to the resort with an interior where wood predominates. On the menu find a fine selection of Catalan dishes, delicious tapas and good regional wines. The proprietor likes the finer things in life (choice meats, locally grown vegetables) and has even set up a ham cellar!

Name: Le Saint-Georges
Description: In his restaurant, just a roll of the dice from the casino, Paul Courtaux doesn’t gamble with our appetites. He crafts vibrant, flavoursome cuisine, which cleverly shines the spotlight on regional produce, illustrated by frothy cold fish soup with an aïoli of cuttlefish and mussels, or a slice of Ségala veal simmered in lemon, basil, aubergines, tomatoes and parmesan… The splendid regional wine list deserves special mention, as does the charismatic welcome.

Name: Vigne en Foule
Address: 80 place de la Libération, Gaillac, 81600, France
Description: A pleasant bar-restaurant serving fine bistro cuisine with a twist, together with a handful of meat dishes designed to share (including suckling pig, veal chop). Tuck into modern and indulgent dishes, such as cod with a fish suquet jus and patatas fritas with rouille – from spring onwards, you can dine on the appealing terrace. The wine cellar boasts a head-spinning selection of almost 300 different wines!

Name: L'Agape
Description: Julien Gleize set up his restaurant on this pleasant square in the heart of the Cité des Papes in June 2014. The chef looks totally fulfilled as he works away in the kitchens, composing hearty, cleverly devised dishes, in which seasonal products are nicely showcased.

Name: Avenio
Description: At this contemporary city-centre restaurant run by a young couple who have stints at high-end establishments under their belts, a warm welcome awaits you. Avenio's well-deserved success is also down to carefully sourced ingredients that go into recipes in tune with the zeitgeist: truffle risotto; bonito fillet, creamy cauliflower and chimichurri sauce; iced Mont Blanc, meringue and blueberry coulis. It is advisable to book ahead!

Name: Café Brochier
Address: 4 place de la Fontaine, Saint-Julien-en-Vercors, 26420, France
Description: This handsome building is an institution in this Vercors village. Dating from 1867 and recently taken over by a youthful enthusiastic couple, it is home to a historical cafe adorned with frescoes dating back to 1912. Locally sourced ingredients play the lead roles on the menu, which changes regularly. Respect for the seasons goes hand in hand with respect for the produce, culinary skill and flavour. Three rooms upstairs.

Name: Le P'tit Goustan
Description: The chef at Le P'tit Goustan takes pride in sourcing his ingredients locally, whether fish or meat, fruit or vegetables, before putting together a feast of tuna tartare, tarragon pesto, cucumber with fresh goat's cheese, manioc chips, cucumber sorbet and gazpacho; roast pollack with turmeric and saffron, panisse, mussels two ways; strawberry tartare... The best of Brittany inspires him to create original, masterful dishes, to be enjoyed in one of the two cosy, contemporary dining spaces. The terrace of this charming establishment has a view of the small port.

Name: Les Maisons Du'O - Le Bistro Panoramique
Description: Locally grown tomatoes and fruit, Ventoux spelt and pork: the chef hits the spot every time courtesy of modern recipes rich in Provençal accents, like baked croaker paired with fennel in aioli and a foamy bisque or a cassolette of gambas and squid. Excellent value for money and a knock-out view of the Ouvèze from the spacious contemporary dining room.

Name: Cartouches
Description: In the picturesque and lively neighbourhood of Saint-Aubin, this tiny bistro is always busy! Chef Nicolas Brousse and his wife take great pleasure in serving up tasty, carefully prepared dishes. And in keeping with this spirit of conviviality, why not share a fine steak (butcher's choice – for two people)? This goes down very well with a natural wine from the extensive selection. The set menu changes every week.

Name: Le Temps d'Aime
Description: In the modern neighbourhood of Port Ariane, this family restaurant (father and son work in tandem) is certainly a good bet. Whether you opt to eat on the terrace or inside the contemporary restaurant, the cuisine is all about fresh seasonal ingredients, most from short food supply chains, and cooked market fresh for optimal flavour. The bill is very reasonable.

Name: Bistrot d'Antoine
Address: 27 rue de la Préfecture, Nice, 06300, France
Description: The lilting accent of the South of France can be detected in this bistro, where a really convivial atmosphere reigns. Things hot up in the kitchen, with dishes such as old-fashioned pork casserole or knife-cut beef tartare – only the best makes the cut here. Crowded? Well, yes: Antoine has a huge (and well-deserved) success on his hands.

Name: Le Bistrot d'Antoine
Address: 3 rue de la Courtine, Strasbourg, 67000, France
Description: Near Place St-Étienne and the rue des Frères, this bistro has cracked the formula for success: seasonal produce, generous dishes from the traditional repertoire (snails in garlic butter, chicken casserole with morels, cream and vin jaune), a friendly atmosphere, a natural and organic wine list... and good value for money.

Name: L'Atelier L'Art des Mets
Description: The chef proposes neoteric, distinctive cuisine, whose mainstay is wild herbs, which he learned to know through a local herb picker. Goosefoot, wild lemon balm, purslane, mugwort... The culinary score is poetic and rich in flavour, illustrated by Ventoux pork with helichrysum-flavoured poichichade. Consider us smitten!

Name: La Ferme de la Haute Crémonville
Description: To see verdant Normandy again, to admire the horses of the neighbouring stud farm, to dream of the pastoral life: this authentic half-timbered farmhouse is so pretty that it makes the most intractable city-dweller want to retire to the countryside. In these parts you will come across calves, cows, pigs and… traditional delicacies: cep ravioli with chanterelle cream, crunchy vanilla millefeuille; not forgetting the steaks cooked over a wood fire. You have barely put down your knife and fork before you are planning to return to these lovely dishes and bucolic setting.

Name: Le Grand Saint-Benoît
Description: This warm traditional restaurant boasts a pretty terrace and a spruce interior in the heart of the village, where the poet Max Jacob is buried. An enticing menu of deftly crafted dishes depicted by subtle blends of flavours, such as a quail and foie gras terrine with red onion preserve. This appetising score is the work of a veteran chef for whom French cuisine has no secrets.

Name: Le Bistrot du 11
Description: You guessed it: the team behind La Table du 11 also runs this bistro located in a touristy pedestrian-only street not far from the palace. Fine produce makes up the menu-carte: baked egg, salad and coconut; beef, potato and garlic; Paris-Brest pastry with pecans.

Name: Le Comptoir Breizh Café
Description: Breizh Café is the result of a stroke of genius: the idea of mixing Breton traditions with the Japanese flair for presentation. Inviting modern decor with a counter facing the open kitchen, as in Japan. Local ingredients (100% organic buckwheat, oysters from Cancale, butter from Bordier) and a few contemporary touches, such as buckwheat pancakes rolled up like maki. Good choice of ciders.

Name: Auberge des Deux Magots
Address: 1 place du Bouffay, La Roche-Bernard, 56130, France
Description: All the charm of an old Breton house in a pretty little town full of character. The refined and creative cuisine showcases seasonal regional produce. At lunchtime, there's a mouth-watering market-inspired set menu that represents remarkable value for money. The line-caught pollack served with buckwheat risotto with squid ink is on point! Even better, the chef bakes the bread himself.

Name: Le Carré de l'Ange
Address: chemin du Parc (Palais des Évêques), Saint-Lizier, 09190, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Paul Fontvieille presides over the kitchens here with the same enthusiasm and infectious good mood as ever. This passionate chef composes delicious and savvy dishes ranging from the creative, such as artisanal soba noodles made with buckwheat from Ariège in a fresh herb broth, to the more traditional, eg comforting veal axoa. Bag a table on the terrace, which boasts a breathtaking view over the verdant valley… you'll be in seventh heaven!

Name: Au Relais des Ménétriers
Description: The time is long gone when ménétriers or itinerant fiddlers went from inn to inn but hospitality is still the rule at this Relais, as is good food! The chef concocts true traditional French cuisine and buys his vegetables from local farmers. You can't argue with the results, which are generous and tasty.

Name: L'Oustalet Maïanen
Description: This discreet and pleasant restaurant is located opposite the former home of Frédéric Mistral. Enjoy the tasty Provençal cuisine under the Virginia creeper arbour.

Name: Le Saint Joseph
Address: 100 boulevard de la République, La Garenne-Colombes, 92250, France
Description: This local bistro serves wholesome, updated, tasty fare, in the shape of a menu devised by chef Bordier, whose illustrious career speaks for itself. Diners dig into good food in a friendly relaxed venue, washed down with a selection from the concise wine list, which showcases wine - producing women.

Name: Au Lion d'Or - Chez Théo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: A pleasant and elegant inn, run by the same family since 1928. The chef brilliantly weaves flavours of today into the wealth of local specialities, without excluding the specialities of other parts of France! The selection of wines by the glass is short but well put together. Make the most of the beautiful terrace in summer.

Name: Le Kitchen
Description: In the student district of the Louis Lumière and Jean Moulin Universities, this Kitchen is thriving. The interior, a delightful blend of Art deco and Scandinavian (as is the owner), holds only eight small square tables. The pastry display case (to eat in or take away), the work of the owner’s pastry chef companion, sets our tastebuds drooling and the kitchen is open for breakfast and teatime, as well as lunch (but is closed in the evenings). Organic local produce, vegetables mainly, take pride of place on the table.

Name: Sauf Imprévu
Description: Félix Gagnaire, a pastry chef by training and son of multi-starred Pierre Gagnaire, whose international renown needs no introduction, deserves our respect for this restaurant (open mainly at lunchtime) in the Brotteaux district. Wholesome food founded on pedigree French traditions: warm pâté en croûte; thyme-flavoured roast veal, mashed sweet potatoes with chorizo; rum and citrus fruit baba. The regulars joyfully dig into high-flying, yet heartwarming dishes oozing with respect for the region. Everything is fresh and entirely made from scratch. What’s not to like?

Name: Le Tiroir
Address: 20 Grande Rue de Vaise, Lyon, 69009, France
Description: This establishment in the working-class district of Vaise, appointed in a characteristic trendy bistro vibe, is irresistibly endearing! The work of a youthful team, the food slaloms between iced tomato soup served with a mousse of white balsamic vinegar and a more patriotic Gallic line-up (tartare of beef, foie gras) – the menus and carte are regularly renewed. Excellent value for money and pleasure, including in the evenings.

Name: So
Description: After notching up experience in some fine establishments, Japanese chef So Takahashi works alone in the kitchen, and his partner, Rie, is front of house. He uses ingredients that are bought directly at the market to concoct French cuisine interspersed with Japanese inspiration. The result is finely executed, light and flavoursome. So good!

Name: Ahizpak
Description: In the upper reaches of the beach of Erretegia, this former haunt of the Arangoits sisters (‘ahizpak’ in Basque) is idyllically located opposite the ocean. Delphine, now alone at the helm, and her chef David Cerisier have devised a concise, modern and eater-friendly priced menu that keeps step with the seasons. Generous, enticing food, served on the terrace in fine weather, examples of which are a chilled cream of green peas, carrot and lime oil; hanger steak, gratin of potatoes, coppa and comté and a decadent crêpe soufflée in orange and Grand Marnier to finish.

Name: Auberge du Pont
Description: The cuisine is meticulous, tasty and flavoursome, with sauces to die for… Enjoy crispy shoulder of lamb with red onion and Taggiasca olives, or opt for more surprising original dishes such as gravlax beef glazed with rice vinegar. When the weather is fine, make the most of the shady terrace overlooking the Allier River. At lunchtime, they serve a single set menu – the menu du marché – and amenu-carte in the evening. Not to be missed!

Name: DZ'envies
Description: You can trust the chef’s culinary hankering or ‘envies’!
