In a hip canteen vibe (white walls, light wooden furniture and black ceiling), next-door to the market, David Zuddas unveils his love of cooking and premium produce. The menu stars a line-up of traditional Burgundy classics, flanked by a few enticing seasonal delicacies. The lunchtime menu is a steal, while in the evening you can choose from 3, 4 or 5 courses.

Name: L'Auberge
Description: Not far from Hazebrouck, this Auberge was once a tannery then a tavern true to the traditions of France's northern regions. Now it is a restaurant with a friendly atmosphere showcasing seasonal produce and Flemish roots in reinterpretations of classic local fare (welsh, carbonade). Chef Antonin, who is also a wine enthusiast, pulls off surprising combinations such as snails, haddock and spinach, too!

Name: L'Embellie
Address: 245 route de Pont-sur-Grosne (Le Bourg), Sainte-Cécile, 71250, France
Description: A former stable whose rustic cachet is enhanced by beams, a fireplace and exposed brick walls. In the kitchen, the chef often draws inspiration from his travels, but always returns to certain classics, such as duck foie gras terrine or sautéed veal sweetbreads. The porchetta-style stuffed Burgundy rabbit and cromesquis made an impression. Have a home-made ice cream on the pleasant summer terrace, which only adds to the charm of this place.

Name: Racines
Description: A stone’s throw from the marina of Étaples and only 5km from Le Touquet, this new restaurant is focused on succulent wholesome fare made with carefully sourced local produce. The recipes of chef Pierre Chavatte hit the spot every time. The interior sports a contemporary vibe with semi-open kitchens and hanging light fixtures surrounded by roots, a passing nod to the restaurant’s name. Highly recommended!

Name: Cave à Vin & à Manger - Maison Saint-Crescent
Address: Rond-point de la Liberté, 68 avenue du Général-Leclerc, Narbonne, 11100, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: La Cave à Manger by Lionel Giraud proposes bistro cuisine made with top-notch ingredients from Occitanie. The food is rugged, flavoursome and spot-on – special mention for the chuck beef slowly simmered in its juices and the velvety purée of carrots. La Cave à Vin, located under the same roof, boasts 2,500 wines; pick a bottle to drink with your meal for a corkage fee. A real winner.

Name: Racine
Description: "The name refers to not just one racine (""root""), but several: the chef's Burgundian roots, a great source of pride for him; the origins of the ingredients he uses (90% of which are produced within a 100km radius). His tasty and well - balanced dishes do the rest. Small delicatessen and wine bar on Thursdays and Fridays. "

Name: Le Cottage
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The restaurant at Le Cottage is the latest venture of Philippe Girardon, a chef whose passion and experience are beyond dispute. He creates bistro - style fare using lovely fresh ingredients. Savour these in the large dining area or outside on the terrace in the shade of the plane trees.

Name: Le Bac à Traille
Description: Masashi Ljichi, Japanese-born star chef of La Cachette, has made his dream come true in this wholehearted, flavoursome bistro, whose name pays homage to a former shuttle (bac) that used to cross the Rhône by way of a cable (traille). In addition to a high-flying gastronomic score, the chef crafts bistronomic dishes rich in big-boned flavours that are bang on every time. The market-fresh cuisine is impeccably curated, always punchy and heroically tasty, illustrated by poultry terrine, veggie pickles and lentil salad or lacquered pork belly in Timut pepper with fluffy mashed potatoes. We recommend the coconut pineapple and rum soup with tapioca and a velvety pineapple sorbet to finish. Fine selection of regional vintages. Knockout value for money.

Name: L'Aillet
Description: The chef may profess a simple, local approach to cooking, but his food finds its place among its trendy bistro peers on account of its definitively contemporary look. A starter of cauliflower, herring, tarragon and peanuts boasts a pared-back presentation and well-balanced flavours. The chef is also a past master in the art of tradition and roasting joints, a skill set we can only applaud! A welcome addition to the Arcachon Bay culinary scene.

Name: L'Air de Famille
Description: L'Air de Famille makes for an appealing place to eat with its period decor (vintage advertising posters, original counter) and unpretentious atmosphere. Tradition and the seasons dictate the menu here, with particular attention paid to flavour combinations and sauces. Calf's head with ravigote sauce and other classics regularly feature… and they boast a well-stocked wine list!

Name: Le Rabelais
Description: Housed in the pretty 17C vaulted room of an old wheat mill, this restaurant would have gone down well with Rabelais's insatiable Gargantua! Enjoy the tasty seasonal dishes that are meticulously prepared (the menu changes several times a week). This place is located in the immediate vicinity of Saint-Chamas's Poudrerie – the black powder mill founded in 1690. History, literature, good food: what more could you ask for?

Name: Le Colvert
Description: Stylish, delicious and tasteful depict this good food venue which sources the vast majority of its produce from local growers and breeders. In the heart of the peaceful Lauragais countryside, this welcoming house with a lovely terrace serves good food at bargain prices: vegetable and parmesan panacotta; beef hanger steak with a confit of garlic jus; apples in honey, white chocolate ganache and a drizzle of black tea sauce. All of which washed down with a fine selection of Gaillac and Languedoc wines.

Name: Chez Yvonne - S'Burjerstuewel
Description: A buzzy vibe and closely packed tables set the scene in this winstub, whose menu is the epitome of Alsace tradition (cockerel in Riesling, garnished sauerkraut, braised knuckle), albeit with a few more creative dishes, such as their delicate Alsace makis. Don’t miss the chance to sample one of the house specialties: melt-in-the-mouth pork cheeks slowly braised and simmered in a velvety pinot noir sauce – to die for!

Name: Les Petits Princes
Description: This inviting restaurant on a corner plot is located close to the tram line. Inside, a partition window provides a glimpse into the kitchen. The menu features up-to-the-minute, appetising and always intriguing dishes, such as roasted magret de canard, vinegar jus, beetroot and hazelnuts, or rice pudding with caramel and puffed rice – incredibly indulgent with its vanilla whipped cream and generous layer of caramel deglazed with semi-salted butter. Verdant courtyard terrace to the rear.

Name: Saku Restaurant
Description: Saku is the nickname of the chef of this establishment tucked away behind a nondescript façade. He and his wife, both of whom are Japanese, prepare jubilant Gallic cuisine in keeping with today’s tastebuds. The produce is fresh, the dishes are meticulously prepared, at common-sense prices, and the service is friendly; an enjoyable experience.

Name: Le Zeste Gourmand
Description: Benjamin Bouvard earned his stripes at Bocuse and La Pyramide before opening this establishment. Expect a minimalist interior that is in tune with the zeitgeist, and food to match. The top-notch produce is well crafted to create variations in texture in dishes such as beef cheek confit cromesqui with a reduced jus, creamy parsley root and pickles. The Dombes chicken with a Thai marinade is a creative and artfully plated dish. Finally, when it comes to dessert, the chocolate and pine feuille-à-feuille pastry shows a mastery of ingredients and a desire to deliver meticulous presentations. Front of house, the service is well-paced and cordial.

Name: La Clé des Champs
Description: This establishment is run by a professional young couple who go to great lengths to keep their guests happy. The fruit of their labours: modern and well-executed cuisine that puts ingredients from the local terroir in the spotlight, as in their tender and tasty haddock sausage accompanied by Picardy mushrooms, or their stuffed farm-reared guinea fowl, apple and onion, chicory jus.

Name: M Restaurant
Description: A cocktail of vitamins! Julien Gautier’s cheerful establishment adds a whiff of exuberance to Lyon’s well-heeled, tree-lined Avenue Foch. The smart interior sports a muted blue and flashy orange colour scheme, felt grey designer armchairs, linen tablecloths, a bar and a wine cellar encircled by a conservatory… The similarly charismatic service is as smooth as a silky béarnaise sauce. In the kitchen, the veteran and talented chef, formerly of Léon of Lyon, rustles up an appetising, market-sourced menu, combining flawless technique and know-how in a bid to pamper our tastebuds with delicate flavours tailored to modern appetites. The honey-flavoured madeleines served with a fromage blanc sorbet are awesome!

Name: L'Amandier
Description: Avocado and shrimp tartare with a dash of sherry; shoulder of lamb confit, rosemary and tomato juice; vanilla rice pudding… The endearing couple’s delicious recipes are rich in Provençal accents. A good meal every time at reasonable prices!

Name: La Table d'Hôtes
Description: Not far from the seaside resort, this family restaurant is the stomping ground of a couple who have experience working in some fine establishments. Yoann Lavalley has bought the stove which he used during his apprenticeship and uses it to create seasonal cuisine that is both flavourful and indulgent. The sommelier, his wife, has curated a nice wine list that represents excellent value for money. Fish of the day, local meat, Normandy cheeses… A pleasant place.

Name: L'Auberge des Montagnes
Description: This farmstead in the heart of a remote picturesque village (ideal for walks in the country) is the HQ of a chef who competently and carefully crafts traditional recipes. Save room for the cheese board and Salers cheese, produced just a few yards away.

Name: Le Montcenis
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Both the decor (vaulted cellar, exposed stone and beams) and the food are full of character. Laurent Dufour draws on fine produce to create generous and authentic dishes, such as guinea fowl breast with spinach leaves and carrots, and green cabbage cannelloni with smoked bacon. The menu changes regularly and, in winter, features truffles, of which the chef is a big fan! A cordial welcome.

Name: Restaurant du Dauphin
Description: In the old town, at the foot of the Porte St Julien, this restaurant in a pretty 16C building serves cuisine for the modern palate. The chefs incorporate a smattering of exotic touches, but always have a handful of classics up their sleeve. The chicken supreme with quince, accompanied by mashed potatoes with walnuts and an amaretto-infused carcass jus is a good example. As for dessert, it is a pleasure to find a vacherin, a rum baba or a moelleux – always a failsafe option! Fine selection of wines by the glass.

Name: La Guinguette du 1er Mets
Description: A revolution is afoot after 20 years of loyal service! Chef Nicolas Mouroux and his wife have daringly adopted an all-out traditional guinguette vibe with colourful chairs, wooden cable drums as tables and pretty bistro lights. In the same vein, some twenty or so deftly crafted tapas at prices that make sense are ordered one after the other during the meal. Each one is a masterclass of quality and care, illustrated by distinct flavours and sharp presentation. Examples include pig’s trotter in breadcrumbs, gribiche sauce and crumbled purple cauliflower; gravlax salmon, dill, citrus fruits; lamb kebab served in soft brioche bread. Cheerful service, great music and a deliciously nostalgic ambience.

Name: Au Colombier
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: By the River Saône, a fine 18C building that feels like a cross between a hip guinguette and a country house. The food is resolutely contemporary: carpaccio of gilt - head bream with lemongrass, saddle of rabbit stuffed with wild basil... without neglecting the classics, such as the wonderful pan - fried frogs' legs. Good taste and character.

Name: Le Bistronôme
Description: Small in size, big in quality! In an exquisite location on the banks of the River Cuisance, Lisa and Jérôme have made their establishment a firm fixture of Arbois’ culinary scene. The chef’s seasonal recipes, emblematic of his technique and flair, are a festival of mouth-watering delicacies from his signature dish, Planches trout stuffed with morel and oyster mushrooms, vin jaune sauce to farm-reared Jura pork chop, pepper and tonka bean meat gravy and dauphine potatoes. The desserts are to die for! Their “au fil du jour” daily special is a steal and the service is refreshingly unstarched and friendly: remember to book!

Name: Les Coloquintes
Description: This restaurant installed in a former silk - throwing factory is run by a young couple – he in the kitchen, she front of house. They propose contemporary cuisine, aiming to keep supply channels short and respecting local produce, trout, chestnuts, fruits etc. In summer, get a table in the shade of the lime trees.

Name: L'Aubépine
Description: L’Aubépine is flourishing in the hands of a youthful researcher, now on a quest for flavour. Chef Manuel is a staunch advocate of locally sourced produce, whose ingredients he seeks to exalt, respecting both their texture and nutritional value. Everything is made in house and the menu changes weekly depending on the market.

Name: Le Rendez-vous des Gourmets
Description: Since he opened this splendid country restaurant, Didier Doreau has turned it into a genuine gourmet stronghold. Terrine of pike à la Chambord, pâté of game served warm drizzled in jus, traditional calf’s head, Grand Marnier-flavoured baked citrus fruits… You can expect a pageant of traditional Gallic staples, made with fresh, crisp produce, crafted into dishes that exalt and respect the intrinsic flavour of each ingredient. The chef is renowned for his way with game in season (hare, venison, wild boar, etc.), which further adds to the well-deserved success of what has become a culinary benchmark in the region.

Name: Le Gantxo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Welcome to the Basque country! Le Gantxo – named after a pass in pelota – gives directly onto the trinquet, the ground where the famous local sport is played. In the kitchen, Isabelle and Laurent Miremont revisit Basque cuisine in a very personal way, composing dishes that are up to the minute, often copious, always tasty. A firm favourite!

Name: Coteaux et Fourchettes
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This cleverly named restaurant (a pun on côteaux meaning hills and couteaux meaning knives) is housed in an old wine cellar. The region is well represented both by the delicious cuisine and by the excellent choice of local wines. Pleasant, contemporary decor and a terrace overlooking the vineyards.

Name: Maison Joanto
Description: Joanto means "Little John" in Basque, but there is nothing diminutive about this place! Its fine traditional architecture and convivial ambience are more than worthy of applause, as is the generous cooking of its head chef, who has worked in some top establishments. This is meticulous and indulgent cuisine, with an explosion of Basque Country flavours: pâté en croûte, milk-fed Pyrenean lamb, Armagnac baba. Fantastic value for money.

Name: Le 6 à Table
Description: In a peaceful village, this small square basking in the shade of the church is the quintessence of rural France. The chef uses local ingredients whenever possible: trout, strawberries, figs, cheese, vegetables… Seasonal food served on the terrace or in a pleasant conservatory-cum-workshop interior.

Name: L'Ô à la Bouche
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: At the head of this pleasant restaurant is a foodie couple who travelled to faraway lands and seas before dropping anchor in Cahors. Jean - François concocts gourmet dishes such as: salmon marinated in fennel or wild seabass, pan - fried chard and Lautrec pink garlic cromesquis. Enough to make your mouth water!

Name: Racines
Description: The roots of this bistro go back to the family history of the proprietors, a young couple: on one side of the family, a butcher's shop specialising in choice meats (especially milk-fed veal from the Limousin) and on the other, chickens and orchards. The chef, former second in command at L'Esquisse, knows all about good produce, as his dishes show: slow-cooked egg, crozets pasta, brezain cheese; onglet de veau (veal steak), polenta, grilled leek, garlic condiment.

Name: Veronatuti
Description: Start with a salad of fennel and orange segments of Sicilian inspiration, followed by a main course from Emilia-Romagna (stracotto of braised beef in red wine, carrots and onions) and a dessert of Lombardy and Piedmont heritage (homemade ice cream made from toasted corn flour (farina bòna) served with a crumble of sbrisolona and a wafer-thin layer of chocolate). The duo who runs this authentic trattoria embarks diners on a whirlwind gourmet tour of Italy. Everything is made from scratch - even the coffee comes from a local artisan roaster. Delicious food without killer prices.

Name: Le Bel'Art
Description: In a modern building on the higher ground outside Périgueux, Sandrine and Vincent Cardoso's restaurant has a functional dining space. The food represents a complete change of tack, with a different menu on offer every week. Served with good jus, first-rate local ingredients are accompanied by seasonal vegetables that demonstrate the chef's indisputable expertise. Everything is cooked precisely and from the heart. The brandade of salmon with sweet wine, the chicken supreme in a ramekin with bay leaves and farm spinach, or the diced Golden Delicious apple on a buttery sablé reflect the care lavished on each plate. This place is a pleasant surprise, with its enticing set menu at lunchtime served by a friendly, smiling owner.

Name: La Table de Nernier
Description: In a medieval village on the banks of Lake Geneva, between Yvoire and Messery, you are invited to cross the threshold of this charming inn. Inside, rustic (terracotta tiles, beams) and contemporary features (pendant lights, designer chairs) are a match made in heaven. The chef's cuisine is seasonal, simple and tasty, by virtue of impeccable technical skill, as in the excellent porcini in parsley or the roasted zander with a meurette sauce. Menu updated on a monthly basis. Smiling and attentive service courtesy of the maître d' (the chef's partner). Pleasant terrace on a charming little square.

Name: Meraki
Description: In Greek, Meraki means made with love, passion and creativity, which perfectly echoes the ethos of this warm, friendly bistro. Maxime Bocquier in the kitchen and Clément Richard in the front of house (even if he also trained as a chef) have chosen to focus on vegetables and seafood. All their produce is organic and local, including the burrata cheese from a local dairy. The single set menu changes monthly. Examples: stock of grey shrimp poured over barbecued cucumber and smoked eel, which explodes as your tastebuds are titillated by exciting, unexpected flavours. Mainly organic, sometimes natural Loire wines play the leading roles, without forgetting guest star appearances from other wine-growing regions.

Name: La Chaumière de Pomper
Address: Le Moulin de Pomper, 14 hameau de Kerhervé, Baden, 56870, France
Description: Well - known in the region, this pancake house rustles up crêpes made from 90% organic buckwheat flour and 10% wheat flour, resulting in a mixture so light and airy the crêpes are even crispier than the norm. In fact, it even has a name in Breton kraz! If you can’t make your choice, we suggest sticking to the classics! Impressive list of ciders.

Name: Manoir de la Pommeraie
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Not far from Vire is this 18C building that may look rustic at first glance, but turns out to be fine... Running the kitchens is a pair of chefs (also a couple): Masako, a Japanese pastry chef, and Julien, like her, trained in several renowned establishments. A good place, for both savoury and sweets!

Name: Vivace
Description: This bright restaurant with wooden floors and pale wood tables and chairs is proving to be a hit. Baptiste and Laura are committed to mindful cuisine that draws on the riches of nature: a grain-based course of creamy spelt, butternut squash, spicy peanuts, lemongrass; a fish course of pollack, roast vegetables, fish bone and tomato jus, hazelnut butter, herbs with aniseed. Vegetables, herbs and spices are precisely balanced in the dishes, and occasionally a fiery touch is thrown in to awaken the taste buds right on cue. All the ingredients are local and used in their entirety.

Name: La Chebaudière
Description: A cosy and newly refurbished interior – wooden floorboards, green and white walls with a few wooden crates affixed to them, modern tables, brown leather chairs – is the showcase for the talents of the chef-patron. His affordable market-fresh cuisine is sure to tantalise the taste buds, thanks to impeccably fresh ingredients teamed with precise cooking and distinct flavours: just-grilled mackerel, aubergine and green olives; catch of the day, mussel cream and artichoke satay.

Name: Chez Loustic
Description: In one of the busiest parts of the Saint-Cyprien neighbourhood, this modern bistro has an industrial feel (aluminium piping, white brick walls, minimalist lighting) that makes for a convivial atmosphere! The pleasant terrace overlooking the square is a bonus. Trained by Christian Constant, the chef won us over with his generous fillet of sea bream on braised leeks, spinach cream and parsnip chips, and his poached peach and rhubarb with cardamom cream. Finely prepared market-fresh cuisine, even sensitive, and very healthily composed.

Name: La Table de Mee
Description: In a stripped-back interior dominated by wood (where you can sit at the counter to watch the chef at work at his large plancha), this Korean restaurant celebrates the country's specialities. Spicy flavours and sauces are the order of the day, courtesy of the obligatory kimchi, Korean fried chicken ("KFC") and delicious ssams. The mackerel fillets simmered in a soya, chilli and white radish broth is a standout dish. The total capacity is 24 diners: booking strongly recommended!

Name: Baca'v - Boulogne
Description: Chef Émile Cotte has opened a sister restaurant of his Parisian establishment. In a modern bistro setting illuminated by large picture windows (and divided into several areas, including a table d'hôte), the chef serves up the cuisine he loves: generous bistro classics with a modern twist and a focus on simplicity and indulgence, cf. his gridouille (andouille de Vire with a piece of lean pork belly) served with oh-so-buttery mashed potatoes. Dishes often pay tribute to Limousin, birthplace of the chef. His tempting menu includes pâté en croûte, vol-au-vent, sweetbreads, millefeuille and chocolate soufflé.

Name: La Petite Verrière
Address: 16 avenue de la Bourgade, Le Puy-Sainte-Réparade, 13610, France
Description: Seating around 30 diners, this gorgeous spot with huge windows set in green metal frames is not as small as its name suggests. A couple who are industry professionals prepare delicious, generous cuisine inspired by and made with fresh, market-sourced ingredients (including bread from the village baker). Think dishes such as arborio risotto with squash; roast duck with spices, figs and seasonal mushrooms, apple and banana tarte Tatin. The menu changes every week. Good-value lunch deal.

Name: Bibendum
Description: Previously a cloister, this fine historical building is full of character. It now houses a restaurant, wine bar and cocktail bar, plus tables laid out in the inner courtyard – bliss on those balmy summer evenings. Mathieu Desmarest, chef of MICHELIN-starred restaurant Pollen, devises the menu; his wife Émilie, meanwhile, takes care of the music at this friendly, party-loving venue. As for the food, the contemporary repertoire is prepared to order, using fresh, seasonal ingredients, with Mediterranean undertones, eg sea bream ceviche, fennel and cherries; Ardèche trout, almonds, roast white asparagus and white wine sauce.

Name: Jumo & Co
Description: In the heart of the old town of Pau, twin brothers, one a chef and the other a pastry chef, have successfully launched their family business in a modern bistro-style setting laid out over two floors, complete with a pastry counter and tea room. The menu is a real draw, and also represents great value for money. This talented pair bring a touch of magic to their apparently simple dishes, drawing on sweet and sour jus and a medley of condiments to enhance their ingenious and generous, yet always light cuisine. Think confit pork belly, barbecue jus, pickled vegetables, radishes, polenta croquette.

Name: La Chartreuse
Address: 622 route de Béol, Le Reposoir, 74950, France
Description: This village located on the road to the Alps has long benefited from the generosity of the Carthusian monks – the name of this restaurant is a nod to them. The menu features well-executed modern cuisine that makes the most of seasonal (and often local) ingredients. The ever-popular "perfect egg" is nicely paired with a tempting medley of mushrooms; the classic beef chuck is slowly cooked in Mondeuse and gentian as well as Cervelle de canut (herbed cheese spread); the choux au craquelin is served with Grenoble walnut praline, hazelnut ice cream and melted chocolate – this is food that hits the spot! Rather traditional decor; large terrace in the heart of the village.

Name: Auberge La Grange aux Loups
Description: This village inn, dripping in style, has been revamped in a modern vibe by an enthusiastic couple. The menu focuses on carefully crafted, mouth-watering dishes (pastilla of pork, wild garlic and broad bean pickles; roast king prawns, Camargue rice, chorizo and fennel; citrus fruit-flavoured rice pudding and orange sorbet). Service with a smile and a lovely patio for alfresco dining in fine weather.

Name: Julien
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Local folklore is celebrated by waiters in traditional costume and a characteristic wooden Vosges decor. In a lively, yet sophisticated atmosphere, you will be treated to tasty, copious regional preparations: sauerkraut, veal kidneys, sweetbread and bouchées à la reine. The food is as heart-warming as the rooms, the grounds and the hotel’s magnificent spa facilities.

Name: Les Épices Curiens
Address: 3b place de la Gare, Écouviez, 55600, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: When strolling around the area you could easily cross over into Belgium without realising it. But the former train station of this border village, since converted into a lovely restaurant, will encourage you to stay in France. Sample the inspired cuisine and nicely prepared dishes, all paired with good local wines. Lots of taste!

Name: Auberge Le Centre Poitou
FacilitiesAndServices: Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The same family has been honing their gift for hospitality and running this inn, formerly a post house, since 1870. Chef Mathias pours his energy into concocting gutsy food with fine produce, harnessing his immaculate technique and inspired talent to the delight of foodies. An experience to be sampled in an elegant interior, whose vintage charm is dotted with modern touches. Attentive front-of-house service by Martial, the chef’s brother. Simpler bistro score at lunchtime. A few rooms for overnight stays.

Name: Air Accueil
Description: Near the Vitry - en - Artois airfield, this vast inn used to be an officers' mess. Today it is much more than a simple canteen! The food is delicious, and all the experience of chef Franck Gilabert shines through. There are numerous nods to local specialities, and the flavours really take off!

Name: Iida-Ya
Description: Confit pork belly with ginger sauce, sushi, maki, tempura… From the soothingly pared-back and chic dining area, diners have an unhampered view of the Japanese chef as he rustles up refined dishes that bring together French and Japanese cuisine. Fine sake selection. A huge hit in Dole!

Name: Minami
Description: This tiny Japanese restaurant is crammed with regulars. The minimalist interior provides the perfect foil to well-crafted Japanese fare with the occasional foray into a traditional Gallic repertory. A few examples: sushi of foie gras, caramelised eel or jasmine-perfumed crème brûlée. A few tables are laid on the patio in fine weather.

Name: Épices et Tout
Description: This small restaurant with an unobtrusive façade will wake up your taste buds. Carefully prepared dishes, fresh produce and judiciously deployed spices. For example, salmon tartare with a duo of lentils, saddle of lamb with mushroom mousseline or spiced poached pear. An appetising menu to relish on the small terrace in summer.

Name: Bistrot du Pollet
Description: Let us make no bones about it: in this bistro, it is the sea that decides, and the dishes depend directly on the local catch. Enjoy squid, foie gras du pêcheur, sole du bistro or scallops with lentils. Quality and freshness are the order of the day, and what generosity in the preparations!

Name: Au Clair de la Vigne
Description: Run by an enthusiastic wine buff, this gourmet bistro also benefits from the culinary talent of a former chef of Christophe Bacquié. The food is authentic, generous and delicious. The regularly renewed slate menu stars a traditional bistro line-up, albeit with an updated Mediterranean tang: mint-flavoured courgette gazpacho and courgette flowers stuffed with Brousse cow’s cheese; roast Mediterranean dentex (fish) and risotto-style celeriac; pistachio-flavoured financier with strawberry soup… Located in a semi-pedestrian street just behind the waterfront, it is thankfully and peacefully off the beaten tourist track.

Name: Bistrot des Anges
Address: Rue de l'Ouest, Le Cannet, 06110, France
Description: This brasserie, run by the team from Villa Archange, sports a modern decor, a friendly vibe and set menus inspired by sunny climes! Tuck into artichokes stuffed with egg mayo, Florentine cream and basil or veal kidneys with mushrooms. For dessert, make your choice from a wickedly tempting sweets trolley filled with treats. You'll be in seventh heaven!

Name: Le Denti
Address: 25 bis avenue de Loverchy, Annecy, 74000, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: This dinky restaurant off the busy tourist track is the haunt of a couple with a passion for ‘denti’ (a Mediterranean fish). Both are talented, versatile cooks and together they craft flavoursome market cuisine with a weakness for fish and a reverence for the seasons. With only a handful of tables, bookings are snapped up fast, so book ahead!

Name: L'Alchimie
Description: Picture an infectiously buzzy neighbourhood hangout, underscored by the vibrant colour scheme of a refurbished bistro. A concise menu, succulent dishes, prices that make sense and the talent of a master chef: such is the secret of this establishment’s success, which is often fully booked. Velvety butternut, chestnut and bacon soup; tandoori-flavoured roast turkey with black rice and vegetables: high-flying culinary technique by a gourmet alchemist.

Name: En Cuisine
Description: Since undergoing a complete refurbishment following a fire, the interior of this refined restaurant displays a degree of Scandinavian flair. The dishes are all about finesse and mouth-watering flavours: eg the soft and tender skate wing accompanied by delicious home-made gnocchi flavoured with lemon and flat parsley, enhanced by a delicious sweet and sour sauce. Everything is well executed – compliments to the chef!

Name: AHPĒ
Description: In a neighbourhood at a remove from the centre, this colourful, bustling bistro with caramel-toned walls and cheerfully mismatched furniture celebrates each season (the name is made up of the first letters of the four seasons) in a light-hearted atmosphere. Chef Idir Fseil is a fan of fermentation, but also of open-fire and a la plancha cooking, and he prepares a good market cuisine: white tuna, cucumber water and orange in brine; pork belly with green chilli, raw cream and beetroot; beef tartare, fermented black radish, bottarga and grenaille potatoes. Booking is essential.

Name: Orizhon
Description: In their restaurant next to the port of Audierne, this pair certainly open up new culinary horizons. The chef is from Brazil, the floor manager hails from Finistère and together they serve up delicious, aromatic cuisine that will make you happy you came. The chef, of course, draws on the local pantry – most notably fish and seafood, to which she judiciously adds modern and exotic touches. Buckwheat pancakes taco style, pork confit, lovage; tuna tart, tomato chutney with spices; grilled octopus, beetroot, fresh goat's cheese, red wine vinaigrette. Pleasantly colourful and contemporary interior decor; terrace with a view of the port.

Name: L'Esprit Bistrot
Description: A remote village in the north of Isère, a small, non-descript bistro: you can't help but wonder what they'll be feeding you here. The answer is excellent food prepared by an enthusiastic chef with undeniable talent, who has worked in Michelin-starred restaurants (including with Gilles Goujon and Michel Kayser). The long list of local producers with whom he works makes your mouth water! For starters, fresh foie gras with walnut wine, pear compote and toasted brioche, or venison and veal pâté en croûte with vegetable pickles; for the main course, roast quasi of veal with salsify in an espuma, roasted and cut into crisps, drizzled with veal jus. Lunch during the week is excellent value for money.

Name: The Presbytere
Address: 16 rue de la Sienne, Heugueville-sur-Sienne, 50200, France
Description: In a picturesque corner of Normandy, English chef Edward Delling-Williams (formerly to be found at Le Grand Bain in Paris) fell in love with this presbytery that he has turned into a locavore gastro-pub. Untreated wood tables, hunting trophies on the wall, an imposing stone fireplace and exposed rafters set the scene. Here, hungry diners can dig into dishes such as mussels with aioli followed by a duck confit with an original and beautifully refreshing cucumber and mint salad, rounded off with a moist courgette loaf cake. The chef also owns a farm, where he grows his own fruit and vegetables.

Name: Aux Bons Enfants
Description: This family business, opened in 1935, only recently had a telephone line installed, but still accepts cash only! The fourth generation continues to craft authentic Provençal ingredients into heart-warming, hunger obliterating dishes. All the produce, fruit, veg and fish from small boats, comes direct from Forville Market just down the road. We tucked into petits farcis (stuffed vegetables), Niçois-style braised beef cheeks, homemade gnocchi and the house dessert: rum baba with vanilla cream – to die for!

Name: L'Ardoise
Description: Although we are on the left bank of the Maine, in an appealing contemporary brasserie interior, the dishes exude all the warmth of the Mediterranean – a selection of antipasti to share, or polish off yourself (e.g. hummus and panisses), followed by appetising mains (pasta with shellfish) and, last but not least, the desserts (tiramisu, pistachio and orange blossom dessert). There are also some more traditional French classics (such as home-made terrine, pâté en croûte and profiteroles). And the bill is very reasonable.

Name: Le Bourgeon
Description: A picturesque medieval village lined in colourful houses and formerly renowned for its tanners and cobblers is the setting of this burgeoning establishment! Helmed by chef Enzo Duchesne and sommelier Adrien Lavorel, Le Bourgeon nurtures a modern gourmet horticultural score whose ingredients are painstakingly sourced. Veggies take pride of place in the menu, with guest star appearances from meat and fish, in spot-on dishes steeped in aroma and flavour, illustrated by a starter that mixes raw and mashed courgette, goat’s cheese, gremolata and confit of egg yolk. Several menus are available at lunchtime and evening with a mystery menu in the evening and on Saturday lunchtime.

Name: JK Restaurant
Description: Jeanne-Louise and Kevin (J+K!) met while working for their mentor Frédéric Doucet, whose Michelin-starred restaurant is very close to their first place – in a small village in the Charolais bocage. Together, the pair create cuisine that is very much in tune with the times, with occasional nods to Italy (the chef's homeland) and in which vegetables are a common thread. The ingredients are meticulously selected: take, for example, the pollack loin fillet with spring vegetables, or the kiwi, strawberry and blackcurrant tartare. Every evening and weekend, the chefs serve a single multi-course set menu.

Name: Maison Devaux
Description: Housed in a half-timbered building that is typical of this part of France (Landes), this restaurant is the domain of Mathis Devaux. The son, grandson and nephew of chefs, you could say he was born into the profession. In a decor of terracotta floor tiles and exposed beams, the crockery and tables are designed and produced by local craftspeople. The chef concocts modern bistro cuisine, drawing on local produce (such as black Gascon pork) to concoct dishes such as tender roast pork chop with a reduced jus, celeriac mousseline and simmered prunes, or tarte sablée with white chocolate, black figs and pistachio ice cream.

Name: Aux 2 K
Description: The two K's refer to Kagy (Samantha, chef) and Kinoshita (Kimiko, pastry chef), a pair who joined forces after gaining a wealth of experience in some prestigious establishments (Violon d'Ingres, L'Ours, Atelier Joël Robuchon, Taillevent). Their abundant technical skill is clearly demonstrated in dishes that are as delicious as their names are enticing, in particular the "speciality" of roasted pigeon, smoked eel and shallot finished with a salmis sauce. A few nods to the South-West of France are a reminder of the influence of Christian Constant. A culinary feat pulled off with great care and finesse, and at lunchtime, a set menu at an unbeatable price.

Name: Siprès
Description: A pair of chefs (both called Alexis) have opened this friendly restaurant on the Place du Prado and, in a space with exposed stone and tiled walls, one is in charge of savoury, the other of sweet. A perfect partnership, right from the (delicious) starter that they create in tandem: house-made pâté en croûte, enveloped in a crispy golden pastry – courtesy of the pastry chef – with a tasty, well-seasoned stuffing made by the chef. This is followed by a kefta of pollack, chickpeas, garlic confit and harissa tomato sauce, an interesting reinterpretation of this dish, in a fragrant and cosmopolitan version. The lunch set menu, devised for those on the go, changes every week; for dinner, the menu-carte is more ambitious and evolves with the seasons and the market stalls.

Name: Bistrot Lucien
Address: La Rôtisserie du Chambertin, 6 rue du Chambertin, Gevrey-Chambertin, 21220, France
Description: Bare stone walls, bench seating and a superb wooden counter set the scene in this bistro, which is housed in its parent hotel. Expertly crafted burgundy recipes take pride of place on the nostalgic menu: home-cured ham, poached egg in wine, Bresse poultry, profiteroles... Fantastic wine list!

Name: Grain de Sel
Description: It's all change at the Grain de Sel, with new premises in a vast 19C building that has had a complete makeover and a menu that showcases a passion for local and artisanal ingredients and fresh seasonal produce. The light-filled interior has an open kitchen and several contemporary areas done out in pale tones; there is also a terrace. Chef Aurélien Moutarlier, who was Romuald Fassenet's sous-chef at Château du Mont Joly, always delivers meticulous, colourful dishes that are cooked to perfection, such as his orange and coriander duck, butternut squash and polenta… He is a dab hand at seasoning, too.

Name: Le Gibolin
Description: Arnaud Jourdan (stints in the kitchens of La Chassagnette and Les Maisons Rabanel) has adroitly taken over the reins of this bistro, which continues to serve indulgent market cuisine that is both simple and generous. Shining examples include the carpaccio of calf's head with ravigote sauce, the skate wing à la grenobloise with glazed radishes and the delicious chocolate mousse with black olives and fleur de sel. A buzzy, laid-back vibe and, true to its name (slang for "wine"), you can expect a fine selection of natural and biodynamic wines at reasonable prices.

Name: Le Petit Paris
Address: 18 rue de la République, Daglan, 24250, France
Description: In the heart of a picturesque Périgord village, this welcoming establishment features two tastefully rustic dining rooms and a large terrace overlooking the village square. The chef, a local lad, takes pride in showcasing regional produce in seasonal menus that change weekly, jazzed up by his globetrotting souvenirs: duck confit nems and houmous made with Périgord walnuts; lamb sweetbread in Monbazillac wine and pink berries, finishing with an iconic dessert - Grand Marnier soufflé.

Name: L'Épicurien
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Luck has nothing to do with the current reputation of this downtown venue, facing Jean Jaurès Fountain, as the darling of the town’s discerning epicureans. The stripped-back interior sports a distinctly Scandinavian feel, which given the chef’s Swedish origins is hardly a surprise. On the culinary front, he deploys his undisputed talent, adding a new twist to French classics and conjuring up enticing recipes in tune with the era: generous portions, well crafted and oozing with flavour. The intelligent wine list and crack table staff, as professional as they are friendly, add the final flourish.

Name: La Table de Michel Dussau
Description: Just outside the town centre and near the rugby stadium, chef Michel Dussau whips up tasty recipes in a fashionable brasserie setting. He professes a weakness for local and seasonal ingredients, even better when organic. The establishment’s other appeals include a glazed wine cellar, a meat maturing cabinet.

Name: Au Plaisir Ambré
Description: Inside Vauban's fortifications, this converted butcher's places a premium on fine ingredients. Freshness is the watchword of the skilful chef, who knows how to coax out the best flavours. Examples would be the slow-confit farmhouse pork belly, wasabi jus and parsnip purée, and the dark chocolate tart with coconut sorbet. Sheer pleasure.

Name: Histoire Ancienne
Description: This bistro channels an authentic vintage spirit, with its banquette seating, mirrors and Art Deco-style posters. Patrick Comte is at the helm, still cooking up his tasty take on traditional seasonal dishes: snail persillade, corn royale, jus à la bourguignonne; tender veal chop, tarragon mustard cream… Generous cooking is the name of the game!

Name: Solelh
Address: 30 avenue des Compagnons de la Libération, L'Isle-sur-la-Sorgue, 84800, France
Description: The owners of the fine dining Le Vivier establishment were happily inspired when they opened this bistro, blessed with a double terrace, in the heart of the Carré des Arts du Luberon. From his open-plan kitchen, the chef rustles up a forthright, modern take on traditional bistro recipes, in addition to nibbles with pre-dinner drinks and choice ingredients grilled on a binchotan barbecue (aged rib of beef, squid, presa iberica, etc.). A concise selection of regional (but not only) wines adds the finishing touch to an excellent, sun-drenched meal…

Name: Le Moulin de la Santoire
Description: This restaurant occupies a converted mill built of black volcanic stone and with a slate roof. Set just outside a small village, it overlooks a pretty lake, beside which the terrace is set up in fine weather. The interior keeps things cosy (winters are harsh in the Cantal!) with a stone fireplace, a bar, a glass-paned kitchen and mismatched traditional wooden furniture. On the plate, diners can expect a beautifully presented, delicious and modern take on classic fare: think beef cheek façon royale or opera cake with chestnut and quince cream, with dishes elevated by hints of spice or Japanese condiments. It is clear that the chef learned his trade in some fine establishments. Most of the produce is sourced in the region (the coffee and cocoa come from a local roastery and chocolaterie). Platter of regional cheeses.

Name: L’Abbaye Caladoise
Description: This picturesque 17C stone - built edifice has been magnificently transformed into a restaurant. The haunt of discerning foodies (the chef won a 2016 culinary award for his pork pies), the interior has been updated and the menu reflects a distinct regional slant.

Name: Éclosion
Description: This colourful, musical eatery in the heart of Quimper hatches modern, inventive bistronomic nosh, crafted by two seasoned chefs who’ve both knocked around a bit. The food reflects their experience and know-how: pink roast duck flanked by mashed, kernels and biscuits of corn, a few gooseberries and roquette leaves; confit of monkfish is paired with courgettes, chard and figs, while the decadent dessert stars fresh strawberries with raspberry sorbet and a roquette sponge cake. Generous, balanced dishes and cheerful service.

Name: L'Aghjalle
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Garden or park,Terrace
Description: This large farm in a somewhat remote and wild yet picturesque food-producing valley in the Balagne has olive groves, grows vegetables and raises calves. The owner is a fiery character, who nonetheless pulls out the stops to make guests feel welcome in this simple, rustic restaurant with an open-air café vibe. She puts all the farm's produce to good use: traditional Corsican cuisine is served here, and it is rife with flavour and hearty fare (conchiglioni stuffed with courgette and prizuttu (ham); cuggiole (traditional biscuits) with mocha cream, tiramisu style). The menu-carte is very good value. It's easy to see why the place, a favourite with the locals, is always busy. The service is attentive and efficient.

Name: L'Itinérance
Description: On the shorefront, overlooking the quaint beach cabins and the sea, this restaurant done up in blues and greens bears the tasteful hallmark of interior decorator Caroline Tissier. The gourmet score features flawlessly fresh, consummately crafted and spot-on seasoned produce: mackerel flambé, aubergine caviar and salted anchovies; pork chop, braised lettuce and seasonal veggies. After roaming the coast, it’s time to put our feet up!

Name: Ose
Description: After stints in top establishments from New York to Paris, two veteran chefs now swap places every fortnight, taking turns in the open kitchen and the dining room. 100% bistronomic cooking from scratch using local, fresh, seasonal ingredients is the backbone of this bistro in the Abbesses neighbourhood. The menu, chalked up on a slate daily, is bang-on confident with a strong French bias and showcases deceptively simple recipes. ‘Ose’ means to dare – so what are you waiting for?

Name: Rēpu
Address: 944 avenue de la République, Marcq-en-Barœul, 59700, France
Description: Chef Abdeldaker Belfatmi wants his guests to leave satisfied and with a full stomach. His organic soft-boiled egg with peas, his pollack with smooth, buttery courgette cream and lemon hazelnut, and his crunchy crumble with pistachio cream and apricot sorbet certainly do the job! This modern brasserie cuisine shows, if proof were needed, that the chef of the former Michelin-starred restaurant Le Marcq has lost none of his flair in the kitchen.

Name: Oxalis
Address: Place de la Fontaine, Marcolès, 15220, France
Description: This bistro is the more casual sibling of the star Auberge de la Tour, helmed by chef Renaud Darmanin, which is even more reason to stay overnight in the medieval village of Marcolès deep in the Cantal countryside. The dining room takes up the most part of the hotel’s ground-floor and is extended by a terrace overlooking the street. Regional produce takes the limelight in well-crafted recipes, including veg from the cottage garden and other local ingredients such as volcano trout, poultry from the next-door farm, Auvergne cheeses. Examples of dishes: trout, vegetables, garden leaves and a knockout stock of fishbones or the melt-in-the-mouth vanilla and apricot millefeuille.

Name: Le Voyage d'Ernestine
Description: A family affair! A team of three (twins – a brother and sister – plus her partner) take their guests on a culinary journey featuring carefully selected local ingredients (lamb from the Bouscarel farm, vegetables from Tauriac, trout from Le Gouffre du Blagour fish farm etc). Trained as a butcher and charcutier, the brother is an expert when it comes to cuts of meat. As for this widely travelled couple, they punctuate their dishes with international touches (eg labneh, black lemon, lamb jus emulsified with tahini). A top-notch culinary experience in a restaurant that is firmly in tune with the times.

Name: Château de Cîteaux - Bistrot La Cueillette
Description: This bistro is a hearty alternative to chef Takashi Kinoshita's fine dining restaurant. It has made itself right at home in the vaulted space that once housed the château kitchens, which still have their period fireplace. Traditional cuisine, meticulously prepared using carefully selected ingredients, is served at lovely wooden tables: pressed ratatouille, slow-cooked egg and balsamic vinaigrette; pan-fried salmon with a mustard sauce. Laid-back atmosphere.

Name: Entre Nous
Description: This restaurant is housed in a 16C building on a cobbled street in the town centre. The decor is chock-a-block with charming features, with its large fireplace, stone window frames, exposed beams and colossal wooden branches from which the light fixtures hang. The discreet hostess (who is also the pastry chef) and the chef, who can be seen fully focused and hard at work in the open kitchen, extend a smiling welcome to their guests. The flawless dishes are bursting with energy: courgette, pepper and chorizo velouté; pressed skate, leek confit, fish fumet creamed with lemon; tartlet, blackcurrant and fig (fresh, in a mousse, a sorbet and a coulis!). The lunch menu is excellent value for money.

Name: Kwon
Description: Cinema, TV series and… food! Korean culture has become omnipresent in France – much to our delight. This restaurant's trendy decor has a minimalist, industrial feel, a menu of Korean classics such as barbecue and bibimbap, and above all a keen sense of detail. The care taken over the accompaniments is particularly clear to see, whether you opt for the emblematic kimchi, crunchy beans with a smoky flavour, caramelised lotus flower or cucumber with chilli. This is generous and fresh fare and good value for money!

Name: Rosette
Description: Pâté en croûte, sweetbreads, chocolate cake – just a few of the mouth-watering dishes that have already sealed the reputation of this popular bistro. Opened by a young couple who have worked in some prestigious establishments, it is named in a nod to their Lyonnais roots. They make good use of top-notch ingredients, including organic vegetables from Essonne. At lunchtime, they serve a menu du jour and five-course set menu (no options; also available in the evening) that evolve with the seasons. The fantastic decor is a contemporary take on a bouchon, allies modern elements and well-chosen antiques. A small restaurant with an open kitchen and a few seats at the counter. Excellent wine list including pots lyonnais>/i>!

Name: Sème
Description: In the heart of the village on the market square, chef Charlotte Gondor and restaurant manager Maxime Zesir have opened this lively and appealing little bistro featuring a rather eclectic decor (wine posters, pepper mill, books on Normandy). The chef, who hails from the north of the Cotentin Peninsula and has previously worked in Paris (at L'Envie du Jour), creates delicious cuisine that is firmly rooted in tradition, which she brings up to date and even upends (with her beetroot dessert, for example). Seasonal ingredients, along with local and regional produce, underpin her dishes. The lunch menu changes daily, and at weekends there are plates for sharing, including the iconic rack of salt-meadow lamb.

Name: Doma
Description: Within the city walls, a handful of tables set up on the pavement; inside, a compact, contemporary space with a corrugated iron wall section and the menu featuring on enamelled tiles: this house (doma in Slavonic) catches the eye and whets the appetite! Marinated sardine, crispy rice and salsa verde, followed by an open prawn ravioli, bisque and seaweed curry emulsion, and – the final flourish – a madeleine cake, nectarine compote and verbena cream. In short, colourful dishes that showcase the season (and are good value for money, too!).

Name: Paul-Arthur
Address: 23-25 place de la Pucelle, Rouen, 76000, France
Description: This former Top Chef contestant, who hails from the South of France, has set up shop in this half-timbered house on Place de la Pucelle. In this contemporary bistro, which still boasts its period beams, the chef cooks up a pressé of veal shank and foie gras with pistachio pistou; hake confit in semi-salted butter, sweet potato and smoked hollandaise; banoffee pie, dulce de leche and caramelised pecans. The style is the right degree of modern, the ingredients are seasonal, and the dinner menu is more ambitious than that at lunchtime.

Name: La Salamandre
Description: Done out in the style of a contemporary bistro, laid out beneath an attractive beamed ceiling, this restaurant is housed in an outbuilding of the Château de Saint-Aignan, a pretty medieval village overlooking the River Cher. As for the food, the seasoned Dutch chef serves up a starter of fine mackerel cooked skin on, accompanied by samphire, caviar, dried egg and yuzu; for the main course, a lovely piece of hake with tender pieces of octopus, spinach and a touch of ginger. Terrace nestled at the foot of the château.

Name: L'Acte 2
Description: Before taking over and modernising these premises, Julie (restaurant floor and wine) and Lucas (kitchen) met at Régis and Jacques Marcon's restaurant, a benchmark if ever there was one. With L'Acte 2, they are now welcoming customers of their own into this small, contemporary dining space. Trout mousse, Le Puy green lentils and a fresh herb sauce; pork prepared two ways, pearl barley risotto, baby spinach and oyster mushrooms, sage-infused jus: the chef goes all out in his endeavours to create well-executed dishes.

Name: Cheung Hing Kee (Tsim Sha Tsui)
Address: GF, 48 Lock Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Hong Kong
Description: Besides the typical sheng jian bao with soupy pork filling, this shop serves varieties such as shrimp, mala pork, truffle, crabmeat and roe. The buns are springy, brimming with filling, and crispy on the bottom.

Name: O Castiço
Address: 65B Rua Direita Carlos Eugénio, Taipa, Macau
Description: This cosy hangout has long been attracting a loyal following for its tasty, homespun food at affordable prices. Now run by the late owner’s son, it continues to welcome diners like family, offering carefully crafted, authentic Portuguese fare. Their signature stewed pork with clams delivers balanced flavours and a pleasant kick due to coriander and a secret sauce. The made to order salted cod fritters are served piping hot.

Name: Nishiki
Address: Shop 103, 1F, Regal Kowloon Hotel, 71 Mody Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Hong Kong
Description: Despite opening over 20 years ago, the bustling atmosphere and tasty grill dishes of this izakaya-style place still shine. The Japanese owner-chef teaches his kitchen team the tricks for perfect barbecue – his famous tsukune, for example, is made with boneless chicken thigh from Japan and Brazil in a specific ratio. Grilled chicken liver from local farms is another speciality. Reservations are recommended; ask for counter seats to get close to the action.

Name: Brass Spoon (Wan Chai)
Address: Shop B, GF, 1-3 Moon Street, Wan Chai, Hong Kong
Description: Tucked away in a quiet residential area, this is the place for authentic Vietnamese snacks and noodle soup. The owner-chef learnt the trade in France, where his family had a Vietnamese restaurant. In his signature phở, U.S. Angus beef and Danish pork combine magically with beef shank bone broth that simmers for over 16 hours. Deceptively simple looking snacks like spring rolls and bánh cuốn taste addictively good. Always busy; expect to queue.

Name: Sang Kee Foods (Western District)
Address: Shop 4, GF, Wo Yick Mansion, 263 Queen's Road West, Sai Ying Pun, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: Come to this place with a nose-to-tail concept for Chiuchow-style marinated goose. Made with grain-fed goose from Chiuchow, it boasts a firm texture and meaty flavour. Try the goose blood curd, web, wing, liver, intestine and gizzard, too.

Name: Tin Hung
Address: Shop D, GF, Yan Yee Building, 88 Kin Yip Street, Yuen Long, Hong Kong
Description: Popular with locals since 2001, this shop sells its signature roast goose in specific cuts, halves or whole. Geese are shipped from Foshan daily, marinated, roasted to perfection, and served piping hot. Other standouts include honey-glazed char siu, roast duck and drunken chicken. Those looking to pair the meats with a local drink should try their herbal tea. Given the reasonable prices and limited seats, it makes sense to arrive early.

Name: Tak Kee
Address: Shop G, 3 Belcher's Street, Western District, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: It started out as a street-side hawker stall in the 1990s and still retains the casual, vibrant vibe. The second-generation hands-on owner shops for groceries every day and sometimes helps the experienced chefs with kitchen chores. Pork tripe and peppercorn soup is a culinary highlight, using peppers from Malaysia and Indonesia. Regulars also come for its spiced marinated goose liver, crispy chitterlings stuffed with glutinous rice and oyster omelette.

Name: Ho To Tai
Address: 67 Fau Tsoi Street, Yuen Long, Hong Kong
Description: Traditional shops that make their own noodles from scratch are hard to come by. Founded in 1946, this household name is among the remaining few. Though the nostalgic two-storey shop draws a crowd with its signature wonton soup, zhajiang noodles and beef brisket noodle soup are also popular. Try braised white radish with shrimp roe for the deep umami and briny-sweetness. The owner also runs a dried noodle factory with retail outlets all over town.

Name: Mak Man Kee
Address: 51 Parkes Street, Jordan, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: No one is here for the no-frills interior, typical of any noodle shop in Hong Kong. This 60-year-old establishment is all about Cantonese wonton soup noodles – firm and bouncy prawns, visible through the paper-thin translucent skin, with springy duck egg noodles swimming in a flavourful broth. The noodles taste equally great when simply tossed in oyster sauce or shrimp roe, the latter also available as a pre-packaged condiment to go.

Name: Lau Sum Kee (Fuk Wing Street)
Address: 82 Fuk Wing Street, Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: Since 1956, this branch (and the original shop around the corner) has been packed with customers buzzing in and out. The third-generation family business still kneads noodle dough with a bamboo pole, like it used to be done, for that springy texture. Wontons are made on the spot with whole prawns and pork; even the crunchy radish pickles are homemade. Wonton noodles are a must; you can choose one or two more toppings if you like.

Name: Lucky Indonesia
Address: 46 Tung Ming Street, Kwun Tong, Hong Kong
Description: For over 30 years, this tiny gem has been famous in the neighbourhood for its authentic Central Javanese cooking. The room feels cosy and youthful after a facelift and the food is as tasty as always. For chargrilled satay exuding an addictive smoky aroma, choose from lamb, pork and chicken varieties. Lontong capgome is sticky rice balls with several side dishes such as beef rendang, opor ayam and pindang egg. Pair with an iced longan drink.

Name: Din Tai Fung (Tsim Sha Tsui)
Address: Shop 306, 3F, Silvercord, 30 Canton Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: From the late Mr Yang’s first shop in Taiwan in 1958 grew a multinational chain with branches all over the world. It’s famous for good service, competitive prices and listening to its customer’s feedback, but mostly for its xiao long bao made on the spot. Even the vinegar, free of artificial colours and preservatives, is shipped from Taiwan. Seating accommodates different party sizes, from solo diners to parties of 12. Expect long queues at peak hours.

Name: IFTM Educational Restaurant
Address: Pousada de Mong-Há, Colina de Mong-Há, Macau, Macau
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Being part of the Institute for Tourism Studies, this place has students working in its kitchen and front-of-house teams – and the pride they take in their work is palpable. The menu features European and Macanese dishes; for a taste of local flavours, start with the Macanese appetiser platter and order African chicken as your main. Oenophiles should peruse the exclusively Portuguese wine list. On Saturdays only the Macanese buffet is served.

Name: Cheong Kei
Description: A family business since the '70s, this noodle shop sticks to its roots and its thin, fine noodles are pressed by bamboo pole in its own factory nearby. Their soup is cooked with dried prawns and dried plaice for 8 hours. The noodles with dried shrimp roe are great, but also try their wontons and dace balls that are served deep-fried or blanched; the fermented clam sauce is the perfect accompaniment to the dace balls.

Name: Takeya
Address: Shop 1, On Wah Building, 31C1 Tak Man Street, Whampoa Estate, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Description: This intimate 15-seater yakitori shop is the brainchild of a Japanese engineer, now the chef, and his wife, now the maître d'. For over a decade, they’ve been feeding hungry diners in the neighbourhood with quality grilled food, with some ingredients flown in from Japan. Rare cuts such as chicken heart and hatsumoto (artery) are definitely worth a try. Pair them with their selection of sake or home-brewed umeshu. Reservations are recommended.

Name: Shek Kee Kitchen
Address: 15-17 Ngan Mok Street, Tin Hau, Hong Kong
Description: During the day, this cosy joint in the heart of the city serves light meals and fried noodles. At night, the menu specialises in home-style Cantonese dishes. The owner-chef Mr Shek sources the freshest ingredients from wet markets daily and regulars also call him directly to pre-order certain dishes, such as fried chicken with toasted garlic which needs a day’s notice. The pan-fried hand-minced cuttlefish patties are springy and flavourful.

Name: Samsen (Wan Chai)
Address: 68 Stone Nullah Lane, Wan Chai, Hong Kong
Description: This casual Thai noodle shop next to the historic Blue House is aptly named after an area in Bangkok where the Chinese traded with the Thais. Rattan blinds, bare concrete walls and distressed wood furniture give off a street-stall vibe. The signature boat noodles are not to be missed – the flavoursome broth alone takes 6 hours to make. Those with a sweet tooth can round things off with young coconut ice cream. Come early to beat the crowd.

Name: Kung Wo Beancurd Factory
Address: 118 Pei Ho Street, Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong
Description: This much-loved shop makes its own tofu that boasts a deep, rich soy aroma. As well as the renowned tofu pudding, it also carries other soy products like soy milk, fried stuffed tofu, tofu puffs and golden fish tofu.

Name: Ah Chun Shandong Dumpling
Address: 60 Lai Chi Kok Road, Prince Edward, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: The shop has a traditional feel to it. Green wooden window frames on the wall are reminiscent of old-time Hong Kong. Dumplings are handmade daily and only the freshest ingredients are used in the fillings. Try their most-ordered item lamb and Peking scallion dumplings. Or surprise yourself with the specialty, such as mackerel dumplings and cuttlefish dumplings. Shandong roast lamb and meat pie are also recommended.

Name: She Wong Leung
Address: Shop A, GF, 298 Electric Road, North Point, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: In business for over 20 years, this shop is famous for its snake soup. While most people consume snake soup only in winter, the owner formulates a different herbal base for every season to make it a healthy tonic all year round. Set menus comprising of snake soup and home-style dishes offer exceptional value and cater for all tastes. Go for glutinous rice or lamb stew in winter. Double-boiled soups are popular but require pre-ordering.

Name: Shugetsu Ramen (Central)
Description: The queues form early for the ramen here, with many of the customers coming for the Tsukemen ramen, as well as the Abura and special soup ramen. The shop makes its own noodles – which you can have thick or thin – but it is the sauce at the base of the slow-cooked soup that really makes the difference: it’s fermented for 18 months in a 100-year-old wooden basket and adds richness and depth.

Name: Fisholic (North Point)
Address: Shop 14, GF, Victor Court, 14-28 Wang On Road, North Point, Hong Kong
Description: Famous for snacks and noodles made with fish, this stall sells playful items like deep-fried minced fish in the guise of French fries, or fish skin nachos. Fishotto, where minced fish is shaped like rice grains, is also good.

Name: Lok Kei Noodles (Patane)
Description: This busy shop next to the Chun Lei pier still kneads the noodles with a bamboo pole like in bygone days. The owner’s wife then cooks them perfectly, thus explaining their bouncy texture. The broth simmered with an array of seasonal fish boasts depth and sweetness. Dried prawn roe sprinkled on tossed noodles is toasted by the owner himself, imparting umami and aroma. Also try the crab congee and deep-fried wontons with crispy dace balls.

Name: Wing Lai Yuen
Address: Shop 102-105, 1F, Gourmet Place, Whampoa Plaza, Site 8, Whampoa Garden, 7 Tak On Street, Hung Hom, Hong Kong
Description: Originally a run-down shop in a squatter village, it moved to this airy and bright location in 2000. But one thing never changed – the food is as delicious and affordably priced as ever. The signature Dan Dan noodles come in two versions: a meat one with ground pork and a traditional one without, plus a spicy or mild broth to choose from. Shuizhu mandarin fish packs numbing heat and the portion size is big enough for a few to share.

Name: Wang Fu
Description: Wang Fu is famous for its Pekingese dumplings – among the great variety of handmade dumplings on the menu, the green onion mutton one stands out most. Apart from dumpling soups, it also serves fried dumplings with light charred crispy skin and juicy fillings. Try also the tomato and egg dumpling, only available after 2 pm. If you fancy more variety, check out their noodles and cold appetisers as well, or ask about the daily special.

Name: Tsim Chai Kee (Wellington Street)
Address: 98 Wellington Street, Central, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: The long lunchtime queue happens for a reason – the noodles here are bouncy and the broth is flavoursome. Only three toppings are offered – springy dace balls, wontons generously filled with pork and shrimps, and sliced beef with a robust meaty flavour and tender texture. You can even choose a combination of any two or all three toppings. Expect to share a table with strangers when it’s busy or eat outside of peak times to beat the crowd.

Name: Kwan Kee Bamboo Noodles
Address: Shop E, 1 Wing Lung Street, Cheung Sha Wan, Hong Kong
Description: It’s inside a local market but easy to spot, thanks to the big yellow sign. Watch the kitchen at work through the glass wall as noodles are made the traditional way – with the chef seesawing on a bamboo pole to painstakingly knead the egg-rich dough for that stringy texture. Secret techniques are deployed to remove the soapy taste of lye and accentuate the eggy flavour. Don’t miss the signature noodles tossed in shrimp roe and oyster sauce.

Name: Congee and Noodle Shop
Address: Shop 2A, 2F, Kerry Centre, 683 King's Road, Quarry Bay, Hong Kong
Description: Hidden in a glass office tower, this simple shop may not have much ambiance or character, but everyone is here for the creamy congee made by a chef with over 30 years of experience. There are countless combinations of toppings and you can customize your own congee; bestsellers include fresh crab congee, and chicken congee with abalone. Deep-fried dough items, and pan-fried fish cake with fermented clam sauce, are also worth trying.

Name: Megan's Kitchen
Address: 5F, Lucky Centre, 165-171 Wan Chai Road, Wan Chai, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Valet parking
Description: The menu offers many Cantonese dishes, but steamed minced beef patty with dried mandarin peel, and Yu Xiang eggplant in claypot stand out in particular. Better still, all mains come with complimentary rice, soup and dessert. Their famous hot pots spoil diners with an array of soup bases and good quality ingredients. Those who prefer a little privacy will appreciate the booth seating with sliding screens as dividers.

Name: Eng Kee Noodle Shop
Address: GF, 32 High Street, Sai Ying Pun, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: This family-run shop is always jam-packed with hungry locals craving Cantonese noodle soup. No matter for dine-in or take-out, expect a reasonable wait. It prides itself on its signature beef brisket – braised one night ahead and steeped in a spiced marinade overnight for silky tenderness and deep flavours. Their oven-grilled char siu is made with pork shoulder and pork neck and has a juicy, springy texture thanks to the fine marbling.

Name: Dragon Inn
Address: Miles 19, Castle Peak Road, Tuen Mun, Hong Kong
Description: This restaurant is known by almost everyone in the neighbourhood and was revamped in 2017 to include more private rooms alongside the main dining hall. Most guests pick their seafood from the nearby wet market for the chefs here to cook up; others choose from the catch of the day without looking at the menu. Baked baby lobster with cheese and baked oysters with port are not to be missed. It also serves dim sum during the day.

Name: Sister Wah
Address: Shop A1, 13 Electric Road, Tin Hau, Hong Kong
Description: The legendary Sister Wah is no longer at the helm but her sons are running the shop just like she used to. The signature beef brisket in clear soup uses fresh local beef which is braised in a stock with over 10 different herbs. Popular items on the brief menu include homemade pork and cabbage dumplings, drunken chicken, Dan Dan noodles, and braised white radish in beef juices. With only six tables, it fills up as soon as it opens.

Name: Din Tai Fung (COD)
Address: SOHO, 2F, City of Dreams, Estrada do Istmo, Cotai, Macau
Description: The second floor of COD plays host to a plethora of casual eateries – and in the corner you’ll find this sizeable branch of the international chain. Din Tai Fung is rightly known for its exquisite xiao long bao but also special here is the steamed crab roe and pork dumpling. Other notables from the 70-odd Shanghainese dishes on offer include the excellent braised beef noodle soup. To finish, try the red bean glutinous rice cake.

Name: Chan Seng Kei
Description: This semi open-air restaurant has stood next to an ancient church for over 70 years and the 3rd generation of the family still focus on traditional Cantonese cooking. Seafood is the highlight as the owner works closely with local fishermen to secure the best catch – he prefers wild-caught fish about 500 to 600g for their tender flesh. Also try stewed duck with tangerine peel which takes more than 10 hours to make, with only a few available each day.

Name: Tai Woo
Address: 9F, Causeway Bay Plaza 2, 463-483 Lockhart Road, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong
Description: One of the district’s most famous names, Tai Woo opened its door in the 80s and moved to this address in 2011 and, while the restaurant may be smaller than before, business is better than ever, with over 1,000 customers served every day. What hasn’t changed is the quality of the cooking – along with a menu of wallet friendly Cantonese seafood dishes, such as fish fried rice with ginger, are favourites like sesame chicken baked in salt.

Name: Kau Kee
Address: 21 Gough Street, Central, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: Kau Kee has been trading since the 1930s and has consequently built up such a huge following that you’ll probably have to line up in the street first to eat here. It’s all very basic and you’ll have to share your table but the food is delicious. Beef noodles are the speciality; different cuts of meat with a variety of noodles in a tasty broth or spicy sauce. Try the milk tea too.

Name: Po Kee
Address: 425P Queen's Road West, Western District, Hong Kong
Description: How far would you go for a bowl of Lai Fan noodles with roast duck leg? Every morning loyal fans line up at the door before this shop opens – that’s how good it is. A fixture in the neighbourhood for over 40 years, Po Kee is hugely popular among locals for its roast meats freshly grilled in the factory behind the shop. Time your visit as roast pork tends to run out before 2 pm and the goose before 4 pm; or you can pre-order to avoid disappointment.

Name: Yuan is Here (Western District)
Address: 31 North Street, Western District, Hong Kong
Description: Decorated with memorabilia and buzzing with night market vibes, this street food shop is the brainchild of its Taiwan-born owner. Some ingredients are imported direct from his hometown to ensure that every bite is as authentic as possible. The signature minced braised pork rice boasts depth and a melty texture, while the traditionally-made double egg oyster omelette is both chewy and eggy at the same time. Round off with taro ball sweet soup.

Name: Chan Kan Kee Chiu Chow
Address: Shop 353B, Level 3, The LOHAS, 1 Lohas Park Road, Tseung Kwan O, Hong Kong
Description: The third-generation owners of this 70-year-old household name decided to move from Sheung Wan to this shopping mall in 2020. Regulars would feel reassured finding the familiar gilded sign on black hanging over the semi-open kitchen where a dazzling spread of food is on display. The must-try signature marinated goose sports velvety, flavourful flesh and just the right amount of fat. Seafood like crabs and fourfinger threadfins needs pre-ordering.

Name: Yi Jia
Address: Shop G04, Lime Gala, 393 Shau Kei Wan Road, Shau Kei Wan, Hong Kong
Description: A stark contrast of colours, neon lights and retro patterns make the room unorthodox but welcoming. On the menu, you can find Shanghainese and Sichuanese classics like Qili Zhuang drunken chicken in wine lees, and Sichuan boiled fish. But novelty creations such as deep-fried soufflé meringue with mango custard filling are also worth trying. The creator’s sense of humour comes through in the cheeky drinks menu. Set menus are especially well priced.

Name: Little Napoli
Address: 8 King Kwong Street, Happy Valley, Hong Kong
Description: True to the chef’s hometown traditions, classic Neapolitan pizzas and street foods like ripieno fritto and panuozzo are made with only ingredients from Naples. Pizzas such as Margherita or Vesuviana are made to order, baked in an Italian stone oven at 400°C, and served whole, not sliced, boasting a puffy, nicely charred crust and gooey centre. It’s basically a grab-and-go pizzeria with a few seats, so come early if you want to dine in.

Name: Tasty (Central)
Address: Shop 3016-3018, 3F, IFC Mall, 1 Harbour View Street, Central, Hong Kong
Description: Be prepared to queue and share a table because over 1,000 customers a day, many of whom work in IFC, crowd into this Tasty. They mostly come for the trademark shrimp wonton or the much-loved beef and rice noodle stir fry; congee with prawns and dim sum are also recommended from the vast choice on offer. The last redecoration left the interior looking a lot more contemporary.

Name: Tim Ho Wan (Sham Shui Po)
Address: 9-11 Fuk Wing Street, Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong
Description: The second branch of this famous dim sum chain is roomier than the original, but don’t be surprised to still find a queue of expectant diners at the entrance. Over 20 different dim sum are on offer, all skilfully made and reasonably priced. Some items rotate every two to three months to keep the menu fresh. Don’t miss their shrimp dumplings, baked buns with barbecue pork filling and steamed beef balls.

Name: Twins Liangpi Limited (Mong Kok)
Address: GF, 99 Hak Po Street, Mong Kok, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: Now with a dine-in option, the shop has moved to Mong Kok. Glass noodles dressed in a secret blend of chilli vinegar are topped with shredded cucumber, coriander, peas and ground peanuts. Choose your preferred level of spiciness.

Name: Glorious Cuisine
Address: 31-33 Shek Kip Mei Street, Sham Shui Po, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: Picking out live critters from the tank is part of the fun – Hokkaido scallops, Thai marble goby, and even Hanasaki crab if you’re lucky. As well as the signature braised chicken stuffed with abalone and sea cucumber, do try dishes made with chicken offal, such as stock-poached leafy greens with chicken liver. Double-boiled chicken soup with conpoy and Yunnan ham is available in limited quantities, so consider pre-ordering certain items.

Name: Sang Kee
Address: 3-4F, Sunshine Plaza, 353 Lockhart Road, Wan Chai, Hong Kong
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Bring your own bottle,Valet parking,Wheelchair access
Description: An iconic landmark of Wan Chai since 1976, Sang Kee has moved shop. The room is brighter, more spacious and offers more seating. But rest assured: the menu hasn’t changed and the food is as good as ever.
