Despite the lack of fancy plating and luxury ingredients, you’ll find yourself craving their salt-baked chicken, pork liver and wolfberry leaves blanched in stock, and baked fish intestine with egg long after you’ve gone home.

Name: Man Yuen
Address: Shop S02, 2F, Tin Ma Court Commercial Centre, 55 Chuk Yuen Road, Wong Tai Sin, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: This newcomer to the East Kowloon dining scene is tucked away on a public housing estate, but that doesn't stop diners coming in droves from near and far for quality Cantonese dishes made with fresh ingredients. The kitchen and front-of-house teams have worked in exclusive clubs, hotels and restaurants – quality of food and service are guaranteed. The menu features all-time classics such as wok hei-laden "king of stir-fries" with fresh, dried and sakura shrimps.

Name: Sing Kee
Address: 2F, 1 Lyndhurst Tower, 1 Lyndhurst Terrace, Central, Hong Kong
Description: Sing Kee is a bright, tidy spot serving traditional, no-frills Cantonese food – something that’s increasingly hard to find in Central. Standouts include pan-seared salted chicken, and grilled tiger prawns in Malaysian curry sauce with crispy rice crackers. Specialities like double-boiled fish maw and pork lung in almond milk need pre-ordering. Come at lunch to take advantage of some reasonable prices.

Name: Kwan Kee Clay Pot Rice (Queen's Road West)
Address: Shop 1, GF, Wo Yick Mansion, 263 Queen's Road West, Sai Ying Pun, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: Its red sign, basic interior and traditional stir-fries all point to an authentic Hong Kong food experience. Claypot rice is only served at night and takes time to prepare, so order it first as soon as you’re seated. The three-rice blend results in a chewy texture and appealing fragrance; the bottom crust is always perfectly scorched. The white eel variety is especially popular; pair it with claypot dishes with excellent wok hei.

Name: Ancient Moon
Address: Shop A, 29 Kam Ping Street, North Point, Hong Kong
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: On a trip to Singapore and Malaysia, owners Fanni and Lico fell in love with their street food which inspired them to open their fun little spot. The small menu lists about 20 items, but you won’t find typical national dishes here. Instead, it’s among the few places that offer Malaysian chilli pan mee (a flavoursome noodle dish with dried fish and chilli sauce) and free refill of Singaporean bak kut teh, a MSG-free, peppery pork rib soup.

Name: Trusty Congee King (Wan Chai)
Address: 7 Heard Street, Wan Chai, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: As suggested by its name, you can really trust the quality of the food served in this long-standing congee shop. The menu has become more versatile in recent years with congee, noodles and snack sets available. All congee is cooked in fish broth that gives an extra dimension of flavour. Many rave about the pork liver and scallop congee, sticky rice dumpling with salted egg yolk and pork, and poached grass carp skin.

Name: Ba Yi
Address: 43 Water Street, Sai Ying Pun, Hong Kong
Description: Despite being somewhat out of the way, lamb-lovers gather here in numbers for items such as stewed lamb and mutton skewers, prepared by the Xinjiangese kitchen team. The signature roasted lamb leg is big enough to share between two and needs pre-ordering. Besides lamb, it’s also worth trying the chicken stew with potato and chilli, as well as the Ketik yoghurt drink. The dining room still features the map of the Silk Road on a stretched canvas.

Name: Lou Kei
Address: Shop H&M, GF, Vang Kei Building, 12 Avenida Da Concõrdia N, Macau, Macau
Description: Though slightly out of the way, Lou Kei is a firm favourite among locals for a simple, good value supper. For over 20 years, its sizeable selection of tasty noodles, congee and Cantonese dishes has won the hearts of countless diners. With heaps of crispy fried garlic and chilli bits, the typhoon shelter-style deep-fried Bombay duck is delicious. Claypot rice with eel in black bean sauce boasts firm, oily fish on crispy scorched rice.

Name: Chiuchow Delicacies (North Point)
Address: Shop 4, GF, Gain Yu Building, 96 Wharf Road, North Point, Hong Kong
Description: This shop isn’t particularly spacious, but that doesn’t stop customers from coming here for their authentic Chiu Chow cooking at wallet-friendly prices. Sliced goose steeped in signature spiced marinade is velvety without being greasy – refer to the mural for the spices used. The variety of chilled steamed fish on offer is quite a spectacle, all oily and delicious. Some dishes need pre-ordering and expect to share a table with strangers when it’s busy.

Name: Din Tai Fung (Causeway Bay)
Address: Shop G3-G11, GF, 68 Yee Woo Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong
Description: The xiao long bao are good enough to justify the long queues – so worry not. Alongside the traditional soupy pork filling, they also come in novelty versions such as black truffle and angled luffa with shrimps. Ingredients are sourced from the same suppliers as its Taiwan flagship and the same kitchen team here delivers food in consistently high quality. Other standouts include double-boiled chicken soup and braised beef brisket noodle soup.

Name: Café Hunan (Western District)
Address: 420-424 Queen's Road West, Western District, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: The kitchen team of Hunanese natives boasts solid skills, especially in quick-fried dishes that sport exceptional wok hei. Ingredients such as chillies and smoked pork are sourced directly from farmers in Hunan. The speciality braised pork elbow involves four complicated cooking steps spanning over 10 hours to develop layered flavours and the right texture. Stir-fried pork with Youxian beancurd and spicy organic cauliflower are also worth trying.

Name: Eton
Address: 1-2F, European Asian Bank Building, 749 Nathan Road, Mong Kok, Hong Kong
Description: In 2019, the long-standing household name Fung Shing closed its doors as the owner-chef retired. A regular customer and the staff then got together to re-open it as Eton in 2020. The room was renovated and about 80% of the kitchen and service teams returned. The menu is largely the same; dim sum, crispy fried chicken, deep-fried shrimp toast, scrambled egg white with milk in Daliang style, and Shun Tak fish tripe thick soup are still recommended.

Name: Ăn Chơi
Address: 15-17 Mercer Street, Sheung Wan, Hong Kong
Description: Run by a binational Chinese-Vietnamese couple, the colourful Ăn Chơi captures the liveliness of Vietnamese street stalls. Their bánh mì sandwiches come in an array of fillings; varying versions of phở are made according to different regional traditions. Lã Vọng grilled fish uses halibut instead of river fish; the house-fermented fish sauce is loaded in full-bodied unique flavours. For drinks, try egg coffee or Vietnamese beer.

Name: Tai Wing Wah
Address: 2F, 2-6 On Ning Road, Yuen Long, Hong Kong
Description: This bright, fresh and long-standing Cantonese restaurant serves dim sum and ‘Walled Village’ cuisine, alongside assorted Cantonese classics. Walled village-style five-flavour chicken boasts flavoursome, velvety meat. Other specialities include roast duck with bean paste and coriander; claypot rice with lard, premium soy sauce, steamed mullet with salted lemon; and, above all, the steamed sponge cake. Also check out the seasonal menu.

Name: Ju Xing Home
Address: GF, 416 and 418 Portland Street, Prince Edward, Hong Kong
Description: This hole-in-the-wall is always jam-packed and that's down to chef-owner Ng's cooking, not the decor or service. Cantonese stir-fries prevail, alongside a few spicy options. The must-try salt-baked Wenchang chicken is succulent, flavoursome… and tends to run out early. Live seafood is also big on the menu, eg pan-fried prawn in soy sauce or steamed eel in black bean sauce. Reservations are recommended and it's worth pre-ordering the chicken to avoid missing out.

Name: Kapok
Address: 60 Rua de Hong Chau, Taipa, Macau
Description: With ceiling fans, bowl pendant lights and Lingnan-style stained glass, the room is the epitome of yesteryear glamour. The menu is likewise dominated by traditionally made Cantonese favourites - diced pork fat gives har gow extra depth of flavour and the white sugar sponge is perfectly proofed without a hint of sourness. Don’t miss their green chillies stuffed with minced dace, double-boiled soups or seafood dishes.

Name: Saya
Address: Shop G701, GF, Square Mile II, 18 Ka Shin Street, Tai Kok Tsui, Hong Kong
Description: A turquoise colour scheme, rattan furniture and wall coverings impart a retro tropical vibe. The menu is dominated by Isan cuisine from Northeast Thailand, mindfully prepared by a Thai kitchen team. Khao Soy bursts with aromas from the coconut milk curry and chargrilled chicken. Pla Phao, salt-crusted grilled fish seasoned with lemongrass and pandan, is served with lettuce, rice vermicelli and a tangy sauce. Lunch menu offers great value.

Name: Tai Wai Dining Room (Tai Wai)
Address: 98 Chik Fuk Street, Tai Wai, Hong Kong
Description: The red lanterns at the entrance are a prelude to the nostalgic, Chinese-style interior. The experienced kitchen team shows respect to Cantonese traditions, but with a subtle sense of cheeky humour. Dim sum dominates the menu at lunch, and all-time favourites like duo sausage rolls and pan-fried chicken sticky rice dumplings particularly stand out. Portion sizes are generous, service is thoughtful – and the food is consistently good.

Name: Son Tak Kong
Description: Since 1979, Son Tak Kong has been jam-packed with happy regulars, lured by its no-frills, authentic Shun Tak cuisine. A Shun Tak native himself, the owner hires chefs for whom the secrets of Cantonese and Shun Tak food have no secrets. Their signature creamy fish soup calls upon exquisite knife work, first-rate ingredients and rich, slowly simmered fish broth. Also try the sticky rice with Sakura shrimps and pine nuts in a cast iron pot.

Name: Yue Kee
Address: 9 Sham Hong Road, Sham Tseng, Hong Kong
Description: From humble beginnings as a tiny countryside joint in 1958, this second-generation family business has gone big, but without losing its flair. Owning a farm that breeds Qingyuan black brown geese ensures quality and a steady supply. Chargrilled according to the owner’s family recipe and served after 11:45am, their goose is known for its distinctive smokiness, crispy skin and juicy meat. The menu also includes seafood and stir-fries.

Name: Kai Kai
Address: 29 Ning Po Street, Jordan, Hong Kong
Description: Traditional Chinese sweet soups like tofu skin soup with ginkgo and Job’s tears, or black sesame soup boast rich flavours. Top it with glutinous rice balls or a hard-boiled egg for extra texture.

Name: Putien (Causeway Bay)
Address: Shop A, 7F, Lee Theatre Plaza, 99 Percival Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong
Description: The original restaurant was founded in Singapore in 2000 and named after a coastal city in Fujian province – the owner’s hometown. This branch comes with an easy-going atmosphere and its Fujian cuisine is respectful of tradition, with a focus on natural flavours. New items are added to the menu from time to time. Don’t miss their themed offerings that feature a particular seasonal seafood, such as razor clams or oysters.

Name: Restaurant Litoral (Taipa)
Address: No. 53-57, Block 4, Wai Chin Kok, Rua do Regedor, Taipa, Macau
Description: The simple space has a vaulted ceiling with exposed wooden trusses, roughcast walls and irregular flagstone floor for a casual vibe. Portuguese and Macanese classics are served in portion sizes meant for sharing. Carne Alentejana marries the umami of fresh clams and pork cubes with bold seasoning; the African chicken is coated in shredded coconut and caramelised onion then browned under a broiler. Finish with the light and fluffy serradura.

Name: Samsen (Sheung Wan)
Address: 23 Jervois Street, Sheung Wan, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: Readers may recognize the name it shares with a noodle shop in Wan Chai – yes, this is a spinoff by the same owner-chef, Adam Cliff. While it shares almost the same menu as the Wan Chai branch, certain exclusive dishes stand out. For instance, its signature 11-spice Northern Thai curry takes up to eight hours to make and is the perfect companion to egg noodles. Desserts like young coconut ice cream or mango and sticky rice are also pluses.

Name: Sai Kwan Lo Jo
Address: Shop B, 18 Man Yuen Street, Jordan, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR China
Description: This takeout-only shop carries both traditional and novelty snacks. Try hand-made lai fun noodles in Sai Kwan style, deep-fried sticky rice dumpling with Iberico pork, or stir-fried turnip cake with XO chilli sauce.

Name: Hao Tang Hao Mian (Tai Wai)
Address: GF, 20 Chik Chuen Street, Tai Wai, Hong Kong
Description: An owner-chef with over 20 years of experience in French cooking opened this 20-seater specialising in just 12 noodle soup items, each with a specific soup base and topping. The signature flat noodles in beef soup with Sichuanese beef cheek and French-style braised oxtail takes two days to make, involving eclectic techniques. The dessert menu is equally impressive – try the all-natural sorbets made in-house with fresh fruits.

Name: Fung Shing (North Point)
Address: 62-68 Java Road, North Point, Hong Kong
Description: This long-standing champion of Shun Tak cuisine sports traditional fixtures and fittings. Locals and tourists come for dim sum in the morning, while painstakingly prepared Cantonese favourites and Shun Tak specialities are served at lunch and dinner. Besides signatures like crispy fried chicken and Daliang-style scrambled egg white with milk, don’t miss their sugar egg puff doughnuts available at weekend lunchtime only. Hearty portions to share.

Name: Ship Kee
Address: GF, Pao Yip Building, 7 Ship Street, Wan Chai, Hong Kong
Description: Ship Kee opened its doors in 2021 and prides itself on Cantonese classics from the old days. The barbecue chef honed his skills in some prestigious kitchens for over 40 years; his Master Woo’s honey glazed BBQ pork is seasoned perfectly, tender but springy. The dim sum chef has 30+ years of experience; his steamed rice rolls with shrimps and Chinese chives look like gems under a velvety, translucent skin. Call ahead to pre-order certain dishes.

Name: Norma
Address: Rua Doutor José Sampaio 35, Guimaraes, 4810 275, Portugal
Description: Norma occupies an old building that almost passes by unnoticed, yet boasts delightful views, especially from its terrace, from where the vista encompasses São Gualter church, the iconic symbol of the city. The head chef here is Hugo Alves who, having worked in leading restaurants around Portugal, decided to return to his native Guimarães. His cooking is centred on a tasting menu and an à la carte that change every season. Dishes that are a must include the profiterole made with crab, tomato, sweet basil and cream cheese, and the mouthwatering “bràs”. For vegetarians, we recommended the delicious “feijoada” of celery, sesame, tsukudani and orange.

Name: Avista
Description: Part of the fabulous The Cliff Bay hotel, Avista is run by the prestigious chef Benoît Sinthon (Il Gallo d'Oro, two Michelin Stars) and, like its older “brother”, boasts truly spectacular views, with the coast, the vast Atlantic Ocean and nearby islands as a backdrop. Here, the cuisine Mediterranean highlights the restaurant’s philosophy of informality in which the idea of sharing plates to enable guests to try more dishes is key, along with a focus on fresh ingredients of the very highest quality.

Name: Zunzum Gastrobar
Address: Avenida Infante D. Henrique. Doca do Jardim do Tabaco, Lisbon, 1100-651, Portugal
Description: This elegant, completely glass-fronted gastro-bar, occupying a modern building close to the city’s cruise ship terminal (and opposite the unusual Museu do Lactário or Milk Station Museum), favours high-quality contemporary cuisine that is based around traditional Portuguese recipes, but without closing the door on inspiration, dishes or techniques from further afield. The bright, designer-inspired interior, with its predominant red and white colour scheme, and the terrace boasting pleasant views of the Tagus come as a pleasant surprise.

Name: Camelo
Address: Rua de Santa Marta 119, Viana do Castelo, 4925-104, Portugal
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: This family-run restaurant is always full despite its location in a part of town most people generally pass through without stopping. Its facilities include a bar, which leads to several pleasantly arranged dining rooms, a large marquee-style space for private functions, plus a huge garden patio for outdoor gatherings. The high-quality and varied cuisine on offer here is typical of the Minho, featuring fish and seafood from its own live tank, with a predilection for lamprey, plus an extensive selection of meat dishes and even a vegetarian menu. When in season, the lamprey dishes are a must!

Name: Carvalho
Description: Located opposite the Tabolado garden and close to the river, in an area with easy parking. Behind the impeccable façade you’ll find a reasonably comfortable and welcoming interior with the main dining room by the entrance and a second space, which is also home to the wine cellar, in the basement. The female owner is at the helm in the kitchen, offering high-quality home-inspired cooking on a menu that changes daily and always includes fresh fish and other typical specialities such as “alheira”, a smoked sausage made with pork and chicken. Superb, friendly service from the front-of-house team completes the picture!

Name: Tasquinha da Linda
Address: Rua dos Mareantes A-10, Viana do Castelo, 4900-351, Portugal
Description: One of the best dining options in this attractive town on the Costa Verde, this contemporary restaurant located next to the Castelo de Santiago da Barra occupies a docks warehouse in which the large attractive fish and seafood tanks take pride of place. Its owners are fish wholesalers, hence the top-quality fish and seafood that is on offer here, normally sold by weight and at prices that are highly competitive. You won’t find a single meat dish on the menu here! Make sure you save space for desserts made by the owners’ daughter!

Name: O Javali
Description: A restaurant that is well run by a couple who are highly passionate about their work, with the husband running the front of house and his wife in charge in the kitchen. Easy to find given its location by the main road, it features a reasonably spacious car park, a public bar and two rustically themed dining rooms, both boasting stone walls and a hunting-inspired decor. Its menu showcases the traditional dishes of the Trás-os-Montes region (including game), all of which are copious and based around the freshest ingredients. Make sure you try the wild boar stew with chestnuts, the rice with hare, and the Bragança-style lamb.

Name: O Típico
Address: Rua Doutor Manuel Alegre 42, Águeda, 3750-139, Portugal
Description: If you’re looking for a typical and authentic dining experience, head for this restaurant in the upper part of town run by a charming married couple. The overall feel is unpretentious with a simple façade and tables set very close together; however, the single dining room boasts a typical regional charm high on detail that includes antique decorative objects and a few farming implements. Here you’ll find a local clientele, 100% Portuguese cooking that is abundant and full of genuine flavours, and delicious home-made desserts. Make sure you try the octopus “à lagareiro” and the cod gratin with “smashed” potatoes!

Name: Dóri
Address: Rua das Companhas, Costa Nova do Prado, 3830-453, Portugal
Description: Situated between the Aveiro estuary and the Atlantic, on the first floor of a contemporary glass-fronted building offering splendid views, particularly from the terrace. The bar features an enticing display cabinet, while the two dining rooms are bright and functional-contemporary in feel. Although the menu includes delicious meats and a few savoury rice dishes, the speciality here is the wild fish, cooked on the open grill, and the seafood. Don’t leave without trying the fried fish (“fritada de pescado”) or the delicious “ensopado” of turbot.

Name: Solar do Forcado
Address: Rua Candido dos Reis 14, Portalegre, 7300-129, Portugal
Description: Located along a narrow, cobbled street in the town’s old quarter, reasonably close to the castle. The modest façade leads to a small but welcoming dining room with a rustic feel and a decor that revolves around the world of bullfighting. Here, the traditional cuisine is focused on meat, with the occasional dish dedicated to bulls in the ring, in homage to the team of “forcados”, a typical aspect of Portuguese bullfights in which both the owner and his father were once involved. Make sure you try the exquisite skewers of bull’s meat, not forgetting the “cozido à portuguesa” stew served every Thursday!

Name: Casal da Penha
Address: Rua Penha de França - Beco do Ataíde n.1, Funchal, 9000-014, Portugal
Description: A family-run restaurant that extols the virtues of all that is simple yet authentic with a menu which lets the ingredients do the talking. Located in the centre of Funchal, surrounded by large hotels, its modest yet neat and tidy dining room is enhanced by the superb terrace upstairs. The father is in charge of the kitchen, where he prepares dishes with a traditional flavour including lots of regional specialities, delicious fish of the day options, an extensive choice of meats, and tasty rice dishes, including a variety of paellas. Make sure you order the clams “à Bulhão Pato” if available – they are truly delicious!

Name: Ofício - Tasco Atípico
Address: Rua Nova da Trindade 11, Lisbon, 1200-301, Portugal
Description: This centrally located restaurant, almost directly opposite the Bairro do Avillez gastronomic complex, defines itself as an "atypical tasco ", where the concept is to offer contemporary Portuguese cuisine perfect for sharing, served in the informal atmosphere of a typical neighbourhood restaurant. Here, you’ll find starters, petiscos, hot specialities, sharing boards and seasonal dishes on the menu, all of which showcase excellent technique, typical flavours and the occasional Mexican touch, given that the chef worked in the famous (and now defunct) Hoja Santa restaurant in Barcelona.

Name: Inato Bistrô
Description: The name of this restaurant stems from In“ATO”, which in Portuguese means something that is active or in movement, a theme continued on the menu where dishes are served in different acts (I, II, III and IV). Young chefs Miguel Rodrigues and Tiago Costa have joined forces to showcase their creative cuisine, which makes full use of the best-quality local ingredients. Located opposite the elegant setting of the municipal square in the heart of Braga, Inato reminds us that it is possible to prepare amazing dishes from the simplest of ingredients.

Name: Solar do Bacalhau
Description: A good location in the Baixa de Coimbra, the section of the old town occupied by merchants and artisans in the Middle Ages. If you’re keen to try the famous Portuguese bacalao you won’t find a better place, as this restaurant impresses with its attractive interior design on two floors, stone walls, a glass-enclosed inner patio and lots of natural light. À la carte and set menu options feature a variety of regional specialities, superb cod dishes cooked in different ways, and a good selection of meats. The display cabinets at the entrance provide a welcoming taster of what’s to come!

Name: Casa Chef Victor Felisberto
Address: Rua Francisco Ferreira da Mata 99, Abrantes, 2200-223, Portugal
Description: Discover the special vision of regional cooking showcased by Victor Felisberto, a Portuguese chef with an impressive track record who trained in Paris and gained experience in restaurants in France as well as others in London, Barcelona and Andorra. His speciality is meat cooked over a wood fire, in particular Iberian pork and veal, with the unique feature of using very slow cooking techniques to ensure sublime textures and much more intense flavours. He favours traditionally inspired dishes, home-made desserts of a high quality and bread made with his own recipe.

Name: 3 Pipos
Address: Rua de Santo Amaro 966, Tonda, 3460-479, Portugal
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The emblem of this restaurant, which is now into its fourth decade and is spoken of very highly by everyone, is three barrels – a reference to its close connection with the wine sector. It features an entrance hall and several dining rooms with a classic-rustic feel and wine-focused decor, in which the menu showcases the cuisine of the Beira Alta region. The simple, copious dishes on offer include pork rice in a garlic and wine sauce, octopus “à lagareiro”, and the loin of confit cod with spinach and pork sausage. The spacious garden and its wine club that sells direct to the public at affordable prices add to its appeal.

Name: O Frade
Description: A small corner restaurant named after the family that owns it. Its interior is evocative of a traditional Alentejo “tasca”, with simple decorative details that highlight the production of the famous “vinho da talha”, a wine with a long historical footprint that, in keeping with Roman tradition, is made in large earthenware amphorae and is a highly renowned wine in the Alentejo. Welcoming service, plus an attractive U-shaped bar popular for dining, where guests can savour a variety of “petiscos”, rice dishes and traditional Alentejo recipes with a contemporary touch – all accompanied by an extensive choice of wines.

Name: In Diferente
Address: Rua do Doutor Sousa Rosa 23, Porto, 4150-719, Portugal
Description: Despite not being in the centre of town or on any of the main tourist routes, it is well worth heading to this peaceful, welcoming and contemporary-style restaurant. Here, Angélica Salvador, the young chef of Brazilian origin, interprets her personal vision of traditional Portuguese and international cooking through dishes that are elaborate and very well presented. Her aim is to create dishes that are different, personal and showcase innovative detail, extracting maximum benefit from the superb fish delivered to the nearby auctions in Matosinhos and Aveiro, as well as from the region’s outstanding meats.

Name: Semea by Euskalduna
Description: This restaurant has improved in every respect following its move to the banks of the Douro – it has gained space, consolidated its culinary philosophy, and now boasts the added benefit of views of the river. The cuisine here, which includes rice dishes cooked in a wood-fired oven, is based around the grill and open fire, using local seasonal ingredients to create dishes that, although uncomplicated, are full of flavour and feature a strong focus on presentation. The restaurant’s other attractions include the delightful panoramic terrace on the first floor.

Name: Xtoria
Address: Rua Guilherme Gomes Fernandes 17, Setúbal, 2900-395, Portugal
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Brunch,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: You may not be aware that fried cuttlefish is one of Setúbal’s most typical dishes. So, it’s not by chance that this restaurant is barely 200 metres from the statue of the “Fried Cuttlefish”, where you’ll also find a mural featuring fish found in the waters around the city. Understandably, cuttlefish features strongly on the menu at Xtoria, where it is prepared in a unique way and with a hint of modernity. Affordably priced dishes that you won’t want to miss include the cuttlefish with ponzu, black potato, sriracha mayonnaise and lumpfish caviar; the Mertolenga beef loin with tuna sabayon and Eringy mushrooms in port wine; and, to round things off, the cardamom cream with a ginger cookie and mango chutney.

Name: Olaias
Address: Rua Abade Pedro 2, Figueira da Foz, 3080 081, Portugal
Description: This is a restaurant that provides you with an excuse to return at any time of year… and why not! The house speciality, the savoury Carolino rice (with rice grown in the Mondego valley), changes constantly with the seasons, and is cooked in a clay oven, which brings added flavour. We recommend starting with the mouthwatering and smooth Rissol da Tia Fernanda, which is absolutely delicious. Next, it has to be rice, of course (with any accompaniment – duck, fish or oxtail – all are excellent choices) and, to finish, the moist “pão de ló” cake with sea salt, which is truly heavenly. The restaurant is located in the Centro de Artes e Espectáculos and has a meticulous yet unpretentious decor, featuring floor to ceiling windows and fantastic views!

Name: O Pastus
Address: Avenida Marquês De Pombal 5, Paço de Arcos, 2770-066, Portugal
Description: This modest yet charming restaurant opposite the Paço de Arcos gardens is characterised by great enthusiasm, painstaking service and the hard work of young Annakaren Fuentes, who is on top of everything. The cooking here can be defined as modern Portuguese, based around respect for traditional ingredients and flavours, showcased in one tasting menu, entitled Cabal (7 courses). Individual dishes can also be ordered à la carte.

Name: Vila do Peixe
Address: Rua Doutor João Abel de Freitas 30-A, Câmara de Lobos, 9300-048, Portugal
Description: An ideal lunch or dinner option for visitors given its location in the upper section of the old town (opposite the municipal market) and its huge windows boasting superb views of both the bay and the ocean. If you’re looking for authentic maritime-inspired cooking and fresh fish caught the same day you won’t find a better option, as guests can choose the piece of fish they want to eat as if they were in the market; the fish is then weighed in front of you and cooked immediately on the grill. Typical dishes well worth sampling, if available, are the popular limpets and sea snails.

Name: Carnal
Description: This lively, centrally located restaurant has quickly become fashionable given that it is owned by famous chef Ljubomir Stanisic (head of the 100 Maneiras group). Carnal describes itself as a Mexican gastro-bar, and is one of those places that immediately appeals to the senses. In its informal, modern design setting featuring subtle details relating to Mexican culture, enjoy harmonious, well-thought-out cooking with a perfect balance between flavour and spiciness in every one of its superb dishes. Don’t miss the delicious pork tacos or the tacos with fried cauliflower.

Name: Gruta
Address: Rua De Santa Catarina 447, Porto, 4000-452, Portugal
Description: Gruta’s is one of those of places where you can eat well at a reasonable price. To a backdrop of stylish yet informal decor and a setting in an alleyway just off a shopping street, chef Rafaela Louzada, a Carioca from Rio but with Portuguese roots, focuses on a concise menu on which fish and seafood (mainly from the north of the country) take centre stage. Her dishes are high on presentation and flavour, combining Brazilian and Portuguese influences and a contemporary style of cooking.

Name: Marquês de Marialva
Description: The name pays a small homage to this Portuguese nobleman who played a decisive part in several battles during the Restoration War. The restaurant enjoys a certain prestige as well as a good location in an old house that has been restored. It boasts three intimate dining rooms combining classic and rustic decorative detail, one with an open fire, plus a large function room upstairs. Dishes with a distinct traditional flavour can be found on the à la carte, alongside several tasting menus. Make sure you try the “lagareiro”-style baked cod and the exquisite roast kid!

Name: Machado
Address: Rua Doutor António José de Almeida 467, Nogueira, 4475-456, Portugal
Description: Quality and quantity are both guaranteed at this restaurant occupying an old house in a small village close to Maia. Several separate dining rooms, all with a similar rustic decor, simple table settings and lots of typical decorative details hanging from the walls. Here, it is impossible to leave hungry given the copious portions on the traditional home-cooked menu which teems with local flavours. Make sure you try Machado’s house speciality, the Lafões-style roast veal.

Name: Pátio 44
Address: Passeio De São Lázaro, 44, Porto, 4000 507, Portugal
Description: At Patio 44, you’ll be pleasantly surprised by the quality of ingredients used as well as the discreet and simple façade. This project was created by three friends, with chefs Simão Soares and Alfonso Ramos in charge of the kitchen – a partnership that developed from experience working together in a previous restaurant. Their cuisine is centred around traditional Portuguese cuisine enhanced by modern techniques and unique flavours. Standout dishes include the cod “punheta” with crunchy rice, followed by a vegetarian option (tofu and mushrooms with a mouthwatering demi-glace) and an impressive fresh cod prepared with a smooth chickpea purée. To finish, we highly recommend the spectacular “pão de ló” sponge cake fresh out of the oven, served with goat’s cheese ice-cream. The reasonable prices here are another pleasant surprise!

Name: Flora
Description: Dishes such as spicy polenta with fennel pickle, confit cod, white trevally fish from the Azores and, to finish, the banana treacle ice cream with liquorice-flavoured rice pudding, are accompanied by a choice of "low intervention, biodynamic and organic wines" that are high on quality. This oasis of creativity can be found in a tiny contemporary bistro in Viseu’s historic centre, where it is run by João Guedes in the kitchen and Anna front of house.

Name: PODA
Description: PODA occupies an old agricultural warehouse that has been completely remodelled and decorated in rustic style with a plethora of wood. Chef João Narigueta and his long-term friend Miguel Dominguinhos have joined together to open this dining space in which the traditional cooking of the Alentejo has undergone a renaissance. One of the classic dishes on the menu is the typical “migas gatas” with cod, which is simply presented but with surprising flavour. Another typical regional dish is “enxovalhada”, a sponge cake filled with walnuts and honey and sprinkled with cinnamon. The wine list mainly features local producers.

Name: Rio by Paulo André
Address: Praça da República 8, Vila do Conde, 4480-715, Portugal
Description: A young and informal eatery with an open-view kitchen located at one end of Praça da República, one of Vila do Conde’s most beautiful squares thanks to its setting on the banks of the Ave river. In a nod to the name of his restaurant, chef Paulo André’s professional career is as surprising and unexpected as the meanders in a river! His cisHisontemporary-style cooking will definitely leave its mark given his passion, technical skill and a strong desire to please, plus a continual focus on using locally sourced vegetables (vegetarian dishes feature on the menu), fish and meat. If the weather’s fine, make sure you eat on the terrace.

Name: Kok Sur Mer
Description: Established in a handsome villa-cum-cottage, Jean-Philippe Furnémont’s traditional know-how is in the masterclass category, illustrated by flawlessly cooked beef fillet, exquisite noisette butter served with North Sea sole or explosively fresh tartar of seabass. Each dish bears the signature of this audacious chef. The formula menu is rich in enticing discoveries.

Name: Père et Mère
Description: Mum and dad, Ria and Frans, are food and cooking mad! Which is why they opened this welcoming, stylish bistro next - door to their son’s bakery, delicatessen and community hall. The menu features classical dishes that are fast becoming a rarity: rabbit in prunes or pig’s cheeks in Trappiste beer. Generous portions, oozing with flavour – hearty, wholesome, country cooking at its best!

Name: Le Cabochon
Address: Boulevard Emile de Laveleye 191, Liège, 4020, Belgium
Cuisine: Modern French, Cuisine from the Marches
Description: Le Cabochon is always a safe bet for a slap-up lunch in downtown Liège. The concise selection of dishes on the set menu is flanked by daily suggestions that vary according to the seasons and market availability. Traditional textbook technique (such as mouth-wateringly tender beef cheeks and subtle homemade sauces) is married with side dishes oozing with an abundance of diverse influences. Food that hits the spot every time, to the delight of its many regulars.

Name: Le Variétés
Description: Le Variétés is steeped in the Art deco elegance of the Flagey “ocean liner” edifice, an iconic work by architect Joseph Diongre. Exotic wood dominates the sleek brasserie interior, while the terrace plunges you into the buzzy vibe of this lively district. Roast chicken is the house specialty, but the menu boasts a host of other dishes, including a patriotic line-up of Belgian family favourites: tomatoes stuffed with shrimp and vol-au-vent. All the food is down-to-earth, generous and steeped in flavour.

Name: Jeux de Goûts
Description: A warm, cosy restaurant flanked by comfortable guestrooms deep in the Luxembourg Ardennes. The scene is set for you to be pampered by Fanny and Jérôme. He adds a modern twist to recipes, rich in bona fide Gallic overtones. Organic, local and traditional ingredients take pride of place on the menu. Refreshing food that pays tribute to the region’s heritage and generosity.

Name: Monsieur V
Description: Jan Verhaert cooks what he himself likes to eat: traditional Gallic dishes with the occasional nod to Italy. His cosy neighbourhood restaurant specialises in bistro classics such as pâté en croûte and risotto with seasonal vegetables, and crispy millefeuille with vanilla-rich crème pâtissière for dessert. The flawless precision of the cooking and the chef's penchant for gutsy flavours are truly noteworthy. A champion of French culinary tradition, Monsieur Verhaert delivers exceptional food at a price that won't break the bank.

Name: Station 3
Description: Station 3 is a no-frills restaurant serving up popular specialties from the diverse Chinese culinary landscape. Rich sauces, exotic seasonings, and occasional bursts of sweet and sour are combined with a sure hand. The sea bass steamed whole and paired with an exquisite sauce based on rice vinegar and soy sauce is a must-try for any seafood lover. With so many lobster dishes and vegetarian options to choose from, you're sure to find something to your taste. The har gow – steamed dim sum – are made fresh using traditional methods and delicately seasoned with ginger. A golden opportunity to discover Chinese generosity in all its glory!

Name: La Charcuterie
Description: The vintage charm of this former butcher's with its olde worlde tiles and wood panelling is eminently friendly. Walk past the delicatessen-cum-grocery store counter into the teeny bistro. Premium produce, wholesome, unpretentious cooking and mind-blowing flavours. Dishes to share, washed down with a glass of fine wine.

Name: Garde Manger
Description: Picture a traditional Ardennes edifice in the Samson Valley whose interior is cosily pleasant and homely… Garde Manger (“larder” in English) inevitably brings a smile to our lips, which is largely thanks to the inspired recipes of Christophe Durand. He subtly reinterprets the authentic flavours of foie gras and juicy cuts of beef, pairing them with deftly crafted side dishes such as seaweed or an espuma of Belgian Herve cheese that add a fascinating kick to the main ingredient. All that remains is to try and solve the dilemma of choosing between the enticing à la carte and set menus…

Name: La Marelle Café
Description: Over 500 beers, an enticing menu and bargain prices: fans of traditional fare will love this bustling bolthole. Rather than fussy frills, you can expect unpretentious, authentic grub: homemade terrine, croquettes of calf’s tongue, Belgium’s version of steak tartare and chips (with mayonnaise and horse meat)… La Marelle Café is a goldmine of nostalgic recipes and flavours.

Name: Au gré des Saisons
Description: Welcome to the achingly scenic village of Achet in Condroz, the location of an excellent eatery, clad in characteristic Ardennes stone. Gregorio Clavello adds a subtle twist to his Italian roots, rustling up flavoursome modern dishes. Mediterranean tangs and a few judicious oriental notes perfume the food that respects seasonal availability. Balanced, authentic, delicious!

Name: Moonstone
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Great view,Wheelchair access
Description: An illuminated moon sculpture dominates the grey colour scheme, hence the name. The setting is further enhanced by the view over the golf course. Chef Roos masterfully celebrates premium produce such as lamb and pheasant, which he crafts into dishes that hit the spot every time, exalting familiar flavours that are also pure, rich and expressive. Don’t miss the extensive market menu!

Name: Car Bon
Description: Don’t be fooled by the cliché of a tightly packed neighbourhood eatery with an extensive menu and mainly Asian clientele, because Car Bon has plenty of other succulent appeals up its sleeve. The food is authentic, with a focus on the Sichuan region. Wonton pork and veal with a chili oil that adds a subtle spicy note. Gutsy, light and assertive all at once, Chinese cuisine that hits the spot every time. Don’t forget to book!

Name: Chez Chen Wépion
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Chinese restaurant on the banks of the Meuse. Exterior made from local stone, bright dining room with just a hint of an Asian feel to it, view of the river thanks to the large bay windows.

Name: Le Coin des Saveurs
Description: In this lively “corner” restaurant, Michel Norga deploys his wide-ranging talents; proof of which you can admire in the interior he helped renovate. In the kitchen, his attention to detail is unwavering, transforming each dish into a triumph of creativity and culinary skill. Head for the terrace in fine weather.

Name: Kline
Description: The brutalist concrete interior of the hip Kline restaurant is perfectly matched to the casual dining vibe. Unusual, unpretentious recipes and a few vegetarian options. Plancha-seared gherkin is paired with cream of smoked yoghurt, mustard seeds, dill, chunks of goat’s cheese and curry oil. “Locally sourced and globally inspired” (their own words) is the ethos of this zero-waste, sustainable establishment firmly in the zeitgeist.

Name: Plat préféré
Description: Are you a fan of fine Flemish fare and time-honoured bistro classics? If so, you can probably bet that your favourite dish will be on the menu here. Chef Gouwy bends over backwards to satisfy his guests and his disarmingly simple, wholesome menu is a treat for foodies: fresh fish served with risotto and beurre blanc – what could be better? The elegant, gilded bicycle that stands next to the kitchen, the chef’s own handiwork, will convince you of his deft craftsmanship.

Name: Olijfboom
Description: Highly polished silverware, a fantastic collection of bottles and knickknacks set the quirky, antique dealer interior of Olijfboom, so you won’t be surprised to learn that the chef is a keen collector of vintage chinaware. However, his main talent is regaling us with old-school cooking. In keeping with tradition, he unfussily enhances the ingredient which he serves generously, focusing on the flavour. An impressive wine list completes this fine dining experience.

Name: Mona Lisa
Address: Rue du Colonel Tachet des Combes 19, Yvoir, 5530, Belgium
Description: A Grimaldi pizza oven immediately catches the eye as you enter this modern eatery, but, make no mistake, you are light years from your run-of-the-mill pizzeria. The Mona Lisa is helmed by two couples of Sicilian parentage, who are proud of their first-rate produce and of lovingly crafting old-fashioned Italian recipes. The pizzas are made entirely from premium ingredients, such as culaccia ham and Caseificio D’Elia mozzarella di bufala. The gutsy flavours of the ravioli explode in the mouth, underscored by a creamy burrata, while the signature chocolate dessert is deliciously balanced. We highly recommend the set menu with options.

Name: Bar Bask
Description: Gent now has a trendy tapas bar in the shape of Bar Bask. After perusing the long refrigerated counter piled high with seafood treats, you will make your way to the heat of the open fire to choose one of the many dishes to share of Basque inspiration: pinchos, spit roast turbot or a juicy slice of chistorra… A festival from the Basque country! Exciting flavours and subtle sauces, all of which at eater-friendly prices.

Name: Parc Le'h
Address: 1 rue de la Forêt, Dudelange, 3471, Luxembourg
Description: This trendy brasserie, done up in wood and other natural materials, is in perfect osmosis with the surrounding Dudelange forest. It is run by a veteran who takes the time to listen to his guests. Jean-Charles Albert’s pared-back cuisine is subtle, often surprising but never disconcerting. He may marry creamy risotto, truffles and a skate wing fritter or jazz up steak tartare with Thai or oriental notes, all the while respecting their intrinsic flavours. Something of a culinary landmark in the region.

Name: l'Epicurien
Description: Sébastien Brela is a true food lover. His passion for fine ingredients is obvious as soon as you peruse the menu. Distinctive flavours play a central role, while generous sauces add a punchy twist. Unexpected associations and textures create a genuine surprise. The fixed-price menus demonstrate that it is possible to be a gourmet food lover without breaking the bank!

Name: Masu
Description: Masu is a bubbly eatery, just like Maxime and Sullivan, the colourful fresco and the cool vibes of the DJ’s soundtrack: youthful, funky and laidback! Every month, the duo of creative craftsmen concocts a new menu that keeps pace with the seasons, often drawing on their binchotan barbecue to add whoomph to inspired recipes. Examples include grilled corn on the cob with a spicy sauce and sweet-sour rings of shallots (the epitome of finger food, of course). It’s party time every day at Masu.

Name: Maïnoï
Description: Whilst refreshingly modern, Maïnoï nonetheless remains true to its traditional roots and the characteristic Thai interior creates a warm, welcoming vibe. The seasoned chef deftly crafts exuberant familiar flavours and cannot be rivalled for his way with sauces, jazzing up beef and vegetable side dishes, for example, with flair and talent. The creative menu is bold and daring and pleasant surprises await the diner. We recommend sampling the house signature dishes, marked up on the board.

Name: Bazaar
Description: A hint of Beirut, a whiff of Athens, together with a gust of Tel Aviv and Marrakech: this bustling restaurant brings together the best of the Mediterranean. Kick off your meal with a fresh cocktail and houmous or a mezze, before sharing a roast chicken. Spices and fruity flavours subtly underscore each dish. We must admit to having fallen head over heels with the grilled aubergine in tahini, candied garlic and peaches – to die for!

Name: Nr.12 by Helsen
Description: You don't even need to step inside to realise that Nr.12 is the hippest restaurant on Grote Markt. It also serves the most delicious food! Veteran chef Frédéric Helsen is a dab hand at rustling up dishes to share (of which we wager you will order too many, so vast is the choice!). He puts his own playful yet fuss-free spin on classic recipes to delight our taste buds. Think succulent boudin blanc with a subtle madeira sauce, or pan-fried plaice with crab and a rich beurre blanc: the menu is sure to make any foodie's heart race. Craving more? Chef Helsen's vending machine (Meidoornlaan 1, Herentals) is open seven days a week.

Name: L'Incontournable
Description: What does it take to create a Bib Gourmand restaurant? Fresh ingredients, sourced locally if possible (here, they are listed on the menu). Consummate technique. This could be the ability to whip up a classic pepper sauce to accompany a fillet of venison, or slightly more playful ideas such as Jerusalem artichoke and chorizo croquettes combined with scallops and a butter sauce with orange. Of course, value for money is also key. And that is precisely why this warm and welcoming restaurant, with father Stéphane in the kitchen and son Loïk front-of-house, is such an exemplary Bib.

Name: Nénu
Description: It is neither its sober contemporary décor nor its casual vibe that set Nénu apart from the many restaurants in the Avenue Louise neighbourhood, but its anh nhau concept. This Vietnamese tradition consists in sharing small and large dishes and a fine bottle of wine with friends and family. The kitchen team adds a modern twist to traditional flavours, creating a mouth-watering menu (choose at least three dishes). Spicy wontons, vegetarian red curry, grilled salmon head with sweet-sour flavours and traditional spices…Superlative Vietnamese fusion cooking…

Name: Le Faitout
Address: place de la Résistance 1, Baudour, 7331, Belgium
Description: Pull up a chair on the delightful terrace and enjoy the lively and infectious ambience of the Faitout. The menu features traditional recipes: Ardennes pork, grilled meats, country terrines and seafood platters… Authenticity and generosity above all else! Take your pick from the varied choice on the menu (with a range of prices), you won’t be disappointed. Open 7 days a week!

Name: Trattoria Bazalia
Description: The Italian sibling of Hofke van Bazel is upstairs from the Michelin star establishment. Its romantic interior is perfect for a dinner for two, possibly alfresco on the patio overlooking a pretty church. Ingredients from Puglia take the limelight, but the chef also celebrates other regions of Italy. Just the ticket for an authentic vitello tonnato, ossobuco or tiramisu, prepared with Italian passion. Extensive menu (also veggie dishes).

Name: Den Duyventooren
Description: The spruce, traditional façade of this ancestral farmstead hides a vibrant modern interior. The peaceful terrace is bliss on hot summer days. The establishment has acquired a faithful cohort of regulars, attracted by the set menus and Inge Herteleer’s enticing carte. Her seasonal cooking throbs with traditional generosity and is dotted with contemporary touches. The shrimp fritters are stuffed to the brim, while a subtle champagne sauce enhances pheasant. Searingly good food!

Name: Au Tour du Vin
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: While wine may not be the only ingredient on the menu, it is clearly a prominent feature of this cheerful bustling bistro. The expert sommelier’s wine selection (excellent tips) is perfectly paired with the creative bistro fare. The chef is a dab hand at reinventing Gallic classics, without forgetting his surprising ‘light’ version of pizza. Bold, spot-on cooking every time. We also recommend the next-door ice cream parlour.

Name: Le Charme de la Semois
Description: The picturesque Semois river and valley set the scene for this delightful riverside Ardennes country inn. The interior is amusingly adorned with a collection of hens, bringing the promise of bygone flavours on the menu. Fiercely traditional, the food is simple and generous and will delight lovers of authentic fare.

Name: Robertissimo
Description: Be forewarned – once you have experienced the joyful vibe and flair of this lively establishment, you will be yearning to return again and again! The big-hearted chef skilfully and generously rustles up genuine Italian fare: immaculately cooked calf’s liver in a gutsy jus served with al dente pasta in butter. Bravissimo for this autentico banquet of Italian delicacies designed to appeal to discerning foodies!

Name: La Branche d'Olivier
Description: With its old tiled floor and leather seats, patinated woodwork, plus the peaceful terrace overlooking Kinsendaal Nature Reserve, this charming bistro is full of character. The many regulars come here to feast on classics such as foie gras maison, cod fillet in a chorizo crust with a saffron white wine sauce, and chocolate mousse for dessert. It is not without good reason that chef Demurger is hailed as a great sauce maker and rôtisseur. This Bib Gourmand restaurant is all about craftsmanship and generosity.

Name: Des Ardennes
Address: rue de la Hate 1, Corbion, 6838, Belgium
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: The Maqua family’s charming hotel has been welcoming guests in the Ardennes since 1900 and several generations continue to work in the family establishment. The peaceful rooms overlook the rolling countryside, while in the restaurant, the accent is on satisfying French favourites, albeit in keeping with today’s tastebuds. The cooking is spot on and flavoursome. Splendid wine cellar.

Name: Le Bistrot d'en Face
Address: rue de la Goffe 8, Liège, 4000, Belgium
Description: A nostalgic friendly vibe and good food are the backbone of this inviting local version of a “bouchon lyonnais”. The traditional, extensive menu takes you back in time with dishes such as confit of duck and salardaise potatoes or boulets à la liégoise (meatballs) – among the best in town! Heartwarming, no-nonsense food, served generously and prepared with respect for time-honoured recipes. Spot on every time.

Name: Au Cœur de Lacuisine
Address: rue du Fond des Naux 7, Lacuisine, 6821, Belgium
Description: The sleepy village of Lacuisine makes the perfect base camp to explore the Ardennes. Don’t miss Ronny and Christel’s stylish establishment which combines a friendly vibe with modern comforts. The chef cooks regional produce, most of which from scratch, with lashings of generosity. For example, you may taste a terrine of foie gras with smoked duck magret or a fillet of plaice with a pastis-flavoured jus. The enticing range of set menus means that there is something to suit every palate. Even better, stay overnight and jump into the pool before or after breakfast next morning.

Name: Enoteca
Address: rue de la Casquette 5, Liège, 4000, Belgium
Description: You will immediately feel at home at the Enoteca, which is depicted by tightly packed tables, a friendly vibe and cheerful service. Food lovers have been flocking here for over thirty years, lured by the unbeatable value for money and the text-book perfect Italian nosh. Farfalle al dente with fresh shrimp, preserved lemons and a knockout tomato sauce – authenticity is the goal! Order the chef’s daily special with your eyes closed and don’t forget the enticing wine list.

Name: Le Moulin
Address: rue de la Lesse 61, Daverdisse, 6929, Belgium
Description: This former watermill is a charming place to experience the beauty of the Ardennes, starting with the view of the babbling river and the typical façade. Inside, cosiness is the order of the day. This is a family-run business, with a mother-and-son team providing friendly service front-of-house. In the kitchen, chef Ludovic puts a subtle modern spin on his father Jean-Pierre's classic cuisine – savour a rich game consommé with venison shank, or scallop ceviche. Foodies will be delighted by the extensive à la carte selection and set menus. Quiet guestrooms available for a pleasant overnight stay.

Name: Durbuy Ô
Description: This friendly restaurant (which also offers accommodation) is idyllically located to explore the picturesque small town of Durbuy. You will feel right at home here thanks to the family-run vibe and attentive care lavished by chef Timmerman on his guests. The pedigree French repertory is enhanced by local produce, such as scallops and venison. The chef treats all his ingredients with the utmost respect, further enhancing the experience with fascinating sauces and side dishes.

Name: Le Confessionnal
Description: Opposite Leffe Abbey, this nostalgic neighbourhood bolthole provides a showcase for the owner’s passion for flea markets. Red and white checked tablecloths, decorative soup tureens and silverware set the friendly scene. The traditional fare oozes with the charm of yesteryear and the regularly changing menu offers an array of hearty, traditional dishes, such as duck leg à la bourguignonne or roast shoulder of lamb with garlic confit. Hunger obliterating food free of fussy frills and a treasure trove of French wines at prices that make sense.

Name: Osteria Bolognese
Address: rue de la Paix 49, Ixelles, 1050, Belgium
Description: Giacomo’s mission is to correct the hackneyed image of ‘spag bol’ and his mouth - watering tagliatelle al ragù does just that! All his ingredients are sourced direct from Emilia Romagna, ensuring an explosion of flavour in the mouth. A delightful Osteria that will introduce you to the real taste of Bologna.

Name: Cadre Culinaire
Description: In addition to hailing from Alsace, Grégory Baruthio avows a passion for pastries, as you will soon realise, and his Gugelhupf is truly second to none! Ever enthusiastic, the chef dons his apron to enhance ingredients that suit the modern palate without losing sight of high-precision cooking and traditional generosity. A welcoming establishment with eater friendly prices.

Name: L'Espièglerie
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: Since 1988, gourmets have been making a beeline for this romantic hideaway, whose old vaults and bare brick walls lend it masses of cachet. Choose from the daily special or the menu to sample rich authentic food that has earned the establishment its well-deserved reputation as a fine dining venue. Succulent pheasant pie with crisp veal sweetbread or an unusual cannelloni of confit pear with fresh fruit. Sensibly priced. Splendid selection of beers and Bordeaux wines.

Name: Le Tournant
Description: The lively, vibrant Matongé district is home to an equally buzzy neighbourhood eatery: Le Tournant. People drop in to sample a glass of “natural” wine (trust the sommelier – he knows his job!) and dig into unfussy, nostalgic dishes reminiscent of grandma’s cooking, together with a few more modern bistro recipes. Examples include gutsy beef cheeks braised in Orval beer or lamb in dried figs. Every dish is an authentic festival of flavour!

Name: Le Saint Boniface
Cuisine: Cuisine from South West France, Country cooking
Description: Picture tightly packed tables, red and white chequered tablecloths, a collection of biscuit tins and French songs and jazz playing in the background: the scene is set in this friendly welcoming bistro. The locals flock here to sample its specialities from the Basque Country, Lyon and Southwest France. Calf’s brain and tartare sauce, confit of duck leg, veal sweetbread and kidneys rich in regional flavours. Heart-warming authentic nosh steeped in traditional Gallic generosity!

Name: Les Potes en Toque
Description: This renovated farm cottage in the heart of a residential neighbourhood is depicted by a characteristic Belgian blend of rural chic. The menu majors in flawlessly prepared brasserie favourites, served generously.

Name: Cul de Poule
Description: A colourful, cartoon-inspired chicken adorns this small bistro, but the real draw is Arnaud Molle. This seasoned chef lets his creativity run riot in regularly changing menus with a Gallic slant. His food is flavoursome, original and ideally suited to make the most of fresh produce. His flawlessly cooked pheasant served with a creamy Fine Champagne cognac sauce is to die for! The meat, from his parent’s butchery, is first class and the prices are truly eater friendly – what more can we say?

Name: De Vous à Nous
Address: rue de Grand Bry 42, Montigny-le-Tilleul, 6110, Belgium
Description: De Vous à Nous (From You to Us) sports a stylish interior, a peaceful, lush green landscape and eater-friendly prices. The know-how and generosity of chef François Duvivier are outstanding and he doesn’t hesitate to add a personal flourish to traditional recipes, such as croquettes of pheasant, pigeon with a gutsy sauce or Belle Hélène pear jus that will knock your socks off! A safe bet every time!

Name: Au Petit Château
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: This endearing villa has, quite rightly, been a firm culinary fixture of Mouscron for eons and its infectiously friendly vibe is nurtured by the cheerful lady of the house. The traditional menu, which features the occasional modern tribute, always hits the spot. Carpaccio of sea bream, frog’s legs, Rossini tournedos… 100% French recipes that pay tribute to the finest traditions of culinary know-how and generosity.

Name: Villa Singha
Address: rue des Trois Ponts 22, Auderghem, 1160, Belgium
Description: Villa Singha is a proud ambassador of Thai traditions. A characteristic Thai decor and references to the mythological lion, Singha, set the exotic scene, further enhanced by an extensive mouth-watering menu. Crispy Po Pia Tod fried spring rolls and Thai dumplings stuffed with ground pork are a few of the generously crafted and perfectly seasoned and spiced dishes. A word of advice – don’t forget to book.

Name: Maza'j
Description: Maza'j serves dishes bursting with bold colours and exciting flavours. The tables here are decked with authentic Lebanese specialities that delight diners with their distinctive spiciness and generosity. Velvety hummus with pine nuts, barbecued minced lamb with a delicately sweet bell pepper confit, an array of vegetables elevated by a blend of aromatic herbs… You and your dining companions can look forward to sharing a real feast in a convivial atmosphere. Experience the richness of Lebanese culinary tradition!

Name: Le Grand Maur
Description: An air of romantic nostalgia reigns throughout this charming small Ardennes castle. Ideally located for a spot of sight-seeing in Spa, the castle also serves a bang-up meal. The attractive range of dishes demonstrates the chef’s passion for first-class produce, which he prepares generously, flanked by polished side dishes and subtle sauces.

Name: Vilain
Description: Vilain offers a choice of 10 to 15 dishes to share, which often change weekly in line with the seasons and the suppliers and sports an irresistible vintage vibe, overflowing in good cheer and boasting a lovely garden for alfresco dining. The occasional international twist jazzes up the traditional pageant: butternut ravioles with ricotta, jus of bacon and walnuts. Sharing such delicacies can pose quite a dilemma!

Name: Onslow
Description: Onslow, a buzzy landmark in the peaceful Sint Anna district, offers casual dining and a terrace bathed in Mediterranean charm. Its international menu with a host of tasty dishes to share is extremely popular with the locals. Lieven Vynck whisks us off to Nice with a pissaladière that is a perfect balance between caramelised onions, anchovies, olives, thyme and lemon peel, unless you would rather sample the fresh, spicy, acidic tang of a mouthwatering ceviche. A feast of flavour awaits you at Onslow: “Food with Drinks, Drinks with Food” is their baseline!

Name: Au Phil des Saveurs
Description: A quick look at the pool and garden overlooking the countryside confirms the holiday vibe as soon as you set foot inside Phil Garcia’s HQ. The food features an intelligent blend of classical cooking techniques with Mediterranean influences. He offers a new spin on vitello tonnato with cod cooked on the skin, flanked by a velvety mousseline of mashed potato and leek oil. Enticing set menus and the cheerful relaxed service of the lady of the house add the final flourish to this fine dining portrait.

Name: Les 4 Saisons
Description: The charm of this Ardennes house is encapsulated by the landscaped garden, providing the perfect foil to the warm, inviting interior. Ingredients take the star role in gutsy nostalgic recipes, albeit with a scattering of refreshing creative twists. For example, the chef’s perfectly cooked veal in truffles with Asian flavours. The menu with options is a model of full-bodied generosity. Deliciously eater friendly prices!

Name: il était une fois toi et moi
Description: Looking for the perfect romantic spot? Look no further: this restaurant ticks all the boxes, starting with the name! A smart lounge interior serves as the backdrop to an exciting culinary story. The extensive menu, which offers made-to-measure options, combines traditional Gallic recipes and more contemporary offerings. The food is both inspired and suave, whilst remaining reassuringly familiar.

Name: Ferment
Description: A drop-dead wine list, a knock-out collection of authentic local beers and updated family favourites to share: this bustling restaurant on Lennik market square attracts foodies like bees to honey! They swarm here for shrimp fritters, melt-in-the-mouth asparagus (served with melted butter, finely chopped hard-boiled eggs and parsley), grilled sea bass and a host of other delectable morsels. Generous home-made cooking that shines the spotlight on local produce and know-how.

Name: L'épicerie Nomad
Description: Cosmopolitan par excellence, Brussels’ international character is emblematic of this bustling eatery which features tightly packed tables and a slate menu that makes no distinction between starters and main courses. How about a fresh, bitter ceviche of seabass with mango and passion fruit, a Spanish zarzuela of seafood, or shakshuka - a vegetarian one-pan savoury dish? The chef’s creativity, which knows no bounds, is further enhanced by his superlative knack for marrying flavours. Pair this culinary journey with one of the carefully curated tipples to make the most of this fascinating experience.

Name: Le Sixième
Description: There is something for everyone in this modern bistro. Chef Clément draws his inspiration from top-notch ingredients, to which he adds a subtle personal spin. Asian influences, the authentic flavour of marinated beetroot, a velvety beurre blanc and the subtle smoky hints of the wood-fired Josper oven… Splendid harmonies and great value for money. A word of advice: if you would prefer a more romantic vibe, ask for a table in the second room.

Name: Magnific
Description: Lounge music in the background, trendy urban wall graffiti and the warm hospitality of Limburg: a meal at Magnific is always a treat. All the more so, as the chef cleverly juggles with French and Italian recipes, throwing in the odd Asian theme. Whether you start with cannelloni or continue with a venison steak and a cranberry sauce, you can rely on the stellar craftsmanship and full-bodied flavours to come up trumps every time! The set menu with choices is highly recommended.

Name: Bienvenue
Description: John van Leerzem is a fan of tradition and of the ingredient before all else. This institution on the main square of Maaseik does far more than showcase time-honoured classics. The chef happily subverts traditional recipes, particularly thanks to carefully devised side dishes, such as a terrine of veal cheek and tongue that he subtly contrasts with sweet-sour chutney. His stamp can also be tasted in the tournedos and stroganoff sauce that strikes a perfect balance of flavours. A feast for foodies!

Name: Au Dos de la Cuillère
Description: The establishment has been treated to a (forced) makeover after the flooding of 2021 but has lost none of its charm. The chef specialises in Gallic cuisine with a fondness for local ingredients, such as Herve cheese and pork from the Tabreux farm. Everything is generous and homemade, even the praline of the decadent Paris-Brest pastry. Don’t forget to book!

Name: La Table du Boucher
Description: Luc Broutard avows a passion for top quality produce, red meat in particular, as you will immediately realise when you cross the threshold of this buzzy brasserie. Seared foie gras, tartare of Salers beef, marinated pork cheeks or grilled tenderloin: carnivores will be in seventh heaven as they drool over the extensive menu. Rich, spot-on cooking, happily free of gimmicks and there are even a few fish dishes. Everyone feels at home at the Table du Boucher, to such an extent that many return in their droves.

Name: Comptoir de l'Eau Vive
Address: place des Jardins de Baseilles 14, Erpent, 5101, Belgium
Description: Trendy and buzzy, this small eatery is the epitome of a Bib Gourmand. Whether you go for one of the classics on the à la carte menu (like meatballs in tomato sauce or rib of beef with fries) or for the more modern set menu (featuring Mediterranean ingredients such as mullet), all the food is depicted by wholesome, instantly recognisable flavours. The wine list and the sommelier’s suggestions are greatly appreciated, as is the possibility of purchasing cheese and wine, in particular, from the shop. One final word of advice: take a seat at the counter if available, you’re in for a treat!

Name: Arti'Choc
Description: The welcoming interior and Katja’s warm personality provide the perfect foil to this friendly modern stube. Chef Daniel is a fan of fine produce, such as trout and sweetbreads, that he pampers and enhances in traditional recipes. Expect rich flavours and authentic sauces rather than prissy details. You can even take a few preserves and liqueurs home.

Name: l'Amitié
Description: When you arrive in this fully renovated bistro, it won’t be friendship, but something more akin to love that you will feel. Fish takes pride of place and the first class ingredients are prepared according to modern techniques and served in small dishes. Scrumptious!

Name: Strofilia
Address: rue du Marché aux Porcs 11, Brussels, 1000, Belgium
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: This always-bustling establishment near the fish market is a hub of authentic Greek hospitality and generosity. Whether you come as a couple or a large group, everyone gets the attention they deserve. The menu features a whole host of delicious mezze to choose from. Tamara with sourdough bread, tender octopus with fava beans, a salad of green lentils with smoked herring, orange and sultanas… This authentic food is packed with vibrant, honest flavours that hit the spot every time. The wine list features an impressive range of Greek options that won't break the bank.

Name: L'Echappée Belle
Description: The quintessence of a Bib Gourmand, this eatery is embodied by Grégory and Camille’s warm friendly welcome. The couple has created strong ties with local producers, such as Ferme d’Artagnan and Ferme Fourchette, who have become part of the family. The chef crafts their excellent ingredients generously and creatively, underscoring the distinctive flavour of Belgian endive with braised beef cheeks, crunchy celeriac and marinated onion. Authentic Liège recipes and a fine view of the cottage garden from the terrace.

Name: Cœur de Bœuf
Address: avenue du Général Gracia 23, Profondeville, 5170, Belgium
Description: The barbecue gets ample use in this Bib Gourmand establishment, a family-run brasserie where you can feast on traditional meat specialities in a laid-back setting. Beef from all corners of the globe is the main feature of the extensive à la carte selection and set menu. Think succulent Rouge de Famenne rump steak tagliata served with fresh fries. Generosity and à la minute cooking are the norm here. Feel free to take the menu home afterwards; it's full of fun facts!

Name: French Kiss
Description: A pleasant restaurant renowned for its excellent grilled dishes and impressive wine list. Dining area with a low ceiling and bright paintings adding colour to the brick walls.

Name: dis-moi où ?
Description: Tell me where? Well, here! If you are looking for food that combines tradition and generosity, this upbeat eatery is the place for you (don’t forget to book). Chef Nicolas Michiels not only knows how to concoct good sauces and grill meat to perfection, he is also a dab hand at whipping up more elaborate recipes of great delicacy. He might mix a subtle quenelle of scallops and langoustine with a seafood jus, creating an exquisitely delicate balance. Choosing from the extensive menu may pose something of a conundrum. Why not try one of the excellent whiskeys suggested by the chef at the end of your meal?

Name: l'Apropos
Description: After a facelift, L’Apropos now sports a warm, bright interior with colourful artwork. Chef Fournier shares his love of world, Mediterranean, Asian and North - African food, which he skilfully mixes and prepares, demonstrating a flawless sense of balance.

Name: Tou.Gou
Description: A single glance at the wholesome country menu, featuring rustic staples such as grilled tripe and snails, pork pie and partridge with endives, will set your tastebuds tingling. The veteran chef, a true disciple of text-book Gallic fare, enjoys adding the odd international twist. Gutsy flavours, hearty helpings, culinary proficiency. A take-out delicatessen service is also available.

Name: Sel et Poivre
Address: rue de la Fontaine 3, Hollain, 7620, Belgium
Description: Welcome to Nathalie and Alexis’ lovely little restaurant. Their enthusiasm is as communicative as their traditional cuisine. This is made from excellent produce and is enticing without forgetting the occasional dash of humour. A salt - and - pepper combination to which we will happily return.

Name: Borse van Amsterdam
Description: Borse is a landmark of Amsterdam, as much for its colossal architecture and historic Flemish décor as for its restaurant. With its huge terrace overlooking the Grand-Place, it has been a blue-chip value for donkey’s years. The menu focuses on generous helpings of time-honoured family favourites and you will instantly be able to taste the deft hand of a seasoned chef who knows how to enhance authentic flavours.

Name: Michel
Description: Time seems to have stood still at Michel’s. From the classical interior to the traditional, no - frills food, everything is authentic. Walloon produce and young cockerel take pride of place on the table. A treat for your taste buds.

Name: L'Ôthentique
Description: All that remains of the former farmstead are the old stone vaults, yet the land and its produce are at the centre of this establishment. Chef Collignon hunts out top-notch ingredients that he deftly crafts into appetising, primarily French classics. Don’t miss the house foie gras and its pageant of fresh, unctuous garnishes. The trout, straight from the aquarium on the terrace, is another house speciality. Authentic generosity.

Name: L'Entre D'Eux
Description: Caroline Druine combines delicacy and generosity in dishes that demonstrate her commitment to local, organic ingredients. For example, she pairs wild boar from the next-door forest with “grandma’s” red cabbage and a gutsy dark brown cocoa sauce that is so good you will be licking your fingers after mopping it up with bread! The casual vibe is further amplified by Alexandre’s natural, friendly service. A small patio in the garden planted with pear trees is ideal for alfresco summer dining.

Name: De Farmasie
Description: A good meal is just what the doctor ordered! So, book a table quickly in this fashionable establishment, quirkily adorned with a 17C pharmacy cabinet. The chef, a keen “farm to table” adept who is equally at home with rib steak and Thai curry, demonstrates an innate flair for flavours and tastes. The owner adores sharing his love of fine (Italian) wine with diners.

Name: L'Embellie
Address: rue de la Station 115, Soignies, 7060, Belgium
Description: Make your day that little bit better with a visit to this restaurant run by charming maître d' Géraldine and seasoned chef Pol. Grab a table at the front of the cosy dining space, or head to the back, where light pours in from the lovely garden – either way, you're in for a treat! When it comes to the quality of his ingredients, the chef refuses to compromise, a pursuit of excellence that is matched by his culinary expertise. This cuisine is incredibly generous, and it shows in every dish, from the rich foie gras terrine served with succulent pheasant to the rich miso jus that lends a subtle spiciness to the sea bream. Pure passion is at play here!

Name: De Gebrande Winning
Description: This characterful farmstead with a cafe at the entrance has lost none of its authentic charm. The focus is on beer and premium produce before all else. Indeed, an annual beer festival, an awe-inspiring beer menu and knockout beer associations demonstrate the star role of brewed beverages here. Chef Sainte pairs this ethos with no-nonsense food that shines the spotlight on nostalgic Flemish recipes, albeit with subtle modern touches. Rare beef is served with fresh green peas, asparagus and a gutsy gravy: rugged, generous cooking that hits the spot every time and which never fails to bring a smile to the face of satisfied diners.

Name: Boris & Maurice
Description: It is crystal clear that Boris and Maurice have worked together before (at Bodo). Their friendly neighbourhood eatery with a long counter offers tasty bistro fare with a twist. For example, you may start with deep-fried bites of sole and tartare sauce, followed by a juicy breast of chicken and a masterful Archiduc sauce (mushrooms and cream), finishing with a chocolate mousse. The French wine list adds the final flourish to this appetising banquet.

Name: Ni Shifu
Description: Sichuan cuisine is renowned for its hot spices, pungent herbs, rich oils and wok hei preparations and the chef here deftly mixes all these components. Traditional fish soup is prepared with a rich stock and marinated Chinese cabbage, while pork belly and pork neck are braised and cooked in chili and fermented black beans: comfort food so good we warrant you will be wiping your plate squeaky clean. Close your eyes and the bustling ambience of this down-to-earth eatery may well transport you straight to Chengdu. The endless menu is truly mind-blowing. The quintessence of a Bib Gourmand!

Name: Magma
Address: Rue Porte aux Oies 43, Liège, 4020, Belgium
Description: It is heaven to spend time in this hip, upbeat eatery. Tom Foguenne has creatively sourced a lineup of local organic produce out of which he crafts mind-blowing flavours. He might mix smoked trout and tomato with subtly spicy oils, or serve fried chickpeas with cream of yoghurt. Each dish is steeped in unusual tastes and savours, further enhanced by the knockout organic, natural wine list. Instinctive cuisine and a frequently changing menu.

Name: Furbetto
Description: Gust and Jasper have established their friendly eatery a stone’s throw from Heverlee railway station in a smart if somewhat low-key town house. Their love of cooking and devotion to simplicity shine through as you watch them wield their magic in the open-plan kitchen. Homemade is the name of the game here, underscored by a constant quest for superlative local produce. After nibbling on a delicious focaccia appetiser, dig into homemade pasta and subtle dishes, such as blue cheese pie paired with fermented raspberries.
